description:
More ramen please! The best part about this place is you can add to the waitlist on Yelp. Give yourself extra time as I added myself to the waitlist at 8:00pm on a Saturday and didn't sat until 9:30 but the best part is we didn't have to wait at the restaurant. You can check for your place in line on Yelp. 

I've been here 3 times in the last month and have to say it's pretty good. Who ever decided  to call the meatball here "fluffy" was a genius. This chicken meatballs are pretty darn good. I've had the Chicken Paitan ramen and I really like how the broth has a thick soupy mouth feel. I asked if this was dairy based since it was so creamy but the staff assured me it wasn't. How they did get it so thick? potato. The ingredients here are really fresh and organic including the onsen (poached) egg. I'm usually whatever about bamboo but the bamboo at this place is amazing. It is actual pieces and it just has this smokey flavor and a nice crunch to it, don't skip this. The chicken paitan soup itself is like a good chicken soup and brightened with a yuzu (citrus). This is by far my favorite ramen here. 

The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce has a chicken leg in it. Don't be intimidated by this as the chicken falls apart easily with your chopstick. It was the perfect combination of savory and salty. 

I got the chicken bun appetizer and it does not compare to good Peking duck in white bun. The mayo and lettuce was very underwhelming, some green onion might have saved this but I would say skip this. The miso cucumbers were only ok too. 

I would say this is my second favorite ramen place with Mensho being my first. But this place is pretty admirable and I've been back 3 times in the last month.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
I joined the waitlist via yelp at 6:15 and got a table for two at 6:57 on a Friday night. The place was packed! My boyfriend and I squeezed into a long table between two couples. 

We got two bowls of chicken paitan soy sauce ramen and takoyaki fries for starter. The fries, imagine fries drizzled with soy sauce and mayo sauce. It was good to start but got salty towards the end. It was $11, a bit overpriced. The ramen came with one big chicken leg that was tender but flavorless. The broth was flavorful, not too oily. The ramen al dente just how I like it. They do not offer extra ramen on the side. The ramen was decent but $18??? What???

The restaurant was so loud I had to yell at the beginning. Halfway through I gave up and finished my food as fast as I could so I could get out. It was not a pleasant $60 meal.
author: Angela T.

description:
We were excited to try this place because of all the rave reviews. Nojo delivered on the atmosphere and taste of food, but for whatever reason the richness didn't quite sit well with us post-meal - leaving us really bloated and lethargic unlike any other ramen place we've eaten at before. 

We showed up on a Wednesday night at 6pm and the restaurant was already full. They have an iPad where you can add yourself to the waitlist. We waited just a couple of minutes. By the time we left at 7.30pm, the line was a half hour long at least.

The atmosphere was lively - a good place to get some drinks and ramen but not for an involved conversation. 

Service was efficient and we took their recommendation for the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce. I was a little apprehensive about the whole chicken leg in the ramen, but it turned out to be really tender so it was falling off the bone. Points off for it being such a different temperature - lukewarm - than the steaming hot ramen that they dropped the pre-prepared chicken into. Also, for the too fatty skin that was inedible. 

The noodles had a great texture, nice and springy, and held on to the broth and garlic oil well. The broth had a real richness to it, possibly overly so. 

When we left, I thought the food was on the rich side and maybe I'd try something else next time. However, just a little while later and we were both struggling with the effects of that overly rich and fatty broth. 

Now don't get me wrong, I like flavor as much as the next person and ramen by its definition needs to have a rich fattiness. But it shouldn't ever leave you feeling bloated and just generally unwell. 

For that reason, I'm going to pass on this one
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Nojo is one of the best places to go for ramen in the city. The most convenient part is that you can add yourself to the waitlist on Yelp. The restaurant itself is pretty small, so prior to the waitlist the wait would often be over an hour. With the Yelp waitlist, you can arrive at the estimated time. There might be a little wait for you table but it shouldn't be more than a couple of minutes. I think the restaurant is best suited for 2 people. 

For appetizers, the Takoyaki Fries are great to share among friends. For ramen, I have tried both the Chicken Paitan and the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce, and I definitely think the latter is better. They are both very heavy and creamy, but the soy sauce version has more intricate flavors.
author: Poy W.

description:
Teetering between a four and a half and a five, I decided to round up this instance instead of down because Nojo is no joke. I thought I knew ramen coming from Houston and trying out various ramen joints in Chinatown (and I am proud to say our Chinatown is phenomenal), but Nojo literally blew my mind away. 

I ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce. Now let me say that everything in this dish was incredible. It was well balanced. Great proportions. It wasn't salty like a salty ex, which is rare with most ramen. My keyboard is literally looking like an olympic diving pool covered with my drool just thinking about it. 

The ramen is good, the chicken is good but this was my very first time trying out fried gobo. I was literally saving it for later because I didn't eat too much of it at once because I wanted to get bits of it in every bite. Not sure if I ate it the right way but it was absolutely delicious.

My green tea was ok. And the macha creme brulee wasn't my most favorite but it tasted exactly like macha. But next time I could go without those two things. Anytime that I'm in SF, I'll definitely make it a ritual to stop by at Nojo for the chicken paitan soy sauce.
author: Zain R.

description:
This place is chill, wish it was bigger and able to accommodate more people but then it would be a ramen factory. The music and lightning are just right. It doesn't feel pretentious at all even though a coke is $4 and the ramen is $18. 

The service is great, everyone's busy at dinner time but busy isn't unfriendly. I asked our server what her favorite ramen was and she asked me questions in return. She asked if I liked spicy food or not, she wanted to make sure I enjoyed my food. 

It's new still, so there aren't layers of grease build up, that being said the place is really clean. It's well lit so if it was dirty you would notice right away. 

We started with the tofu and avocado salad, it also had okra, tomatoes and cucumbers. It was refreshing and tasty. I got Nikumaki rice ball, it's basically pork belly with teriyaki rice. It was really salty but really good. We got a teriyaki chicken bowl for the kid and I had the ten ten spicy miso Ramen. I was sweating just the right amount when I was done. One consideration is that all of the Ramen here is chicken except for the vegetarian, the vegetarian is also a vegan option. 

We ended with the green tea ice cream, they make desert extra fun. 

All the ramen places in San Francisco today, I'm glad I tried this place but I've got others that I like more. Still, this place is delicious. It's a little bit on the expensive side. And there's almost always a wait.
author: Ben M.

description:
I've been to Nojo a few times now and this is up on my list  for best ramen spots in the city. I've had the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce and the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso Ramen, and both satisfied my ramen cravings. The broth was flavorful and rich, and the noodles still had a nice chew to them. The Tan-Tan Spicy Miso also had a spicy kick to it which I liked. The Takoyaki Fries are also a good appetizer to share while you wait for your ramen. 

Their menu seems to change from time to time, but the ramen selection seems to stay the same. This place also gets fairly busy so I recommend placing your name on the Yelp waitlist before coming over. The staff are also friendly and attentive, and the food comes out fairly fast. I definitely plan on coming back to try out their Chicken Paitan Tomato ramen!
author: Michael L.

description:
Best ramen I've had in SF so far.

Before checking out Nojo, I'd been largely disappointed by the ramen in this city, especially compared to NYC. But as others have noted, the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen is very well done. Tender chicken, chewy noodles, decadent but not overly greasy broth and interesting textural contrast with the chives and fried Japanese yam flakes on top- overall a very well balanced bowl.

Only reason I'm detracting a star is it's on the pricey end, even for ramen...but hey I guess this is SF.
author: Harry X.

description:
Chicken paitan tomato ramen - 5/5. This might just be the novelty of never having had this type of ramen, but it was kind of like if spaghetti in marinara sauce were a ramen. The ramen itself was solid, and the tomato flavor was great with the shredded chicken and meatballs (which were extra), which you would expect it to be like marinara sauce. The broth itself was surprisingly light given that you would expect tomato sauce.

Takoyaki fries - 4.5/5. Its just fries with takoyaki seasonings, but they added enough of the seasoning that it felt like you were eating takoyaki,  so give it a try if you like takoyaki.
author: Nevin L.

description:
After an intense yoga workout, we were ready to chow down on the Nojo's signature Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce dish. There was about a 20 min wait when we got there at 9pm on a Thursday.

Unfortunately, the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce was sold out... what a disappointing way to start the meal. Instead, we ordered: 

1. Teriyaki Chicken Bun: chicken was dry, the "house" tartar sauce tasted like mayo that was made to cover up the dry chicken, and the bun was definitely store bought. Do not order. 
2. Chicken Paitan regular: noodles were al dente, the broth is super bland but we ordered a spice bomb to make it more interesting...would not order again
3. Chicken Paitan Tan-tan Spicy Miso: not spicy at all. This one was decent if you enjoy the tan-tan flavor

Overall, we were pretty disappointed. I'm not sure I'd go back, even if I didn't try the signature dish.

My weekly yoga workout was more memorable than anything we ate that tonight.
author: Yuchen L.

description:
The perfect bowl of ramen exists and it's located in San Francisco. I found Nojo via the Yelp app, and have done nothing but sing its praises ever since. After asking the hostess what their most popular bowl was, I settled on her suggestion of the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce. 

With a savory and salty soy broth, the noodles simmered beneath a whole chicken leg, soft-boiled dashi egg, green onion, and fish flakes. The bowl was perfect to enjoy on this cool and windy afternoon! Service was pretty quick, and even though the restaurant was packed, I was seated, served, and out the door in less than 45 minutes.
author: Callie G.

description:
I looove Ramen, but sometimes it can be a challenge to find a vegan-friendly bowl of ramen that has a developed broth that compares to its meat-based counterparts.

I've tried the Vegan ramen at Mensho Tokyo, which deserves its shiny 5 stars from me for its rich creamy broth.
I noticed that Nojo had a veggie ramen, and wanted to compare the two.

The Veggie Miso Ramen is vegetarian by default but can be made vegan by omitting the butter. IMO, the butter is not missed at all because this bowl hit my taste buds out of the ballpark.

It is rich, creamy, dense, and savory. It is topped with corn, scallions, this veggie 'meat' (mushroom?), okra, and beet chips.
The veggie meat provided an additional fatty element as well as texture. I loved the addition of the okra & beet chips and wished they put in more than just 2 pieces of each. I thought the noodles were cooked well.

I ordered it as-is, but if I were to come back, I'll probably add their belovedly-called 'spice bomb.' 
Speaking of their toppings, I think the pricing to add items is a little insane. $2 to make it spicy? $2 to add a few leaves of cilantro or dashes of oil?? Come on...I find that ridiculous especially since the bowls of ramen already start around $17+.

Overall, if we're comparing this one to Mensho, Mensho wins. It has way more toppings included, which makes the meal feel more filling and complete. Plus, I think Mensho's ramen flavor just has that extra element of depth to it. (They finish it off with a chili oil and a few other ingredients)

I also tried the Oze no Yukidoke Sake, which is a filtered dry Sake. Really smooth and delicious, pairing well with the meal.

We came here at 6:30pm and the restaurant was only half full. By 7pm, there was a wait and a crowd forming outside. There are a few 2-top booths, with the rest being communal or bar seating.

However, I definitely want to come back because it is still a damn good bowl of ramen. Plus, it's only a block away from the Davies Symphony Hall, making it a perfect pre-show dinner!
author: Lanie L.

description:
Let's just get this out of the way. There's nothing real "authentic" about this place. And for me, who is all but anaphylactic-shock allergic to pork is JUST FINE since most (all?) of their broths are analogous to the protein in the soup.

We were immediately seated and the restaurant was quickly packed at about 5:30. The waitstaff were super attentive with the water. A big bonus with the usually sodium-dense broths of ramen. Note: they only seat full parties

Though Chicken Paitan Tomato ramen is a bit more like a tomato soup than any ramen I've ever had, it's also epic creamy and rich. The Grana Padano cheese and lemon are delicious and effective garnishes.

I'm not a pasta person in general, but if I need a bowl of ramen and don't want to fear what's in my bowl, this is a memorable option for sure!
author: Mari H.

description:
This ramen is sooooo good!  As expensive as it is, Nojo Ramen has earned it's spot on my list of must-have-ramen in the bay. 

The environment at Nojo's is classy and comfy, unlike other ramen restaurants. You can eat comfortably without feeling like you're invading the other tables' privacy. 

I tried the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen ($19) and the tan tan ramen ($18). Both were delicious, but the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen was much more flavorful. They give you a whole chicken leg in that, whereas in the tan tan ramen, you get minced chicken/pork instead. 

I would rather have a whole chicken leg than minced meat, but that's just a personal preference. 

I would definitely go out of my way to have this ramen again. So stoked to finally find a ramen place  aside from Ramen Parlor that I enjoy!
author: Destynnie T.

description:
I got their Tantanmen, which ended up being over $20 after tax and tip. I hate how they charge $2 for an egg. The ramen is already expensive enough as it is.

The broth wasn't that flavorful or spicy, but it definitely was FULL of cilantro! I love cilantro, but this was like a couple handfuls of cilantro. Never had that in Tantanmen before, and never will again.

The noodles were the only thing that carried the meal. The fried scallions were kind of weird, and I don't remember eating or tasting much ground chicken. For $22, I expected much, much, much better.
author: Michael K.

description:
An average ramen restaurant in Hayes Valley that may hit the spot but will likely leave you underwhelmed. There are much better ramen places in San Francisco. I got the chicken paitan, but people say the chicken paitan soy sauce is a better option. There seems to be great variability in taste between menu items.

I came here with a friend on a Thursday evening, during which the restaurant was crowded. We waited around 15 minutes. The interior design has the standard shiny black finish. the seating arrangement is more crowded than your usual restaurant, but on par for ramen spots. There are "bar" seats, "long table" seats, and regular table seating. We got a nice corner table by two glass windows looking out to the street. It was for sure the best seat in the entire restaurant. 

I ordered the chicken paitan and my friend ordered the chicken paitan tomato. The chicken paitan soup tasted like chicken broth, and ramen portions were small. It has an interesting lemon flavor that can be hit or miss. My friend described the chicken paitan tomato as being "acidic". Neither of us were impressed. 3/5.
author: Chris W.

description: Love tomato soup, feels like drinking pasta. It's very flavorful and smooth. But I am not impressed about shredded chicken.
author: Hana H.

description:
I'm not typically a chicken paitan fan since I normally go with the fatty tonkotsu pork broth. But the pictures and raving reviews here at Nojo really intrigued me. In what world can you resist such a good looking chicken leg?!

So of course, I got the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce - their classic ramen dish with slow braised whole chicken leg, blackened garlic oil, nira, dashi egg, red onion, scallion, fish powder, fried gobo (burdock root - it's yummy don't worry). At $18.50, I was definitely paying above market for this ramen. Though the portion size was average, I was very happy with the flavor and fattiness of the broth, tenderness of the chicken, and texture of the noodles. The broth did get progressively saltier, but it was tasty nonetheless. 

It's really hard to describe ramen to the T and I feel that everyone has different preferences. Though relying purely on someone else's review is IMO insufficient, I will still go ahead and recommend Nojo as one of my favorite ramen spots in the bay area.
author: Sally L.

description:
My friend and I had dinner here. It's much smarter to book a table on Yelp than actually go there and sign up, in which case you'll still be on that same Yelp waitlist.

My friend and I had the nanba, which was the fried chicken fritters. The chicken wasn't fried all that well and was average at best. It was also covered in what felt like an egg salad. All over soggy and kind of overly salted, I would pass on this.

For the ramen I had the soy sauce chicken paitain. That dish was pretty good, especially the broth which was rich and flavorful and all around good. I felt the chicken was a little dry in some spots, but overall not that bad. The ramen was firmer which is how I like it as well.

Overall the ramen was decent, and quite filling but I would pass on the nanba in the future.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Came by for dinner on a Friday night around 6:30PM and waited for about 45 minutes for a table of 2. They have a good system through Yelp for their waitlist and they do move people off the list relatively quickly. 

The restaurant is pretty small and intimate, but they have a pretty good size menu with different options. We tried the tan tan ramen, the chicken paitan with the chicken leg, and umami wings. The wings were my favorite thing we ordered - I would go back just for that!

The tan tan ramen was pretty spicy and had a strong herb taste to it. It also had a ton of cilantro, so it wasn't anything like what a usual tan tan ramen would taste like.

The chicken ramen was delicious and had a great soup base and noodles, but it was a thick soup and quite oily.

I don't think this is the best ramen option in the city, but I think all of their appetizers look pretty good and unique, so I would recommend those! Plus service was really good here.
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
I really wanted to give place 5 stars, but the hostess messed it up. She took the check flipped it over and slammed it on the table so we can see the receipt. How RUDE!! So I asked for another beer! 

So first put your name on the waitlist before you arrive it saves you a lot of time!!! We were seat 5 minuets before our scheduled show time.  Our server was DA BEST!!!!! It was our first time there so we asked alll the questions.  Ordered the tan tan spicy miso with extra spice BOMB!!! It was delicious! I will be back when I want fancy ramen!!! Definitely check this place out!!!!
author: Dorothy M.

description:
Wow, wow, wow! My tastebuds say yes, this is wonderful! Chicken paitan soy sauce ramen was delish! Come hungry and be prepared for a rich and heavy meal! 

Why I was here // Came for a date with my boo. Definitely add yourself on the yelp waitlist because the wait gets long pretty quickly for weekend dinner nights. 

Service // Quick and efficient. 

Food // 
-Appetizer // Chicken Nanban // 9.00 // very different from the crispy karaage chicken, even though it's fried. The flavor is delicious but expect a more soft texture (not too crispy) and more saucy. 

-Ramen // chicken paitan soy sauce // 18.50 // pretty crazy but the night we went to visit - around 9pm we ordered this and pretty much got the last two of the night! Worth the wait and worth the price. The broth is well developed and the texture of the noodles were wonderful! The braised chicken leg was so flavorful with the meat coming easily off of the bone. 

Overall // Really enjoyed the Ramen here! I would come back but not too often because it's such a heavy meal. Come hungry and plan to wait long if you come on a busy night, cuz this place is bumpin!
author: Emily T.

description:
Having just returned from my trip to Japan where the ramen was simply amazing, I did not think the ramen here would be able to compare. However, I was pleasantly surprised at how tasty the broth at Nojo was. It immediately hit the spot for me and memories of the delicious bowls I had while abroad came rushing through me. 

I opted for the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce whereas my wife ordered the Chicken Paitan. The flavor profiles of each bowl were different, but both were delicious. The soy sauce bowl was especially savory and hearty; the depth of flavor in the broth immediately filled your mouth when you sip it. The chicken leg and the egg that came with the Chicken Paitain Soy Sauce definitely satisfied my hunger and I was stuffed by the time I finished this bowl. 

The Chicken Paitan was very light and tasted like it had a hint of yuzu or something citrusy. I really liked the fluffy chicken tsukune meatballs as well -- they were, for a lack of a better word, fluffy. 

We also ordered a side of chicken wings and finished the meal off with a Monaka ice cream sandwich (black sesame flavored). Both were good choices and tasty, although the portions were a bit small for the price point. 

I would go back for some delicious chicken ramen and recommend checking this place out. Also, we were able to put our name on their electronic guest list which worked seamlessly through the Yelp app. We put our name down on the guestlist while we were 20 minutes out and by the time we arrived, we were able to bypass the crowd of 10 people and were promptly seated!
author: Simon S.

description: This is my favorite Ramen place in SF, maybe even in the whole world. The have very creative flavors and seasonal limited-time ramen flavors that I love. Most of the time when I visit, I order their classic Paitan Ramen with chicken leg in it. This place never fail to please me. They seriously need to expand though, the wait can be really long.
author: Jessie L.

description:
I was looking for a good place to meet up with a friend and found this place on Yelp. It had lots of good reviews so it seemed promising.  We got there early--shortly after the 5pm opening; there was no waiting and only a few tables occupied at that time. It got crowded quickly as it neared 6pm.  

Menu had lots of choices--small plates/tapas, salads, ramen--it all looked so good that we had trouble deciding what to order.  We decided to share an appetizer and opted to order their signature offering--ramen.  

We ordered a specialty dish, the Nikumaki rice ball meatball (pork belly wrapped in rice) and the chicken paitan tomato (dashi soft boiled egg on the side) and chicken paitan soy sauce.  Overall, the broths were thick, good flavor, well seasoned and not overly salty. The noodles, however, were okay, I thought a bit on the chewy side, wished it were just a little softer.

For a ramen restaurant, I was surprised
that there wasn't any tonkotsu broth (pork based) offered and only chicken broth was on the menu.  

This was worth the try...but no immediate plans on returning.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Definitely makes the cut for the top 3 ramen places in SF!

The wait can be pretty long so I recommend adding yourself to the yelp waitlist. 

The Chicken Paitan Soy is wonderful! Great flavor, chewy noodles, and quality ingredients. If you're a Marufuku or Ippudo kind of gal, you'll like Nojo.
author: Alicia L.

description:
I'm so torn. I wanted to love this place bc of the high reviews but this place is just meh and while I didn't hate my ramen, I wasn't a huge fan of the flavor profile and the broth. I would consider the ramen here more fusion than traditional.

Having lived in Japan, Tonkotsu style ramen is MY LIFE. I have traveled near and far to try anything that has that creamy oily pork bone broth. They don't have a pork option here. No biggie. Most of their menu is either veggie or chicken. 

We ordered the chicken paitan and the chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso. The presentation for both was a 10, but other than that, I was not a fan. The chicken meatballs in mine were light, but flavorless and only came with 3 pieces (that's all the toppings besides bamboo). I liked that they used fresh bamboo shoots, but once again it was 2 small pieces.  The noodles were okay. Not chewy. Not soft. The broth was rich without being overly salty, but the flavor reminded me of Chinese herbal medicine that my mom used to brew. Also the yuzu they grated into the broth was over-powering. Towards the end of my bowl, every bite of noodle was covered in yuzu shavings. 

The tan-tan spicy chicken was not spicy at all and the broth was oily and bland. It also didn't have much chicken. The ground chicken sort of disappears into the broth as you start eating.  

We also ordered a soft boiled egg as a side, gyoza, ice cream sandwich, and some sake. Don't order the egg. It lacks any sort of flavor/taste. Literally just an egg. I can do that at home. The gyoza was deep fried and covered in a curry like powder. Pretty tasty. Ice cream sandwich was good. We got the sesame flavor. It comes in a sugar cone shaped like a Daruma doll. The sake was alright. Nothing special. We got a small carfe and that ran $25.

We came here mainly bc it's located near the Nourse Theatre (across the side street). Come early (we got here at 5:30ish) or else the wait is long. If you don't want to wait, you can check in through the Yelp app before you get there and it will "stand" in line for you.

With many other establishments offering a more "traditional" taste, once was enough for me.
author: Junella T.

description:
Currently my favorite bowl of ramen in SF :)

If you haven't been to Nojo in a while, the ownership changed and the menu followed suit. For me, their Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen is just amazing. Definitely worth the upgrade from the Chicken Paitan (especially considering it includes the tender chicken), though I can see some people preferring a more "plain" broth so in that case, the regular version is definitely good too.

(If you're on the fence though, try the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce.)

It has several included toppings that would cost way more to add a la carte, delicious broth and great noodles. Man, I would go back now if I could.

Also, notably: the waits can be long (30min+). Nojo is closed on Mondays, and only open for lunch on Sundays.
author: Greg G.

description:
Definite utilize the Yelp wait list feature. My friend and I came here for dinner on a Tuesday night and probably would have had to wait over an hour if we hadn't put our names on the waitlist via Yelp on the walk over. We still waited about twenty minutes once we got there but it was well worth it! 

My friend ordered the chicken paitan with a side of soft boiled egg and a spice bomb and I ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce. At first, I was a little skeptical because I'm such a fan of traditional tonkotsu ramen and tonkotsu is my go to order at any new ramen place. But I was really pleasantly surprised by the ramen - the broth was flavorful without being too salty, the noodles were perfectly chewy and the braised chicken leg was fall-off-the-bone tender. One slight pet peeve: my egg was way over cooked to the point of being just a hard boiled egg. One of my favorite parts of ramen is eating that gooey creamy soft boiled egg so I was a little disappointed by that, considering how good the other elements of the dish were.
author: Amanda O.

description: Yummy chicken broth ramen! In the past, it was my first time trying chicken based ramen. Thick and rich broth. However, the broth was extremely salty. Great thick noodles were definitely memorable. The bowl was very filling. Egg was perfectly cooked. Yum. Long wait over an hour was actually worth it.
author: Andrea S.

description:
I've been here twice already and I always get the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen cuz it's the best!!! 
Planning on going back to try the other dishes. 

This place gets pretty packed easily so I highly recommend joining the waitlist thru Yelp!
author: Krista D.

description:
Delicious ramen in a trendy environment 
Small place that doesn't take reservations so id you're with a party larger than 2 or 3 people plan ahead and go early to get on the wait list.
author: Mariaté G.

description:
I like getting the chicken paitan soy sauce. It is tasty without being too salty. Noodles are the perfect texture, and the soup is creamy and thick. Egg is cooked to perfection as well! 

Portions are too big to finish comfortably but not so huge that you start to dislike it. The perfect time to come is when you feel hungry.
author: Andrea T.

description:
Cozy place. The noodle and the soup are delicious. We went on Friday and the wait was not too bad. 
Highly recommend the pork bun. Great place to stop by.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Let me preface this by saying my boyfriend is forcing me to try every ramen spot in the city to find the one that remains supreme -- and after many bowls of ramen, Nojo ties with Marufuku.

We had the hamachi appetizer - super tasty and fresh. Love the toppings.

We had some of the last bowls of the chicken soy sauce ramen and we are sooo glad. The chicken is fall off the bone tender, and the skin is such a guilty pleasure. Tasty broth and perfect egg.

The wait is long but it's super convenient that you can get in line on Yelp, so you can chill at home until your table is almost ready.
author: Miranda M.

description:
This cute little gem was a great find and conveniently located right next to the Nourse Theatre. 

Came here on a rainy afternoon around 5:30 PM and made it just before the dinner rush. The waitresses were very accommodating and friendly as they took our orders. 

I shared a plate of takoyaki fries with my friend and enjoyed the savory sauce and bonito flakes mixed in with the fries. For my entree, I decided to try their chicken paitan tomato ramen with a spice bomb but sadly the spice bomb didn't make the ramen as spicy as I had hoped. The ramen broth was very rich and heavy, and I really enjoyed the texture of the noodles. 

I would definitely love to come back to this cute little restaurant and try some of their ramen dishes! While they are not ramen in the traditional sense, the flavors they have are very bold and well-crafted!
author: Allison T.

description:
2.5 stars. My roommates and I have been on a ramen binge, trying to discover the best spots around the city. While they fell in love with Nojo Ramen, I hated my experience here. Yes "hate" is a strong word, but I mean it. 

We put our names down and were told to wait for 1.5 hours. Instead of sticking around like we should have, we went for a drink and came back 50 minutes later. There was a hostess with bangs (wish I got her name) who was so incredibly rude. It makes me angry to think about it. She was super condescending at our request to get back on the list, and while I understand the frustration, there are nicer ways to handle the situation.

Anyways, we were seated at the bar. The stool was wobbly, but it was cool to see all the cooks do their thing. I was sitting close to the end of the bar. I suspect the last seat is reserved for VIP food critics or something because all the waitress treated anyone in that seat like a god, including that hostess. Why don't you do your job instead of flirting with customers?

We ordered Takoyaki Fries and a Rice Ball to share as an appetizer. They were pretty good! I'd recommend both of them. For my entrée, I had the vegetarian ramen which was okay. I wouldn't order it again. I would, however, get the black sesame ice cream sandwich again.

If you're on a similar journey to find good ramen in SF, I'd say to try Nojo once. I just wouldn't come here again because of the negative customer service vibe. It seems that not eveyone likes working here, and a select few have attitude issues. I just don't want to be around that. Anyways, even the ramen alone wasn't enough to come back, but it's important to experience the whole spectrum of restaurants.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Absolutely love this place and now that they have started a waitlist within Yelp, it's my favorite spot for ramen in the city given the predictable wait time and amazing quality of food! 

Ordered the vegetarian ramen with the spice bomb - it was absolutely delicious. Highly recommend the spice bomb if you like spice. The fries were addictive! 

Will come back for their seasonal veggie ramen which they were out of.
author: Eshita S.

description: This place has got to be one of my top favorite places for ramen. My friend and I shared the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen and the spicy chicken soboro tossed noodles. The soup ramen was my fave. The broth was so rich and flavorful. The chicken was also packed with flavor and just slides off the bone. The noodles were cooked perfectly, not too hard not too soft. The tossed noodles were good, but I don't think I would order it again. Definitely order the chicken soy sauce ramen if it's your first time. Loved it.
author: Valerie C.

description:
The best part of 2017's J-Pop Summit occurred before walking through the doors at Fort Mason: a ramen showdown just out front featured an army of ramen purveyors, each offering only one specialty.  The lines for every vendor were off-putting and I opted for the single vendor with a very short line, Nojo, despite being certain that the ramen they were offering was the one I wanted least of all.

Then something happened.  

I sat down with my Chicken Paitan Ramen and it utterly wowed me.  The flavors were soothing and delicious and I finally almost understood the appeal of comfort food.  This was it.  

A meal at the restaurant itself proved somewhat less satisfying owing largely to the value proposition (there's no value to be found in ramen that costs $18.50 before any add-ons) and a perceived lack of complex flavors.  

Nojo Ramen Tavern is perpetually crowded with virtually no time when there's not a wait for a table.  By the time I was seated - around 10 p.m. on a weeknight - they'd run out of their Vegetable Miso Ramen and because I wanted to try something new and something different than my dining partner my options were limited.  At the recommendation of my server, I opted for the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ($18.50) and sampled the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso ($17.50) of my table-mate.  

Though other reviewers have remarked on small portion size I found the portion size adequate and filling.  For that price though, it should've been about 30% larger.  And, at that price, I was loathe to request any of the add-ons which could easily have brought the bowlful to nearly $25.  

So I sampled what Nojo offers, straight up, no add-ons.  

Of the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce I'll say this:  for chicken fans, possibly chicken fanatics.  I left almost squawking, sated with rich chicken flavors and not much else.

A conversation ensued and my dining partner remarked similarly.  He wasn't stuffed with chicken but he understood my comment that the whole dish felt sort of one-note.  His had too.  One-note is fine if you really love chicken but the complexity of flavors wasn't there for me.  In no way was this as delightful an experience as I'd had at Oakland's Ramen Shop. 

Pre-tip and with a $7 IPA, 2 bowls of satisfying if not particularly inspiring ramen ran just under $48.  Oddly, I found the ramen I'd expected to like least (that Chicken Paitan Ramen) to be the most satisfying version I sampled.  Was it because I'd paid less at J-Pop?  Was it because I had higher expectations for the restaurant?  Probably a bit of both.  

Nojo is a fine if overpriced ramen purveyor with a  lot of fans.  I'll keep searching because, though it was satisfying, at those prices it should be mind-blowing.
author: Tracey A.

description:
So far, this has been the best ramen I've had in SF. 

I ordered the chicken paitan, and although it was a little on the pricey side, boy was it good. The chicken, with enough time in the broth, slid right off the bone, resulting in the good bone-in taste without any of the hassle. The noodles were chewy and the broth was extremely filling and not too salty.

The wait here is usually pretty long, and there have been times where I got to the door an hour before closing and they'd already run out of noodles! Use the waitlist feature on Yelp before you go for sure.
author: Jatin N.

description:
8.2/10
Chicken Spicy Miso

1. Broth - amazing, not overbearing, flavorful, spice hits your throat
2. Noodle - thinner than usual, wish it was a tad bit softer, didn't add or takeaway from experience 
3. Chicken - chicken was diced in bits, wish I had gotten the braised leg
4. Presentation - loved how deep the bowl was, however my spoon was too flat

Takoyaki Fries- overhyped, but necessary for the meal, it basically is DESTROYED TAKOYAKI on fries- same flavors, no octopus

Edamame- meh, no special seasoning, small portion
author: Nabiha J.

description:
Ironically, after purchasing a ramen t-shirt at Azalea, I decided to check out Nojo for dinner since it was on my way back to BART.

Despite being packed on a Thursday night I managed to get seated after a very short wait at the bar. (Lightning fast service was the name of the game at Nojo.) I was surprised and a bit disappointed by how few ramens are on the menu (five, to be exact), but it's better to do a few things extremely well than a few more things just ok.

I went with the chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso, which has ground chicken, toasted sesame, scallion, cilantro, fried gobo, and a spice bomb. I wasn't sure what to expect from gobo because I'd never had it before, but it was delicious and one of my favorite parts of the dish. It had an earthy taste that worked very well as a fried component sprinkled over the ramen. There was way too much cilantro, all of which I carefully removed from the bowl, but once that was out of the way I was able to appreciate how rich, spicy, and fantastic the flavor of the broth was.

While not the most generous amount of noodles for $17 a bowl, the meal was incredibly good nonetheless. I probably wouldn't make a trip so out of the way again - there are many other ramen options in the East Bay - but if I was in the area I'd be happy to return for another bowl of that tan-tan.
author: Angela M.

description:
Great spot with nice ambiance, friendly staff and delicious food. 
4 stars for now because I had a short experience here but I'm definitely coming back for some ramen! 

PARKING:
No garage, only street parking. Meters go until 6pm (not sure if that's only mon-friday), $3.25 an hour ! Forget the coins, bring your card lol 

WAIT:
It was getting packed when we arrived but since it was just 2 of us, we were luckily seated within 10 minutes. If you're waiting for a table, there's a clipboard next to the door to sign in. They had tables and counter seating. 

NOTE: 
Only one bathroom. But at least they have one ! Also, inside is pretty dim but manageable enough to not bump into people. 

SERVICE:
Staff was friendly overall. Quick and prompt service.

FOOD:
I'm never in the mood for ramen, or anything soup-y (unless I'm sick), so I opted for their teriyaki chicken rice bowl and their Nojo "takoyaki" fries.

Teriyaki chicken rice bowl ($6.50) served in a small cup (pictures included) topped with nori and scallions. Server warned me that this item is very small, and she was right, but it was still filling. Small dish with lots of flavor. Ask for a small plate on the side to put your pieces of chicken on so it's less of a mess.

Nojo "takoyaki" fries ($8): fried octopus balls topped with Kewpie Japanese mayo, bonito flakes and furikake (Japanese seasoning). I'm a sucker for takoyaki and I was disappointed that they didn't offer this dish here but oh well, sorta close enough for me. 

OVERALL: 
I think this is a great place for an intimate get together with friends or a loved one. Expect to pay a little extra for the amount you receive.
author: Grace Anne D.

description:
This place is awesome! I love the ambiance and their food is delicious. A huge plus is that they open @ 4pm rather than the typical 5pm. Arrive early as always cause of the crowds. 

Their menu is sleek, clean and well designed. We came as a group of 7 and ate up! We had rounds of sake and bowls of delicious ramen. I ordered Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso with a side of red chili flakes to spice things up. My ramen was $17 with an extra egg of $1.5 which isn't too bad but a bit too expensive for my taste. I would definitely come back! The broth is thick and delicious with lots of flavor! The noodles were freshly made I can tell because the quality is superb and texture is on point. I love how they top cilantro too! It's my favorite herb and goes insanely great with ramen! I've got to do it more often. 

I like this place a lot and it's part of Hayes Valley which is my favorite district in the city! If you're craving ramen and want it sooner than I prefer this joint!
author: Allister D.

description: Why do I keep doing this.  I don't like Raman. Not here. Not in Tokyo. But it seems my friends do so we show up and wait and wait. Here I got the chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso. Ground chicken and sesame and scallion with some heat. Sounds good with noodles? Ya...was ok. To be fair I should quite going ramen places...but I'm going to keep trying until I find a bowl I like.
author: David S.

description: Ten out of ten would recommend. Absolutely delicious! Make sure to add your name on the waiting list through Yelp before arriving! This place gets pretty busy. Ramen is worth the price!
author: Esmie B.

description:
I came here with my bf for Valentines day so this review is really long overdue lol. Both my bf and I aren't die-hard ramen fans which might explain the lack of excitement?

We ordered the chicken wings, chicken paitan soy sauce ramen for my bf, and the chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso ramen for me. Our favorite part of the entire meal were actually the chicken wings. They were kind of small (and there were only 4, I think?) but they were crispy, hot, and juicy--mmm! Unfortunately, we were not nearly as wowed by the ramen. We both really enjoyed the chicken leg in my bf's ramen but the excitement kind of stopped there lol. Nothing about the ramen was unpleasant, but we didn't find the noodles or the broth any more special than other ramen that we've had at other establishments. 

I really enjoyed the atmosphere and the service at Nojo's, but I didn't leave wanting to come back.
author: Anna L.

description:
My best friends brother's wife loved this place and told us to check it out since we were craving some ramen to get over our hangover from their wedding the night before.


LOCATION-its very close to Blue Bottle Coffee. If you have a car, its street parking only. Good luck with that. 

SERVICE-our server was good. It was our first time here so I had to ask our server what their signature ramen was and she recommended the 

NOJO "TAKOYAKI"FRIES-it was heaven. Its pretty much fries with the sauces that go on top of a Takoyaki. 

CHICKEN PAITAN SOY SAUCE RAMEN-first of all, the presentation was so pretty. Secondly, the broth was a game changer. I thought I had some good ramen in LA, but this changed it all. The egg is boiled to perfection and all the toppings that was in it harmonized the dish. 


The restaurant has a rustic/modern setting and there are ample seating. We went in at 11:30am which is when they open so we didn't have to wait. But even if there is a wait, I would wait to devour this goodness.
author: Mindy K.

description:
You can now add yourself to the waitlist via Yelp, so you don't have to wait outside for hours! It was so convenient to add myself to the waitlist then show up an hour later to only wait 15-20 mins.

The line does get long here, so be prepared to wait! There are private tables, a communal table, and the bar. The service is always fast and nice, so return the favor to others waiting and don't get angry about the quick service. If you're looking for a long sit down/catch up dinner, then this is not the place!

It's always hard for me to choose my FAVORITE ramen place, but I think Nojo is solid. I always get the Paiten soy sauce with the chicken leg. 

- The chicken is literally fall off the bone juicy
- Egg is perfectly yolky
- Heavy/creamy broth so you've been warned! It's tonkotsu style...
- Noodles are wavy, medium thickness, and chewy

Overall it's good for a heavier ramen and always hits the spot every time! I believe it's chicken based broth and they have a vegetarian option if needed.
author: Jackie O.

description:
I was introduced to Nojo by a friend who normally hates going out to eat ramen. That's how good this place is; it's NoJoke!

Came here around 6:30pm on a Saturday night, and the wait was well over an hour. It's not a terribly large area, and tables are pretty close together. Despite the cozy atmosphere, Nojo makes do wit what they have. I like the attention to detail -- The bowls are specific to each type of ramen you order; you can tell what someone ordered by looking at their bowl. The chopsticks are smooth and delicately made, but the tips are textured, so your ramen wouldn't slip everywhere even if you're not the most skilled wielder. 

We grabbed literally the last couple orders of their famous Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen. I appreciate the waitress going around and telling people they're about to run out, even as we were waiting to be seated. It allows those who came for the specific item to reconsider eating here, or have time to decide on ordering something else. 

The ramen was excellent. The noodles themselves are a bit thicker than normal ramen, and were of perfect doneness. Very chewy without being tough or undercooked, and remained that way even towards the end of the meal. The broth was very rich, especially considering it's not the conventional pork-based broth. The chicken... the chicken!! It was so flavorful, so juicy, so tender. Removing the bone took absolutely no effort; a flick of the chopstick and the whole bone slid out. You look at the menu and think the price is a bit high, but considering the quality, the flavor, and the fact that it's in SF (I'm from LA, where food's just cheaper in general), and the price is more than justified.

The wait is long and it's not cheap, but if you ever get the chance, Nojo is a great ramen place.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Wow, this is probably the first time in recent history that I was thoroughly disappointed in my dining experience. My husband and I ordered the chicken bun, the pork belly rice roll, and the chicken leg ramen. The appetizers were tiny - one each on the plate. The ramen has a thick broth, but it made me nauseous. It tasted like sauce soy mixed with corn starch. 
I spent the evening just saying out loud "I can't believe how bad that was..." :(
author: Paulo C.

description:
One of my favorite ramen places in SF! I came here with a friend for lunch on a Sunday. There was a line in front of us but we ended up only waiting about 15 minutes.

We both wanted to try the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen because it had a whole chicken leg but they were already sold out. So I ordered the Chicken Paitan Tomato and was pleasantly surprised! It was my first time having tomato in my ramen broth and it was delicious. The chicken was tender and the cheese added some good texture. The noodles were my favorite part and definitely stood out for being perfectly al dente! I really enjoyed the tomato in the broth which made it taste  like comforting home-cooking.

There were two things that kept the meal from being perfect. First, I forgot to ask them not to add cilantro so it came with an insane amount of cilantro (it was so much that even my friend who liked cilantro was picking it off) but because they just added it on top, I was able to pick it out. Second, my friend ordered the Spicy ramen and she thought the broth was too thick. In fact, an hour or so after the meal, she said she was still nauseous from how heavy the broth of her ramen was.

Fortunately not all the broths are that heavy. Next time I'm coming back to try the soy sauce ramen or maybe even get the tomato ramen again!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Post night out my friends and I were looking for some ramen to satisfy our cravings. It was around 9:30PM so not many places were open much longer but luckily Nojo was open until 10:30PM. 

This place is located near Civic Center so parking can be a pain around here, but if you're lucky you can find some street parking. We came around 9:45PM so it wasn't packed as I would normally think it is. It took about 10 mins for our group of 6 to be seated. 

What's interesting about this ramen joint is that it's mainly a chicken ramen type of place so don't expect to get some chasu with your ramen. When looking at Yelp reviews it seems like this place is known for their Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce (limited amount). We came pretty late so by the time we ordered they were already sold out. :(  Instead we got the: 

- Nojo Takoyaki Fries - Yum! If you're a fan of takoyaki this is a great alternative. It has all the flavors of what you would expect minus the octopus. It's a great dish to share with a group. 

- Chicken Paitan Spicy Miso - Definitely spicier than what I expected & filled with WAY more cilantro too. The broth in this dish was creamy but not too creamy that you couldn't finish you dish. The spice was there and left an afterburn on your lips. I thoroughly enjoyed it but others thought it was too spicy for their liking. I do wish that they had a paste on the side where you can add more depending on your liking. The noodles however were perfect! I love mine a little harder than most so it was cooked just right in my opinion. I did feel like there was WAY more cilantro than needed, if you're not a fan of it I would ask them to remove it like someone else at my table did. As for the chicken, it was tasty but it was sparse in my dish.

- Soboro Noodles (no broth ramen)- If you've been wondering how broth-less ramen tastes then this is your chance! We opted for a poached egg for this dish and I think it was the right choice. It's very similar to the chicken paitan spicy miso but without the spice that the broth entails. The noddles in this dish are a little thicker & flatter as well so it's similar to a fried noodle dish without all the oil. 

Overall, the place is in a great location & is clean. Service here was friendly & even though we came later we didn't feel rushed. The price can seem a little steep but $18ish for a bowl or ramen is what i'd expect in places such as SF.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
This is my favorite all time ramen place.

The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce is my go-to option and the best ramen i've had before. The Spicy Tan-tan is another extremelly good option.

If you want to get an entree, you can't go wrong with the gyozas.
author: Yasu F.

description:
Came here one night for dinner on a weekday. There was a bit of a wait but it wasn't too bad.  We all got seated and all wanted the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce, the one with the whole chicken leg.  It did not disappoint.  They way I described it to friends was that it was ramen that made me excited about ramen again!  Savory broth and tender Chicken!  Add the spice bomb to it, it is totally worth it!!!  The other items looked delicious but we didn't have time for that!!!

Enjoy with a bottle of Sake and finish off with an ice cream sandwich! yum!!!
author: Veasna H.

description:
2 stars for the service, 4 stars for the ramen.

They consistently run out of their ramen long before they're closed for the night; is there anything more frustrating than trucking over to a restaurant, waiting to be seated, and then realizing that they're sold out of the item that you've come to order? This week, I was there at 5:45pm and they were sold out.....terrible customer experience. I would give them a break, but this is something that happens on a weekly basis. They need to get it together.
author: Alex N.

description:
Having lived in the ramen capital of the world (Japan), I've had my share of the different qualities of ramen. Some are borderline fair to googly-anime-eyes-explosive. Nojo falls in the latter category. I haven't had as many chicken-based ramen in the past, so this assessment may be based on a limited sample size. I don't tend to write long reviews about anything, so to me, it speaks to how much of a lasting impression this one dining experience was. The three biggest factors in my subjective, personal dining experience tend to relate to seating, service, and quality of the food itself, so here they are.

Getting seated: 
Table wait times are extensive. Expect a 1-2 hour wait time. You can set your name on the wait list and walk around the block, grab a drink from a bar, or enjoy a conversation with your buddies. We did all of the above. The table itself is 'Nihon-poi', or Japanese-like. Meaning, if you are a taller, larger, American, you may need to limit how much you man-spread lest you bump knees with other diners.

Service: 
We had great service despite how packed the place was. I think that Californians tend to be harsher on this factor in reviews, and I'm a Portlander, so take that with a grain of salt. Our waitress was pleasant, did not seem burnt out, and engaged in some back-and-forth when we made empathetic comments. Our food did not take very long to come out, which is saying something, especially if they are able to keep up with orders and maintain the quality of their product.

Food: 
I had the chickan paitan, and my partner had the tonkotsu. In both dishes, the broth was rich and flavorful. Serving sizes were large-American-worthy. There was a complex (i.e., umami) flavor that distinguished them from each other and from other places where I've dined before. My standards for comparison for this is based on well-known places in Japan that I tend to frequent in various provinces while living there; Ippudo, Gogyo, Tsuta, and Ichiran being amongst the more well-known ones. 

Now, compared with the ramen from Tsuta (a one-Michelin place that also features some dishes with a chicken-based broth), the focus is on enriching the flavor profile of commonly-found ingredients. If you're looking for fancy foie gras quality from a chicken egg, you're shooting too high. What you'll get as you enjoy a bowl, instead, is a deep, rich feeling of almost... nostalgia. I was reminded of a couple of things. First, how unique the experience of enjoying a bowl was in this small-ish restaurant in San Francisco. And second, how the persnicketiness and almost obsessively perfectionistic nature of Japan can often lead to their products having a one-of-a-kind quality. 

Will I return and wait in line for over an hour again? You better believe I will.
author: Sara C.

description:
Nojo has probably the best vegetarian and non-pork ramen I've ever had. I've been there twice, but the first time they ran out of the miso ramen, so I knew I had to come back to try it.

This place is amazing for people like myself who don't eat pork but love noodles. They specialize in chicken based ramen, and I want to come back to try every kind. They also have a vegetarian miso based ramen, which was absolutely amazing. Each bowl is around $16, but they're so large that it definitely feels worth it. The only thing to watch out for is that they sometimes run out of certain kinds of ramen, so if you're eyeing the miso ramen, come early! You have to write your name down, and then they call you once they have space for you.
author: Arya B.

description: I would give 5 ratings just for the Ramen but the side orders were just as I expected in any other Ramen places or even below average for the price. Avocado with seaweed was pretty unique though. The broth for Chicken Paitan is very rich in flavor and unique with a a little bit of Yuzu taste to it, nothing like I've had before. You can add toppings like fried Gobo and soft-boiled Dashi egg to add more flavors to it. I ordered spice bomb for the table and it was good addition if you want to add some chilly oil to the broth. The meatballs in the ramen were delicious, bamboo shoots are not cut in an ordinary way but cut in bigger chunks and add more texture to it. Ramen was very satisfying and made me full. This restaurant is popular and always crowded. I recommend putting your name down on the waitlist through Yelp before walking over, especially at peak lunch/dinner hours.
author: Adel A.

description: Chicken paitan tomato with a spice bomb and chicken meatballs is the bomb! I've been coming here every couple of months for a few years, and it never disappoints. I also recommend the chicken wings. My only complaint is the noise level: they have concrete floors and ceiling, so the sound bounces around. It's super hard to have a conversation.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Nojo is an innovative ramen that doesn't serve the typical tonkotsu style; but highlights a chicken paitan bowl in a few different ways. I tried the tomato paitan, which was basically a Japanese version of spaghetti but so savory and had a bit of umami to satisfy the soul. There was a mix of garlic and even cheese, which made for an interesting fusion not usually seen in normal ramen. The chicken was also very tender, although there were only a few pieces because the bowl was filled with a mish-mash of items.

I also tried a bite of rice ball, which had a delicious soy sauce but was sadly lacking in the amount of pork belly. I also tried a very tiny ice cream sandwich, which had a light cracker-like base and a good black sesame flavor. While the food here is not traditional, the ramen is memorable and a nice change of pace that is perfect for the chilly SF nights.
author: Steven V.

description:
If there were no lines, I would go there every day!

I don't eat pork, so my ramen options are pretty limited. Nojo delivers. Every time.
author: Adam L.

description: Good restaurant with nice atmosphere. Their ramens are based with Tori paitan, a boiled hardy longtime chicken soup stock. I ate spicy one, but I could feel the taste of it.
author: Keisuke W.

description:
Update...

I tried the chicken meatball soup.  It comes with three of the lightest chicken meatballs I've ever had. Truthfully, the only chicken meatballs I've ever had - but very light and tasty.

I'm kind of sorry I mixed the accompanying teaspoon of chopped ginger into the broth.

For me, the ginger detracts from the richness of the chicken flavor, bringing it to an undesirable thin finish.

I'm left with three meatballs, a decoration of green things, and bowlful of thick ramen noodles that are coated in the broth flavor.

Not much for $15.

I say boo on this bowl.

(Formerly had spicy ramen, which I loved!)
author: Sondra H.

description:
Meh, for $18 for a bowl of ramen I was a little disappointed.  Also, I was surprised the menu didn't offer any pork ramen options. The chicken ramen did come with a tender chicken leg where the meat fell right off the bone which was delicious but I wasn't sold on the broth and the trimmings.  For me, I think I prefer more of a traditional ramen. 
The ramen at Nojo is more of an Americanized fusion version, or perhaps some versions are Japanese fusion with a hint of Italian. 

The place fills up fast and we were only lucky enough to get in without a wait by waiting outside before doors opened. They are also very strict about seating everyone until your whole party has arrived.
author: Briana C.

description:
We ordered the gyoza, fries, the chicken soy sauce ramen, and the spicy miso ramen. 

4 stars for the ramen, -1 star for the fries, and +2 stars because this business uses Yelp Nowait to hold my place in line. 

Ramen was clearly the star of the show; see the zillions of other Yelp reviews on the chicken soy sauce ramen. Gyoza was nicely dusted with a curry powder, which made them above average for gyoza. I was disappointed with the fries. They are just fried with mayo and salty stuff on them. They just weren't worth the stomach space when there was delicious ramen to eat! 

Service was amazing. Wow this was my first experience using the Yelp app to put my name down in the waitlist. I timed it with my Lyft ride so that we could breeze our way in and get seated right away. We ended up waiting 5 min at the restaurant, but given that the wait would have been 25 min otherwise, I was a pretty happy camper.
author: Sheewon B.

description:
This is the best ramen in San Francisco!
I love all the ramen here.
Mainly I have a Chicken Paitan ramen.
If you haven't tried it yet, you should try it!
author: Kazuki N.

description:
My friends and I came here on a Thursday evening and the wait wasn't bad at all. There were about twelve parties ahead of us but it went by quickly because many of the parties were no longer there or their whole party wasn't present. The four of us were seated at the bar after about 40 minutes. The worst part about our experience would probably be the parking so be prepared for a walk!

It was our first time here and my boyfriend and I tried out their most known ramen dish, the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ($18.50). I love spicy so I added the spice bomb($1.50) to mine which I really enjoyed. The spice ball wasn't too spicy at all either for those that like spicy! The chicken literally fell off the bone and it was delicious! The broth was super creamy and yummy. Usually the soft boiled egg is my favorite part of the ramen but nothing stood out to me about it. Also they only give you half a soft boiled egg versus a whole soft boiled egg. There was plenty of green onions in the ramen as well which is my favvv!! My boyfriend also added tsukune meatballs($3) and an extra piece of chicken($7) to his ramen. He said he could've managed without the tsukune meatballs. 

Our server was quick and nice. She was good on refilling our drinks and making sure we had all our food! We waited a fairly short amount of time for our food to come out as well. It was about less than 10 minutes or so!

Overall definitely give this place a try if you have the time and don't mind spending a little extra for some bomb ramen!
author: Ha T.

description:
A great dinning spot before the symphony.  Simply a half block from Davies Hall.  

This place can be a little difficult to get seating. No reservations, but they open at 5:00, you can place yourself on their wait lisit via the Yelp App.    We got on the  wait  list at 5:20 while we were driving across the bridge and our name was called at 6:10.   Street parking may be rare around this restaurant.   We parked in the Civic Center Parking for a Safe, well lit, clean facility.  

A very active, fast paced spot.  Our group of three were seated at the higher counter type bar.   Convenient hooks under the table to hang purses and jackets "off the floor."

Appetizers:  Chicken wings are some of the best I have had. They are sprinkled with a spice mixture after being fried - for a exotic surprise.  We also tried the pork belly wrapped rice ball with lettuce.  Nikumaki rice ball - A great piece of "comfort food". But pricey at $4.50 each.  

I ordered the more popular ramen dish Chicken Paitan soy with the whole chicken leg and thigh.   Very nice presentation.  The broth had good body, flavor is fabulous,  but as we ate our meal the broth became more salty- as goodies were stirred up from the bottom of the bowl.  chicken meat came off the bone easily.  I prefer my noodles a little chewy.  Noodles were cooked to perfection.   An excellent dish - I would order again

My wife ordered the Chicken Paitan meatball ramen.  Also had great flavor,  she too enjoyed her meal.   

Chicken teriyaki bowl was presented very nicely.  Good size portion.  A deal at $6.50 

We had a very nice dinning experience, service was very comfortable, the waitresses were easy to talk to , and the food came out reasonably fast.  

I'm not sure how we did it?? But for three , with tea and one soft drink-   Our bill was $100 including tip.
author: Uncle Ernie ..

description: This place is a great choice for ramen in the city. Got the spicy chicken! Amazing...All ramen are made out of chicken broth but you will not notice the difference between the pork broth which has been my all time favorite since it's full of flavor! Loved the waiting list in yelp! Helped get a table in this long line busy restaurant. Would come again every week!!
author: Maria Fernanda G.

description: This was a big disappointment... I've had Nojo bookmarked on Yelp for awhile now and finally got the chance to try it last week. I heard so many great things about this place from my friends! The wait was pretty long on a Friday night; we waited about an hour. I got their limited chicken paitan soy sauce ramen and thought it was just alright. It was aesthetically pleasing to look at, but it was subpar in terms of taste. The broth had a strong garlic flavor and nothing else. I'm not sure if I came on an off day, but the chicken leg was dry and flavorless... It wasn't terrible, but it was definitely not worth waiting an hour and spending 20 bucks.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Having sampled almost every ramen spot in SF, Nojo is a strong favorite of mine. Come in early (5pm-6pm) on any weekday to miss the line.

The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen is the item to get here - rich, opaque, flavor-packed broth with chewy noodles, lots of green and red onions, and absolutely melt-in-your-mouth roasted chicken. The egg has a nice soft yolk. I love it with the 'spice bomb' add-on, which is basically a big ol' scoop of red pepper flakes and chili oil on the side.

Also notable is the hamachi appetizer - a super refreshing dish with lime, green & red onions, and a light soy/sesame pour-over. The fish is fresh af.
author: Natalie M.

description:
I came here on Friday night with a friend. The wait was insane  - almost two hours. The place seemed clean, the staff was friendly. The tables were very close together and the entire place was really loud (just saying and not basing my review on this because I don't care about noise levels).

Ramen was ok. I got the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce and my friend got the Chicken Paitian. The soy sauce one definitely had better flavor and was generally more filling and tasty, the Chicken Paitian was pretty bland. For the price, you'd expect both bowls to come with more toppings (you can pay for additional toppings...)

Overall, it was fine, but there are a handful of better ramen shops in the city that I prefer.
author: Nelya T.

description: This place is always crowded so plan ahead and join the yelp waitlist, its efficient. I got chicken paitan tan tan spicy miso ramen. Noodles could have been more soft, and it was not as spicy as expected. Since I love spicy food, I would have preferred this to be a bit more spicy. Green tea creme brulee was so good. With their open kitchen and larger seating area, its a fusion of open kitchen ramen restaurants of Tokyo and fancy busy restaurants of hayes valley!
author: Amulya V.

description:
I really want to say that I was impressed, but I'm not sure that my meal was worth the hour wait. If you do decide to check out this place, do yourself a favor and hop on the waitlist through Yelp. You can do this before you arrive which will save you some precious time.

Now to the food - their ramen is all chicken based with the exception of one veggie option. I'd say the style of ramen is more fusion, rather than traditional. I ordered the Tan-tan spicy miso ramen, which was very flavorful but a tad too salty for my taste. I added an onsen poached egg to my order and that was a mistake. No flavor, was a bit undercooked, and the yolk was pretty sad. 

Service was efficient but felt a bit rushed at the end. This is understandable, given the 20+ parties that are waiting for your table. Overall the food is pricey but decent, just be prepared for the wait.
author: Christine C.

description:
One of my favorite ramen spots in San Francisco! I love both the ramen with the whole chicken leg and the one with ground chicken. Typically I don't like chicken broth because I find it much less flavorful than something like a Tonkotsu pork broth. At Nojo, however, the broth is the perfect level of richness and packs so much flavor! 

I also love that they now let you add yourself to the waitlist on Yelp so you don't have to wait while you're there. This makes eating here so much more pleasant!
author: Sara M.

description:
Overdue post

I came here at a wrong time with 5 people.  On the weekend during dinner time so the wait was about an hour.

The place seemed really popular..lot of folks waiting outside.  To get on their waiting list, you need to have Yelp which was really annoying since none of us had it installed on our phones.  

The place itself was quite cute, wish we were seated by the window in the back.  But I could not stand eating in here because of how loud it got inside.  Literally had to yell across the table the entire night.  

We got a little appetizer of the chicken nuggets.  Meh...the sauce was ok but not memorable.

I unfortunately can't eat ramen because the broth is too rich so I got the taco rice to try something new.  It came out on a little cute stone plate but it does not taste good at all.  Very salty and I did not enjoy the tomatoes on it.  Corn seemed frozen and was hard...cheese on top is also not a good combo.  Could not finish it.

My friends who ordered the popular chicken ramen thought it was ok but wasn't authentic enough for them.  Pretty expensive for mediocre ramen.  

The service was on point though...quick, friendly and attentive.  

Don't get the hype about this place.
author: K C.

description:
One Sapporo on draft $7
One Fort Point Westfalla on draft $7 (arrives in a smaller mug)
Gyoza $5 (5 pieces)
Chicken karaage three pieces $8
Tan tan spicy ground chicken miso ramen $17

Shared everything. Loved everything. Sat at bar  ... 45 minutes  total time here ....service was sweet

Once was enough

Walked here from New Conservatory Theater on van ness,  where we saw a matinee performance of It's  Only A Play, which was great too
author: Foodlover B.

description: Their chicken broth ROCKS! We don't eat pork so whenever we go for ramen at other ramen restaurants, we have to order either chicken or veggie broth which are always a thin broth. The chicken broth they have here is so surprisingly thick and amazingly flavorful! This is definitely a hands down place for us to come back all the time. Thank you Nojo Ramen to provide this great experience and choice for us and everyone else!
author: Choco W.

description:
I've been dying to try this place, since I am always looking for the best places to satisfy my ramen cravings, and my recent experience has done just that! My friend and I came on a Friday night, expecting long lines, but we were luckily able to get a seat without waiting. We came in at around 5:00pm when it opened, and there wasn't a line. We put our names down and told the hostesses to save us a spot for around 6pm. We ended up walking back at around 6:20, and a line was definitely forming. However, we were luckily able to grab a seat at the counter, which I personally prefer since you get a chance to watch the cooks make the ramen. 

Once seated, we looked at a pretty simple menu with just a few options, and we had to go for the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen, which apparently is limited each night to a certain number of orders. Our orders came out pretty quickly and we were surprised by the huge bowls it came in, as well as the full roasted chicken leg that came with it. 

I took a first bite, and the meaty, rich yet somewhat light flavors of the broth hit my instantly. The broth wasn't too greasy, despite the rich appeal of the broth, and the green onions added a lot of flavor. I really liked the onion chips, which tasted like a crunchy snack on the ramen. The noodles were also cooked to al dente, and they used a thicker, bubbly type of noodles. The chicken leg was also to die for: super flavorful, fall of the bone with crispy baked chicken skin, and well seasoned. The soft boiled egg, however, was pretty disappointing and the yolk wasn't too runny. The only major concern I had with the ramen was that it could have a been a tad bit less salty; otherwise, the food was great.

Also, the servers were very nice and they constantly attended to our empty water glasses. The interior was also very aesthetic, and I'd highly recommend the trip to Hayes Valley to try their fancy ramens. Parking can be difficult ad prices are more on the steep side at $20 a bowl, but it is most definitely worth the experience!
author: Sandra S.

description:
Nojo Ramen is my ramen place OF CHOICE. Mensho needs to move over, as this is the best ramen joint in San Francisco.

The Chicken Paitan ramen is something. The chicken is tender and falls right off the bone, and the broth is delicious. It's rich and thick without being overwhelming. Whenever someone wants ramen in my circle, I without a doubt will drag them here, as this is the only ramen joint in SF I'm willing to rave about.
author: Jessie Y.

description:
My girlfriend and I came by this place for Sunday lunch around 12pm and was pleasantly surprised to find no line and plenty of seating indoors.

I've noticed that many Japanese ramen places recently are going with heavier broths and this place isn't any different, it specializes in tori paitan. The noodles were pretty chewy and the broth was very flavorful. I opted for the tori paitan with a whole chicken. Even though the chicken leg was good, I definitely still prefer pork chashu. 

The ramen here is $$, but I'd say it was still worth a try. However, at this price point I definitely prefer Menshou because it comes with duck and pork chashu. Probably wouldn't pay that much for what it was, you can get something similar at Marufuku ramen for about 70% of the cost.
author: Edward W.

description: The spicy chicken miso ramen is soooo yummy! It's pricey, but that's basically expected in SF. You can skip the wait by using yelp to put your name on the waitlist or sit at the bar. Such a fulfilling and tasty dinner option in Hayes valley!
author: Vinitha R.

description:
I was excited to find this spot. Pictures made me more excited to try this spot.

We ordered the Takoyaki fries and chicken Naga. The fries were thin, hard and cold with too much sauce which made it unpleasantly just salty. The Naga came with salad that was drenched on one side of the salad and Naga was partly drenched in soy sauce. Too salty. 

Now the ramen. The Paitan Soy Ramen was pretty good. Flavorful and chicken cooked perfectly. It was way too oily by my 5th bite. The Tan Tan spicy chicken was not spicy first of all and it was very bland. It didn't have much chicken nor flavor but lots of thick oil. 

Overall I'm sorry to say I will not be back here to spend another $70 on such quality food and presentation.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Not your typical Japanese ramen eatery. They have their own unique ramen dishes (mostly chicken based instead of pork) you won't find anywhere else and most of them are delicious too. However that is the reason there is always a line here unless you come really early (weekdays get there before 5:45pm, and on weekends a line starts to form as early as 5pm even on a Sunday).

Nikumaki rice ball: added cheese and spices. Basically rice wrapped up by pork belly. Unique dish but tasted average, would not order again.

Nojo takoyaki fries: if you've had takoyaki before this is basically that flavor and all the sauces that come with it on top of fries. Would order again.

Chicken nanban: so juicy, never had a chicken appetizer taste this good. Best juiciest chicken ever.

Chicken paitan tomato ramen: delicious and bursting with  flavour. Will need to drink lots of water.

None of the ramen come with a soft-boiled egg so make sure to add that to maximize your ramen eating experience.
author: Tom P.

description:
5 stars for service.
4 stars for food and environment.

I ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen and Chicken Paitan tomato Ramen.

Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce  Ramen
It was come with a huge chicken leg !!! Absolutely looked beautiful!! !The soup was super thick and creamy, and tasted salty, I have to drink much water after this meal. However, the chicken leg was nice and moist, I liked it more than the ramen.

Chicken Paitan tomato Ramen
It sounds very interesting, because it was a  combo of black garlic, cilantro, tomato, & Grana Padano, and I never tried this before. But I didn't like it, because they put so much cilantro on the top of ramen!!!!  The tomato soup was thick and tasty, but still tasted salty.
author: Anny L.

description:
For my 1,100th review, it didn't take me long to decide to write about Nojo Ramen Tavern.  Besides just being my new favorite ramen spot in SF, when I fall in love with a place this quickly, it's like the review just writes itself!  In this case though, I have to admit it took me A LOT longer than it should have.  Not that I regret it though...it just meant having more excuses/time to come back to try more on their menu!

In nearly every way, Nojo Ramen Tavern (not to be confused with their previous iteration, Nojo) is pretty damn awesome (okay, except for the general lack of parking in Hayes Valley).  Stepping inside, the restaurant has a dim yet lively vibe, counter seating to watch the kitchen work (creeping on your food!), and a legit menu filled with a wealth of tasty options.  Especially their ramen - a half dozen or so varieties that all sound terrific!

-- CHICKEN PAITAN TAN TAN SPICY MISO - Spicy Ground Chicken, Toasted Sesame, Cilantro, Scallions, Fried Gobo, and Spice Bomb...$17
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nojo-ramen-tavern-san-francisco-2?select=EGFh6Ra5JpxdWh1I_0JNgw)
If a bowl of ramen could give you a hug with how delicious it is, this would be of the bear-sized variety.
