Just about everything was perfect (if only I had asked them to leave out the cilantro...) - the noodles were cooked well, the ground chicken was awesome, and I liked the fried gobo.   .  The broth was the best part though - flavorful, deep, and not super heavy.

-- SPICY CHICKEN SOBORO TOSSED NOODLES - Flat Noodles Topped With Seasoned Ground Chicken, Nira Chives, Cilantro, Fried Onion, Red Onion, Shredded Nori, Bonito Flakes, Toasted Sesame, and Raw Egg Yolk...$16
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nojo-ramen-tavern-san-francisco-2?select=d9KI3irXiaG-jKl6U4CHxA)
If this really has fallen off the menu, it's a real shame.  Other than being a little heavy on the chives, this was TERRIFIC!  The noodles had the perfect bite, the ground chicken was very well seasoned, and the mix of ingredients made for a tasty combination.  What's more, the egg (which you can get soft poached instead of raw) added a nice umami-ness to the dish.

Given how increasingly popular Nojo Ramen Tavern has become, expect a line regardless of when you plan on coming here.  However, it's actually not too bad if you arrive early; both times I've been here, we arrived around 6:00-6:30 on weeknights and only had to wait about 10-15 minutes, if that.   Beyond the wait, the only real knock on Nojo is their prices.  At the same time, considering how it's comparable with the likes of Marufuku (my other favorite spot) and Mensho, it's actually not that pricey.  Plus, the food is more than worth the money!  Yumm...
author: Mike L.

description:
Nice ramen spot nearby! Love for sure!
High quality dishware combine with enviroment, and seems like they change the menu a little bit. This is my frist time and my friend's second time. We both really love the experience.
author: Faye L.

description:
Unfortunately I have to give this place 4 stars...
I had the chicken paitan spicy miso and it is definitely one of the better ramens that I have had in the US. Only problem is that it's a little expensive.... worth going to one time but not sure if I would get it again just because of the price...
author: Philip H.

description:
My partner and I found this place for lunch right after marching for a few hours at Pride. We were enticed by the Yelp online check-in (which was very convenient as we used the waiting time to walk there) and Japanese food reasonable close to where we were. We also enjoyed the atmosphere and the setting of the venue.

We both got the Spicy Chicken Soboro Tossed Noodle with raw eggs. The overall dish was very flavorful, especially for those who enjoy spicy food. One would have to mix the noodle with the veggies, chicken, and raw egg on the top. The noodle itself was very firm and chewy, but everything else was not particularly outstanding or noteworthy. It's a nice, spicy dish for those who are hungry or craving spicy food. 

Overall, the ramen was decent, and there are definitely many other interesting-looking dishes being offered on the menu. In my opinion, the portion size was a little small compared to the price level. Hopefully, the taste can make up for that.
author: Jim X.

description:
I was hanging out in SOMA and had a strong craving for ramen. My friend isn't a huge fan of soup so I was trying to find a ramen place that might have a few other items that she could eat. This place was open fairly late too compared to alot of restaurants in the area. They have a good seating system, where you walk in and immediately write your name down. As things run out they are sure to let people know or write it down on the list.

I ordered the spicy ramen. I was tempted to get the famous chicken leg one...but I was worried it might be too salty. My ramen was salty already but very very delicious and honestly if you have a decent spice tolerant, it's not too spicy at all. Just the right amount. 

Teriyaki Chicken bowl was small but priced well and tasty. Enough for my friend with the fries we shared. 

Spicy ramen: 4 stars, expensive but delicious and good salty balance 
Teriyaki Chicken: 4.5 stars, small portion but good price 
Overall value: 4 stars, most ramen run close to $18. Good but expensive.
author: Alyssa A.

description: This place always has a long line waiting. For a table of four on a Sunday lunch, the wait was about 30-40 minutes. It was my first time there so my wise sister ordered the dishes I had to try. We got the fried chicken appetizer which was good and has seasonings and salad that are different than you expect. I also got the chicken ramen with the drumstick. It says it has limited amounts served but we were able to all get the bowl. The bowl is very heavy for me. One because I had ayce the night before so not really hungry and having a heavy meal for lunch has never been my preference. If you come here, I recommend you go for a dinner and if you're not hungry, then split Cuz it's a lot in that bowl. Overall, a good solid place.
author: Amy H.

description:
I was very impressed with the ramen broth here. Loads of flavor! I reccomend adding a braised chicken leg to any bowl, the chicken is cooked amazingly well. 
Me and my fiance came here a couple nights ago, he ordered ramen and I got the salad and chicken wings. I loved the chicken wings. I tried my fiances ramen and it was very flavorful. I was a little confused why my salad didn't with a fork, it was a little difficult to get the edamame and nuts with the leaves all in one bite. Also there was a lot of water at the bottom of my bowl. 
Would reccomend and will be coming back
author: Nicole W.

description:
Yyyyyyaaaaasssssss! 

Amazing!

Just be sure to go early as they ran out of ramen the day we went at 1pm!
author: Chris B.

description: I ordered the veggie miso ramen. Garlicky but really good. Enjoyed the smoky okra. Also ordered Yuzu miso cucumber for appetizer. Pretty nice place for a legit veggie ramen.
author: Prateek R.

description:
Pricey but really good and unique ramen. We both got the spicy miso and it was delicious with the perfect amount of spice. The gyoza were great as well. 

We came on a rainy Friday around 5:30 and didn't have to wait long but it was very packed by the time we left. Definitely not a place you can hang out for a while though, they have a lot of people waiting and want you in and out.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
Wow, this place blew me away! Last night, I came here with my boyfriend and we probably got there around close to 9pm and there was still people waiting in line. It was actually one of the best ramen I've had in awhile to be honest. Parking was relatively easy to find during this time which was nice lol. We got seated after 30 minutes or so on a Wednesday night which wasn't too bad.

We both ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen and one order of the chicken teriyaki bun! I originally ordered the regular chicken paitan but after looking at the picture, I was like eff it, I'm about to order the soy sauce one instead. It was definitely a good choice. The pork broth and the soy sauce combo was delicious. The soup was super filling but a little bit saltier so I had to keep drinking water. There was a chicken leg in the ramen was SO DAMN GOOD. The meat just fell right off the bone and gave lots of flavor from the soup. 
The chicken teriyaki bun was also very good. It had lots of flavor and I'll just say, I can probably eat like 5 of them if I wasn't eat the ramen. It was that good.

The prices were a bit higher than other ramen places but I would pay for the price. The quality and service was what makes everything worth it.

The server was super nice and accommodating and overall we had a good time! Definitely will be back for some more next time! :) Mhmm.....ramen!!!
author: Monica W.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE! I don't eat red meat, so finding a ramen place that specializes in chicken was amazing.

I came here pretty late on a Saturday night (close to closing time) along with some other parties, and rather than turn us all away, they sat us all! I really appreciated that.

Throughout the dinner, they were very attentive, refilling our waters and making were we had everything we needed periodically. The service was great.

For dinner, I got the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso. It was by far the best ramen I've ever had - incredibly flavorful with just the right amount of spice. The noodle to soup ratio was on point, and it tasted great.

I would highly recommend this place; I intend to come back often :)
author: Remy B.

description:
This was so not what I expected. I expected to walk in to some ramen with pork broths and be full of pork belly. What I got instead was something altogether fantastic. 

I got the Chicken Paitan Tomato ramen. I was skeptical at first, but as soon as I took a bite I knew it was something fantastic. I expected the broth to be bland since the menu only has chicken. What I got instead was a bold flavored broth that wants to remind you that there's a way to have pasta with tomato sauce that isn't your regular spaghetti. The noodles were the perfect texture and the broth was bold without being heavy. I added part of the spice bomb to the broth to add an extra spice to it. I personally think there was a bit too much cilantro, but that was such an easy fix that they still get five stars. 

Spicy Chicken Soboro Tossed Noodle was suggested from our waiter. I usually ask what their favorite dish is. I didn't get it myself because I wanted broth, but my date did and we were not disappointed. She warned me it was spicy, and she didn't mean American spicy. If you can't do hot sauce without sweating, stay away from this dish. After a few bites I was sweating. But the kicker is that it's seasoned so well! It wasn't spicy for the sake of being spicy, it was flavorful, and happened to be spicy. It was perfect. I actually couldn't decide which I liked more so we kept switching back and forth when the Soboro noodles got too spicy. 

I will definitely be back for more!!! Thanks Nojo!!!
author: Amber T.

description:
I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Ramen Places in the Bay Bay Bay.

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

Rod Ramen Rating = (Taste of Broth / Taste of Noodles/Taste of other stuff in soup) on a Scale of 1 to 10 (10/10/10) being the best score possible

* Please note that I don't have a preference for thick or thin noodles or thick or clear broth I just call it like I feel it.
When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 

# 1 Marufuku Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 9/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *5 stars 
# 2 Mensho Tokyo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 3 Orenchi Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 4 Orenchi Beyond  *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 5 Ramen Parlor *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 6 Ramen Dojo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 7 Iza Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 8 Nojo Ramen Tavern *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/6/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 9 Yokohama Lekei Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/5/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 10 Ippudo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 11 Santa Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 12 Ramen Yamadaya *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 13 Sobo Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 14 Ramen 101 *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 15 Ramen Shu *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/5/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 16 Suzu Noodle House *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 17 Hinodeya Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 18 Slurp Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 19 Tadamasa *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/3 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars
author: Rod M.

description: This is the best ramen in the city of SF. I've tried so many and they're good, but the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce in a winning choice. The thick broth was very filling! It is pretty pricey but so worth it! I come here whenever I'm in the mood for ramen!
author: Kat L.

description: Came here for the first time last night for a belated birthday dinner. My friend called to make reservations - but I believe they don't take any; you have to just come in, put your name on the waitlist and wait. We waited for a short while (we got there a few minutes before 6:30, waited for about 15-20 mins) and then asked to be seated at the bar - it was just two of us. After sitting down, we were given menus immediately. The menus featured one specialty ramen dish - a vegan one - but it was crossed out. I didn't see any pork or beef ramen dishes - only one vegetarian one and 4-5 chicken options. The add-on prices vary - but they're fairly cheap. I chose the ground chicken ramen and added a soft boiled egg. We ordered sake. My friend got the veggie ramen. We ordered edamame to share (so good!). The ramen was good - spicy, lots of flavor, good noodle to broth ratio. We also received a dessert for my birthday - matcha ice cream in a wafer sandwich. Overall, I'd definitely recommend and come back! FYI - hard to find parking in this area, and according to google crowd, 7:30 is when it starts to get really crowded - even at 6:30 on a Tuesday for 2, it was pretty busy!
author: Zinia G.

description:
Today I was able to taste this location! 
I am very happy with their menu and prices. 
I came with my sister and her daughter.
We were greeted by such nice staffs and the restaurant was so nice and I enjoy every moment of it!
author: Sao N.

description:
Exemplary veggie/vegan ramen . As a vegetarian I usually don't have many ramen options, But NOjo changed that for me . 
Their veggie ramen is like a warm hug on a cold winters day . The noodles , the broth and veggies are best friends together . 
The broth is rich and buttery which is exactly what you want from a good bowl of ramen .
author: Priyanka P.

description: The vegan ramen is to die for. Get it. I have gotten this twice now and was nervous it may not be vegan because it's so delicious. It is definitely vegan and I have no clue what they out in it but it so so creamy and delicious.
author: Katie B.

description:
We lucked out after the Davies Symphony Hall concert. It's only a block away and we snagged one of the bar sections. 

Loved the appetizers: gyoza and teriyaki chicken bun. 

We ordered the ramen and it was a beautiful presentation. It was a very very very rich and creamy broth. It's a little too much for me which is why I knocked a star off. I like more brothy but hey if you're all about the flavor blasted flavor then this is the place for you!
author: Noren R.

description:
The ramen here is awesome! Especially the spicy tan tan miso ramen, it's just soooooo delicious. The soup base is very thick and tasty, noodles are cooked just right and the whole bowl makes you feel happy. 

You won't go wrong with selecting this place for your ramen fix. Make sure to add that spice bomb if you like enjoy spicy food :)
author: William Qi D.

description: Delicious and I love that we can put our name on the waiting list via yelp. Got drinks at Brass Tacks, then went to the restaurant when they said the table was ready. Was awesome!
author: Christina D.

description:
Dropped in Nojo Ramen Tavern tonight for a quick bite before a movie. I was by myself, and when I arrived around 6 pm, the place was already packed. It has a nice vibe - modern, lots of wood. I sat at a high communal table - that seems to  be first come, first serve.  Nojo prides themselves on a different type of Ramen - Chicken Paitan, made with chicken broth (not the very popular Tonkatsu). The other thing about Paitan apparently is that it is creamy - often including soy milk. This gives it a rather sweet taste compared to Ramen. 

I've heard Paitan has become very popular in Japan and my Ramen was certainly good. Their noodles, which they refer to as artisanal, are beautifully chewy and flavorful - exactly what you want. My Paitan had little chicken meatballs.  They were tender and tasty, but frankly a bit under-cooked. The center was still slightly pink. So far, no "distress", but the kitchen should cook the meatballs at least another minute.  The Chicken Paitan had daikon sprouts (yum), bamboo shoots (real ones), and yuzu, which gives it a lovely citrus under-note. I also ordered a soft-boiled egg, presumably poached in dashi. It was a very nice softness - not runny, and made a good addition to my Ramen. However, I give Nojo three stars due to the undercooked chicken meatballs. Otherwise, I'd give it a 4. Also I found it a little too noisy. Not a deal breaker, but...

I also ordered a Cucumber salad w/ Miso. Delicious. Even though they were busy and full (with a line of people waiting), I was out of there in about 45 minutes, leaving me ample time to get to my movie.  The restaurant is on Franklin, near City Hall, so it's very convenient.  Service was polite and efficient - no complaints. I'll be back.
author: Carol M.

description: Great place for chicken options for sure. Had to add a bit more hot chili oil to spicy miso, but overall great.
author: Dorysa M.

description:
The menu had so many delicious options, I had a hard time picking what I wanted! Despite the restaurant being very busy, staff were very polite and efficient. Food came out quickly for a table of 8 and everyone's food was delicious. I had the spicy chicken tossed noodles -- highly recommend!

Best ramen & noodle place in the neighborhood!
author: Ryan C.

description:
Lives up to the hype. The chicken meatballs in the Chicken Paitan are the best meatballs you will ever have. Slightly crisp on the outside, but as soon as you pierce that delicious outer layer they are pillow soft inside, and have a great umami taste. The broth looks weak at first since it's so pale, but it's very flavorful. I tried to get a side of the chicken leg, but they were out. I was content with the serving size so it worked out. My friend got the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso and it was as advertised, very spicy and one of the tastiest tan-tan broths I've tasted.

Start things off right with a plate of the takoyaki fries, they are lighter than you think and worth it.
author: Gonzalo S.

description:
The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce is solid.  Thick, delicious broth and good noodles.  The chicken leg was tender but wasn't as flavorful as I'd like.  

The green tea creme brulee and ice-cream sandwich weren't anything special.

Would not wait 1.5 hour (honestly, why would you want 1.5 for anything?!) but we waited 30 minutes, and it was worth it. 

Still prefer Mensho, though.
author: Christine A.

description:
Prepare to wait at this place during meal hours. The staff is a bit slow and disorganized im not sure who our waitress was because it seemed like she never came back. The only upside to the wait is that there is some space to wait and heaters above the waiting area outside.

In terms of food i think they topped the ramen with way too much cilantro. I love cilantro and even I thought it was too much. I asked for extra spicy in the Chicken Paitan Tan Tan Spicy Miso and they gave me chili oil that didn't really do anything for the dish. I enjoyed the noodles but flavor of the broth was pretty mediocre.

I think this place was just ok, they have some unique dishes and a nice ambience in their restaurant but customer service could use some work.
author: Laura Y.

description:
Best ramen in sf!! Katana ya used to be my place until they took an epic turn for the worst. 

5/5 Spicy ramen was so good I couldn't get enough of that broth! And the tuna tartar and fried chicken were just dreamy!!!
author: Morgan S.

description:
Stopped by this place after a jazz concert. Good that it opens late.

We were lucky to get the last two daily limited chicken soy sauce paitan ramen. And they were very good! Rich flavor and the soup is very thicken. Chicken is soft and tender. One star is off because personally I don't like soup that is too thick. But my boyfriend loves it. I like the fries Gobo that's on the top! (The waitress told me gobo was a Japan veggie). Also I love their tuna tartar appetizer. 

One more thing, they don't provide extra noodles thou, my bf asked for it but they say they don't do it here. But overall a very nice place to eat
author: Sunny L.

description:
YUMMY!! I went to Nojo for dinner after my brother who lives in SF raved about it. He specifically said get the chicken leg so I did.
I ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce and it was absolutely delicious. The broth is super thick and creamy and the chicken leg slayed the game. It also comes with a soft boiled egg My friend got the Spicy Miso and said it was really good too!!
Service is super friendly and when we went at around 9:15PM we didn't have to wait at all! Bigger parties have to wait a little longer though. Overall such a good experience for me.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Absolutely awesome food! We ordered the chicken nanban, chicken paitan ramen, and chicken paitan tomato ramen. The chicken nanban was honestly some of the best chicken I've ever had (juicy, tender, and perfectly fried). My chicken paitan tomato ramen was incredible with a rich and flavorful broth. I don't even like tomatoes very much, but I finished my entire bowl. My friend got the regular chicken paitan which they enjoyed a lot. I'm already dreaming of coming back!
author: Abbie R.

description:
Great service, unbalanced ramen. The chicken leg ramen looked beautiful, but was way too salty and the noodles were way too difficult to slurp since they were all too short.

I've been to many ramen shops in Tokyo, Osaka and Kyoto as well as in SoCal (Kitakata, Ikkousha, Tsujita, etc.) and this was one of the saltiest bowls I've ever had. The chicken was tasty and tender and the crispy bits were great.

Service was quick and attentive, so thumbs up there.
author: Mike P.

description:
I was teetering on 4.5 but they earned the 5 because of the extra effort the hostess made to accommodate our friends 9 month old that joined us for dinner. Efforts like those makes places like this shine. 

We started with apps:
Edamame- perfect and not salty
French fries- OMG! My mouth was in heaven! Delicious!
Wings- tasty

Ramen... loved, loved, loved the texture of the noodles! More on the firmer side. I ordered the spicy ramen. I'd definitely get it again. 

We came on a Friday night. The wait wasn't bad. Our servers were friendly, helpful and quick to anticipate our needs.
author: Mary H.

description:
This is definitely not authentic Japanese ramen style, but still so freaking good. I'm surprised to see some of the reviews mentioning the portion isn't huge. I struggled walking after having whole bowl of Chicken Soy Sauce (shoyu) Paitan Ramen. It is HUGE especially with whole chicken leg being the topping. I wasn't a huge fan of the tomato one but i guess worth trying it. If it's your first time going here, just get chicken soysauce paitan ramen. That's a must dish. 

also, if you want some refreshing appetizer before ramen, get cucumber salad with yuzu and miso sauce. So refreshing that preps my taste buds to fully enjoy their ramen. 

Be prepared to wait for LONG time. I realized weekend lunch line right when they open isn't too bad.
author: Serena Y.

description:
Kinda pricey for what's served. Thing1 is 11 and his pupils dilated when he saw the (small) portion of the teriyaki chicken bowl. He immediately turned to me and said "I'll need a snack afterwards. This is not going to fill me up."

I ordered Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen ($18.50), considerably expensive but I let yelpers help me decide on this one. With that price, they weren't very generous with their ramen and other ingredients. The broth is different from ordinary ramen joints such that it was thick and rich in flavor, a bit too salty for my liking. Then comes the chicken drumstick - extremely flavorful, juicy and tender. Didn't need to use my hands to eat it since it took no effort removing the bone.

We lucky there was no wait when we checked in (after a recital at SFCM) on a Sunday.
author: Em T.

description: Had the veggie miso ramen and it was creamy, flavorful, and filling. Even better when you use the waitlist feature to skip the line!
author: Sophia C.

description: I love the taste but need to order spicy and you need to give extra money to get it .. kind of pricey but good to try ... thank you ..
author: Zaw Win T.

description: Nojo has a unique take on ramen with a chicken leg in their signature ramen. There was a short wait when we patronized the restaurant, but they had a Yelp waitlist integrated which is a nice touch to be able to virtually sign up and manage it electronically.
author: Thomas C.

description:
TL;DR delicious chicken-based ramen but pricey and requires long waits (oh San Francisco....)

Came here last Friday for dinner with 4 other friends. We put our name down around 5:15 but didn't get seated until almost 6:30. 

We would have gotten seated a little bit sooner, but Nojo has a policy that all members of a group have to be present before they can be seated. Another group of 5 that came way after us had told them first that all members of their party were present, so they got seated before us. This seemed kind of weird to me, but the restaurant comped us for dessert at the end so at least they tried to make up for it.

I would recommend to the restaurant to add a note to let them know when all members are present, if that's the system they are going by. I'm not used to doing this at other restaurants and thus failed to notify them when our last person arrived.

The rest of the meal passed without a glitch. We had already perused the menu while we were waiting so ordering was a quick affair. My friend and I split a Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce, which comes at a whopping $18.50 per bowl. Yes it does come with a whole braised chicken leg, but I'm not sure if that warrants the high price tag.

Food came out within 10 minutes of ordering. I snapped some pictures (it was so photogenic) before eagerly digging into the ramen. I love chicken-broths and my favorite ramen in the city is the Tori Paitan from Mensho, so I was very excited to try the Chicken Paitan here. The broth had a rich chicken flavor but was a little bit too salty for my tastes. The braised chicken leg was tasty but slightly dry. I loved the soft boiled egg, though! And the use of chives was an interesting touch; this is the first time I've seen it used as a ramen topping. 

At the end of the meal, our server apologized for the confusion at the beginning and said we could each order a dessert on the house. I wasn't expecting it and was very pleasantly surprised and grateful to the restaurant for recognizing our annoyance and doing their best to handle the situation. 

I ordered the matchadoodle ice cream sandwich, which came a the Chinese lion (or dragon?) face on the cracker. Definitely very unique! It wasn't too big and was the perfect way to end the meal on a sweet note.

The restaurant is in Hayes Valley so it's all street parking in this area.
author: Dianna H.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for dinner after choosing this place randomly off a Yelp search and there was a waitlist so we knew this place must be good.
We started off with the porkbelly onigiri which was delicious but we were a bit disappointed that there was only one
 I was aldo surprised  that there was only chicken or veggie ramen but I decided to try the Black Garlic Braised Leg Ramen. The bowl was huge and the broth was rich and very tasty! The chicken leg seemed to melt in my mouth and and the noodle were not too firm.
For desert we had the matcha creme brulee and black sesame ice cream and it is something you MUST TRY when you eat here!
author: Katelynn S.

description:
I've been here a couple times for lunch and I always get the chicken paitan soy sauce ($18.5). Personally, it's my favorite compared to other types of ramen I've tried at Nojo. It's a bowl of creamy, rich chicken broth with ample soy sauce with one piece of juicy chicken leg, chives, diced onions and a soft boiled egg. The noodles in this dish are definitely thicker than what you would expect in a normal ramen. The ramen is one of the best chicken ramen bowls I've had except that the broth is too salty especially with the soy sauce. 

The restaurant is very clean and casual that feels very open with top to bottom windows surrounding the space. There's usually enough seating and I've never waited too long for a spot. The servers here are very nice and attentive as well.
author: Kyle R.

description:
Checked this place out last night with a friend. So good!

We arrived around 7:30pm and there was a crowd of considerable size waiting outside. I was worried it would take forever to get seated, but I put our name on the list and we were in within 30 minutes. 

I was looking for something warm and comforting to eat on a cold, rainy evening, and this really hit the spot. I got the Chicken Paitan Tam-Tam Spicy Miso Ramen with a dashi egg added, and it was delicious. The broth was creamy and tasty, and the noodles were cooked perfectly (still a bit chewy but not undercooked).

The menu is chicken rather than pork focused, which is unique, but it works really well. They also have some unique choices to try (if you decide to venture off the beaten path of the signature dish), like ramen with chicken, tomato broth and cheese! There is also a veggie option, which I appreciated as someone who often prefers meatless options. 

It's not cheap for ramen, but, a filling meal (including a glass of wine) for ~$30 in SF is not something I'm complaining about! I'll definitely be back.
author: Christine G.

description:
Really delicious chicken ramen. I suggest going with a few friends so you can order some of the apps to share as well. They are just as good!

A couple words of caution. There's almost always a wait though given the prime location in Hayes so be prepared to stare longingly through the glass windows at others slurping down noodles. 

The service is also just okay.. nothing to write home about but not bad. They are trying to turn tables given how long the line gets, which makes it reasonable, but still sort of meh to experience every time.
author: Ting N.

description: The "Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso" and "Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce" are the two best bowls of ramen I've had in my life. Highly recommended.
author: Veronica O.

description:
Headed to a show on a Tuesday night, we were able to walk right in and get seated at the counter. I didn't know what I was in for, but the experience was great! I ordered the Taco Tan-Tan rice bowl which was served hot and stayed hot! Absolutely delicious! My husband ordered the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso and he thoroughly enjoyed it! After we ate, we enjoyed cute little green tea ice cream sandwiches.

The restaurant is small, sort of loud. It was fun to watch the cooks while seated at the counter. Waitstaff was very accommodating. Would like to go back and try something different. Thank you!
author: Shayna O.

description:
Location::
Located in the Hayes Valley of San Francisco, you can easily locate it since they have a sign that says "Nojo". If no we it's located on the corner of linden and franklin. Expect to find street parking here in San Francisco. 

Interior::
Beautiful interior with tons of seats. Compared to mensho, this place lets you sit on a table where you don't have to share it (community table). The chopsticks have a cool unique look to it too. The whole interior of the place though is beautiful. 

Service:: 
Our waitress was really nice and patient with us. She was happy to answer any questions we had such as what exactly is a chicken fritter. 

Food::
-Chicken fritters: the chickens were moist and the sauce that was put on it tasted delicious. I want to say it tasted like tar tar sauce or aioli sauce. Overall very tasty and delicious.  
-Chicken pai tan soy sauce: they seriously give you a whole chicken leg! Delicious with the broth tasting to perfection. 
-Spicy miso: so this is supposed to be spicy, but to me it wasn't at all spicy. If I had to give it a spice level I would give it a 1/5 but hey maybe I'm used to heat. The broth tasted really good along with the soft boiled egg that I added on. The pieces of chicken was hard to eat, but they give you a spoon that separates the broth from the meat. This makes eating easier.
author: Nadine Y.

description:
I was meeting someone here for dinner and had not done my usual Yelp research, so I did not know when I walked in that Nojo is exclusively chicken ramen. I arrived around 7:45 and there was a 30 minute wait and people lined up around the corner, and that line only grew over the next hour or so. A lot of them also kind of hover where you're seated so made for a somewhat awkward experience. The menu is limited, and as a diehard tonkatsu lover I was slightly disappointed and intrigued at the same time. I wasn't sure how I felt about having a whole chicken leg floating in my soup, but after a long wait I probably would have eaten anything. I ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen (at $18 a bowl my eyes bulged a little bit, even in LA you don't see those prices) and we waited. and then waited even some more. 

I will say the noodles were some of the best I've ever had. They were thick and chewy and perfect, and the broth was good but verrryyy thick. A little too gelatinous for me and I would have liked a little more of it. The chicken was tender and fell off of the bone, but there was a little too much work involved trying to get the skin and meat off the bone inside of a bowl of soup. 

It's kind of cramped and loud, and you'll be so happy just to sit down when your name is called that you'll take the barstools if offered, so I wouldn't recommend it for a date unless it's your 30th+. Overall it hit the spot at the time and I'm glad I tried it. I'd go back, but only after I hunt down all the other ramen in the city first.
author: Lauren M.

description:
My goodness! This place is so full all day everyday! 

I came on a rainy day with my boyfriend and a friend. That day was raining especially hard and we waited for a seat for about 1.5 hours. I am not sure if people were waiting to eat something warm Bc it was such a rainy day or if this ramen place is really good. Regardless of what, we still decided to give it a try even though we wait for such a long time.

When we got seated, immediately the waitress gave us a paper menu. Some of the items we got were the most popular chicken leg ramen (forgot what the actual name is) and the fries as appetizer. The service was quick and efficient. And when we got our bowl of ramen, it smelled pretty good. I like the consistency of the broth and it was very rich and the noodles are very good. The only topping was really the chicken leg and the meat was tender and soft. The food is good. 

My overall experience was pretty good. I have nothing bad to say about this place. I know the restaurant is small so the capacity is very limited. But I wouldn't necessary come back for this ramen Bc this $18+ ramen with 1 or 2 topping is not really worth it. I would recommend this place to people but 1 experience @ this place is enough for me.
author: Joanne C.

description:
Stopped by on a Fri evening. Even though there were only a few people standing outside waiting, don't be deceived. The lobby of the restaurant was completely packed and we put our names down (probably 20 groups before us)! Good thing is you can get a beer to help pass the time by during your wait. At some point well before they close, they took away the clipboard and blocked anyone else from getting on the wait list. It's not your traditional ramen experience in that they specialize in chicken (no pork based products on the menu) and located in the trendy Hayes neighborhood.

We were finally seated. I came specifically for the chicken paitan soy sauce and was told it was sold out (waaaaaaa). How can you be sold out of your most popular dish?? So I decided to go with the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso instead with an order of Nojo "Takoyaki" Fries. The fries arrived first and were delicious!! The ramen was good but very heavy (both broth and the type of noodles used). Flavors were good/interesting but not as rich as pork based broths. Be prepared to spend $17-18 for your ramen here plus extra for soft-boiled egg and other toppings. 

Service was very friendly but disorganized. I saw lots of tables opening up that were neglected for a while. If they tightened up operationally, I think they could serve a lot more customers. Definitely considering coming back for the chicken paitan soy sauce but not worth an 1h+ wait.
author: Yin H.

description: Best ramen I've ever had. Vegetarian friendly. I went w the veggie ramen. Kind of pricey likely twenty bucks a bowl but so worth it. There's a wait in the evenings so plan accordingly. Afterwards check out Linden room around the block for post dinner cocktails.
author: Marisa F.

description:
We managed to arrive and get seated before the dinner rush showed up. Service was terrific.

The menu is a bit small so we felt that our choices were limited. We both ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen. Of the five ramen dishes offered, this appeared to be the most robust. In hindsight, we probably should have done as we usually do and ordered different flavors.

The ramen had a nice bite to it. The chicken was falling off the bone tender and it was easy to strip the meat from the bones just using chopsticks. The broth was thick and could be a very good warm-up meal during winter. While flavorful, we felt the broth was a bit saltier than we preferred. Neither of us finished the broth. 

We also shared a Ground Chicken on Baguette that was different than we had ever had before. It was well seasoned and quite tasty. 

While we didn't appear to enjoy our meal as much as many other reviewers, we would try this restaurant again if we were in the area.
author: Dexter D.

description: If you are a vegetarian and have a craving for ramen or finding it difficult to get goo chicken based ramen - this is my go to place. I am sure the other ramens would not disappoint, considering this place always has a min 30min waiting. We waited for 45 mins but it was all worth it. We also ordered a side of spice bomb, that lets you adjust the spice level of you ramen as per taste.
author: Shraddha N.

description: Love this place! My all time favorite ramen spot! I've moved away from the city and will gladly drive 40 mins to eat here. I always get the spicy miso and I've never been disappointed! This is the 1st place I mention when my friends ask for food recommendations in the city. They're usually pretty busy but I've never had to wait more than 15 minutes for a table.
author: Tara M.

description: Who serves cold sliced soft boiled eggs on the side? Am I totally uncultured or is this not usually a thing? Also, who then charges $2 for said egg? On top of the already steep $14+ for the ramen? Don't get me wrong, the ramen here is really good. But between the wait, super steep prices, and weird experience, the best I could give this place is a 3 star rating.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Nojo Ramen is excellent. Tried out lunch on a visit to San Francisco. Had a seat on one of the barstools and watched the chefs in action. 

I enjoyed the chicken meatballs in the ramen with a soft boiled egg and the appetizers were delicious too. Highly recommend the takoyaki fries and the rice ball with pork belly! 

Dessert was great too! Definitely try the green tea ice cream sandwich. 

The wait for lunch on Sunday was not long at all and parking was very easy to find. 

If you're in San Francisco, try Nojo Ramen :)
author: Bret H.

description:
There was no wait for lunch on a weekend. The restaurant is pretty spacious and service was super quick and attentive. Everything on their menu sounds delicious. 

We got the Nojo "Takoyaki" Fries ($8) as an appetizer. It was a well presented and tasty dish. The standout part to me however was the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ($18.50) ramen. It's a little pricey but so worth it. The broth was AMAZING! Extremely rich and flavorful especially with the blackened garlic oil. The egg was perfectly cooked and the chicken leg was tender with the meat falling off the bone. It was one of the best ramens I have ever had. My fiance got the second most popular ramen which was spicy miso ($17). The broth was rather spicy and I wasn't a huge fan of this in comparison to the soy sauce ramen.

Overall, definitely worth checking this place out! I can't wait to come back and try their other items.
author: Linda X.

description:
It's been a sad three years living here in SF trying to satisfy my ramen cravings, almost sad enough to make myself consider dragging myself back to the concrete traffic filled jungle of LA. Then comes Nojo...I'll ignore the $15 price tag for a bowl of ramen, welcome to SF.

Who knew I would take to chicken ramen!? Their broth is rich but not too rich. I've tried all of their different broths and each one is unique and delicious. My favorite is probably the tomato, but the rest are great too. I like the texture and thickness of their noodles.

Aside from the price tag, the only downside is that the wait is always superrrr long, at 6:30pm on a weeknight the wait is 30 minutes, but creeps up to an hour later in the evening and on weekends. Also, definitely don't come here with more than 4 people, it's a pretty small restaurant.
author: Chanel H.

description: Came here for dinner on a Wednesday night at about 5:30pm and we got the last table, or else we would had to wait at least 30 mins for a table to open up.When we left there were lots of people waiting for a table so i suggest go early. Go for the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen! It has a huge chicken leg in the ramen. It has a very flavorful and thick broth and the best part is there is so much meat from the chicken. The noodles are really good as well. Although it was $18.50 for the ramen, I think it is sort of expensive but you do get alot of meat. Overall I want to come back to this place and get the same ramen!
author: Shauna f.

description:
Came here on a friday and had to wait about 40 minutes for a group of 6. Ambiance is decent, people are friendly, and we ended up sharing one if the hi-top tables with 2 other people.

We Order this -

1. Iced Jasmine Tea - super refreshing and unsweetened! It was perfect because it kept me from overheating!

2. Chicken Soy Sauce Ramen - this was the tables favorite, but the broth was a bit too thick and had a little slimy residue after you eat it. Kinda like okra..didnt win the night for me, but everyone else seemed to really enjoy it!

3. Tan Tan Miso Ramen - omggg so good!!! this one was actually my favorite! I loved the kick to it and added a soft boiled egg. I'm literally salivating just thinking about it. 

4. Furikake Fries - if you like furikake and japanese mayo, this is totally up your alley!! One order would've been enough for all 6 of us to have a try..definitely a must try!

5. The chicken wings - they're small and only come 4 to a plate...we ordered 3 of them, but these were soon forgotten when the ramen arrived 

Overall, delicious experience and attentive service. if you stick around for dessert, try the matcha ice cream sandwich...its pretty darn good!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I don't quite know how to put this into words... but get the chicken paitan soy sauce. 

Some lovers of tonkatsu ramen (myself included) may be skeptical at first, with succulent pork broth nowhere in sight. Trust me. It may even be tough to go back.

The broth is like a bowl of delicious, creamy, perfectly balanced... Thanksgiving gravy? And I mean that in the most reverent way possible. That's the best analogy I can think of to describe how silky, deep, and full of flavor this broth was when it hit my palette. 

Noodles were top-notch, too. Great texture, bounce, mouthfeel, and flavor. 

I found chicken quarter on top a great addition, and I enjoyed the full experience so much I went for a second bowl. My friend initially balked, calling me crazy. He then dove right in when I had my fill of round 2, and subsequently thanked me, because deep down we both knew one bowl wasn't enough. 

Of the ~10 Bay Area ramen spots I've tried, this place is definitely my favorite.
author: Ryan K.

description:
Got the paitan tan tan ramen with a side of chicken. Getting the side of chicken was a little overpriced, in my opinion. But the ramen was pretty good! Definitely on the thicker side though. The noodles were pretty hard. I guess that's more authentic, though?

My least favorite thing about the place was the wait. We went during dinner time on a Thursday night and we waited about an hour. Good food though!
author: Do P.

description:
This is a great Ramen spot.

My favorite is the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso.  So flavorful and excellent if you add some soft boiled egg and a spice bomb.  If you love spicy ramen then this is a dream dish.
author: Scott M.

description: This is my new found favorite ramen house now. So delicious. I wouldn't mind eating this every day, literally. If not just for the fat in the broth, ill be here every week. So yummy!!!
author: Madelaine J.

description:
This time (or several times but especially this) - believe the hype! 

Delicious (pricey) ramen but imo, it's way better than Mensho - with their perfect fatty, not super thick broth - and you get a lot more for what its worth - especially if you order their popular Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce which comes with a whole chicken leg (10/5 - is this possible for the rating? HA!) We also ordered the Takoyaki fries (3.75/5) - mainly just takoyaki sauce with bonito flakes. My friend also ordered the avocado dish and a salad, which both seemed mediocre. 

Wait is about 45 minutes-1 hr for 5 people if you come after 6PM). They won't seat you without your entire party present, so even if you come early, you won't be able to get a seat immediately. I was there around 5:55PM last Thursday and the hostess literally went through half the waitlist since no one was there! 

Overall, 5/5 for the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce, friendly employees, and location. Recommend having your entire party show before 6PM, or come after 8:30PM.
author: Annie L.

description: AMAZING! People say pricey....I say worth every damn penny! Go here! You won't regret it!
author: Ella J.

description:
Ate here with a group of 4 on a Sunday late afternoon for an early dinner after a pop pilates session. No wait, we sat at the high top table near the door.

I initially wanted a poke bowl ($16) but sadly they ran out. So then I opted for the veggie miso ramen (vegan style, no butter, $16.50).

The ramen was good, the hot soup satisfying, and I liked the corn and okra, but I feel like I can find similar for a lower price elsewhere.
author: Melissa W.

description: I went back for that green tea creme brûlée, and it was delicious! Tastes very strongly of matcha, so only order if you love that flavor (which I do). Also, I forgot to mention what type of ramen I ordered (both times)--the chicken paitan tomato, and it was amazing. I loved it. 10/10 would order a third time.
author: Brenna S.

description:
NOJO Ramen is no joke! Unlike other ramen places, the chicken is truly a star here! 

Their Chicken Pork Bun and Chicken Paitan Soy sauce Ramen are their best dishes here hands down. The chicken pork Bun has a juicy texture and nice teriyaki glaze to it. While the chicken Paitan soy sauce ramen has a thick, yet savory broth. And the chicken was seriously fall off the bone. My main problem is that it was a soy sauce broth. Don't get me wrong, soy sauce broth is good, but wish it had a spice option or more of a kick. Or I wish the fall of the bone chicken was offered with the spicy miso and offered more variety. 

Other than that, nojo is a perfect ramen spot in SF. Great beer, sake, and wine offerings and nice intimate location. Since it seats about 30-40 min every time, the wait can be long, but this place is seriously worth trying.
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
Ramen was good. But not very authentic. 
Felt really westernized. Had a lot of tomatoes in it. And soup base didn't have the flavor I was hoping for. 
We also ordered the karaage. Very crispy and delicious. Maybe a little too much tarter sauce (?) tho. 
All in all. Good place to eat, tho a little pricy
author: Jen W.

description:
Wow Nojo has changed so much since the last time I came by. They still dish out delicious Japanese food but this time around it's definitely more ramen and tiny plates focused. Came in on a Sunday right when they opened at 4pm. Service was very nice and we were seated right away. I was surprised at how fast the place filled up after. By the time we left at 5pm the place was almost completely full.

For my dish I got the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce w/ an Onsen Egg. I also got one of the rice balls w/ cheese.

Rice Ball: It is surprisingly small and considering what the ingredients used are (pork, cheese, rice), it is a bit pricy. But damn it was good. I can't be sure if it's cause I hadn't eaten all day or if it really was that delicious but I wanted at least 2-3 more. There is a point where I wish there was a bit more cheese or pork but for the most part the ratio is perfect and the sweet soy glaze, the lettuce, and cheesy fattiness all go together so well. (4/5)

Chicken Paitan: Damn good but once again a bit pricy. The whole chicken leg is HUGE. I found the texture simultaneously juicy and a bit mealy at the same time but at least it wasn't dry. The broth was milky salty goodness and the little additions like the fried gobo and onion really work well with it.  The noodles were a bit thicker and had a good bite. It was definitely a very filling bowl and towards the end it was getting to a bit much. (4.25/5)

Overall Nojo is bit pricy and overwhelming after a while but it's a hearty delicious bowl of ramen and I can't say no to that.
author: Vivian C.

description: Very beautiful food, creamy broth, and good service. Found it waaaay too salty! Couldn't finish it even halfway..
author: Catherine R.

description:
Came right at opening on a Friday with no wait and 20 min later, the place was packed with a long line already forming.

We ordered the Nojo "Takoyaki" Fries as appetizer, which had bonita flakes and was delicious. I'm not much of a ramen type of person, but their Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce was definitely worth the $18. The noodles were thick and the meat was so soft it was falling off the chicken leg! The broth was creamy, though a bit too salty.

The spicy miso ramen is great for those enjoy a little kick to their food. My only complaint is that it didn't seem to come with a lot of ground chicken - I had to dig around to find small bits of it.

Service was friendly and attentive -- will definitely be back to try their other dishes!
author: Winnie N.

description:
I've been hearing rave reviews about this place from co-workers, and so this was near the top of my must-try list. I heard there were always lines for this place, but I figured since it was a random Thursday, the line for dinner shouldn't be that bad, right? Wrong. It ended up being about a 45-60 minutes wait, so we were like, better be good haha. 

- Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce: wow! The chicken was definitely the most impressive thing. There was a huge hunk of meat on the chicken leg, and it was literally fall-off-the-bone goodness. The soup was extremely rich, perhaps a little too much so and on the salty side (probably the soy sauce), but as a whole, it was a great bowl of noodles. I think I preferred the normal Chicken Paitan soup base more than the soy sauce one because it was a bit lighter (and less salty), but the chicken leg was really great, and I fished for every last morsel remaining in my soup haha. 

I've never paid almost $20 for a bowl of ramen, but boy would I pay $20 for Nojo's. I'll definitely be back! It's no wonder this ramen joint is so popular and the wait is literally out the door.
author: Joanna C.

description:
"Oh neat, we're getting ramen tonight! Wait, why don't they have tonkotsu...?"

Like everyone else who realized it was more than instant noodle, I have become a huge ramen fan and love the plethora in the City (though South Bay also has an excellent selection). When my friend said we were getting ramen while drinking in Toronado, I thought we were going to Iza  (which is also excellent). He corrected me by saying we were going to Nojo. Saw the high reviews from my Yelp friends (oddly save Cherylynn), but I was a bit shocked when I realized this was the chicken ramen place. If you weren't aware most of the ramen places in the city are pork based, and reading a Thrillist article about the best ramen in SF, sure enough the description for Nojo mentions tonkotsu purists may scoff - I did.

When we arrived the waiting area inside was packed, but we decided to wait outside. It wasn't too cold, it had more space, and gave us time to talk to some other patrons who mentioned this was their favorite ramen spot. Okay Nojo, you got me. 3 of us arrived early and soon our 2 other guests joined and the wait fortunately didn't seem too long. As we were more attentive, the waitress called for a table of 6 above us, waited a second for no response and then took us in.

The interior has bar seating, a couple 2 person booths, and a bunch of tables in the middle that can be combined for larger groups. Expect to be sitting close to another group regardless of where you are. Our server quickly came over (all the staff work their asses off here) and we quickly put in an order for appetizers and booze, which included:

-Yuzu Miso Cucumber - I'm glad these were ordered by the group as I've been on a miso kick at Japanese restaurants. Just cucumber in a miso glaze. Yay greens in our diet!
-Nojo "Takoyaki" Fries - I was about to mention ordering these but Charlie beat me to it. When they arrived everyone else was freaking out over the bonito flakes that make it look like it's alive. But so good! These went real fast.
-Chicken Nanban - Basically chicken tenders but a tad bit different than karaage. The two dipping sauces were great.

On to the soups: they all sounded good and we were all having difficulty deciding. I was on the fence between paitan soy and tan-tan because I love me some dan-dan noodles. The server mentioned the paitan soy and tan-tan were the favorites but if we wanted the paitan spicy we could just order some spice bombs for the table, which we did. In the end, all 5 of us got the paitan soy.

The ramen itself was really good - I'm a huge fan of blackened garlic oil in ramen and this added a lot to the flavor. It was smoky, hearty, and creamy with the first few bites definitely had that umami pow that left us all impressed. The whole chicken leg, while intimidating at first, literally falls to pieces so make sure you have a small plate to collect the bones. The chicken itself had solid flavor. I also really enjoyed the fried gobo which gave each spoonful some crunch. The weakest part is the noodles - I thought they could have been more tender, but it didn't ruin the overall experience.

I'm still a tonkotsu fan, and would prefer char siu over chicken most times, but I'm glad I got to try Nojo and do recommend it.
author: Michael C.

description: The service has really improved!! The servers are friendly and funny. And of course the ramen!
author: Lake R.

description: I think this is one of the best ramen in San Francisco. I can feel that each menu was created in time. If you try it here, you will feel different from other ramen. Especially, I like ramen with tomato sauce in chicken soup. The thick noodles and rich chicken broth are excellent. You may have to wait for the table at lunch or dinner time.
author: Da Won L.

description:
4 stars for the service, but only 3 stars for the food. I appreciate that I was seated quickly and the staff was very kind, but I'm growing tired of these hipster ramen places that don't offer pork broth and chashu in their ramen. Also, why is the soft-boiled egg cost extra. Anywhere in Japan, the egg is always included.  

I ordered the Chicken Paitan, which was 90% chicken broth and came with chicken meatballs. I am not a fan. The broth was very creamy, which deviated from traditional ramen which doesn't use any added cream. The chicken meatballs were too soft and squishy. Neither went well with the ramen noodles :(

Maybe I'm too traditional or maybe I'm spoiled after eating ramen in Japan, but I can't get hip to this new age ramen. Please give me my chashu and soft-boiled egg!
author: Vasiliy M.

description: Absolutely amazing. My partner and I got seated immediately and were waited on right away. We ordered two of the "must haves" the chicken bun, and the garlic chili pork belly rice ball. To say they were incredible would be an understatement. So much flavor. We then ordered the Paitan tomato ramen which had shredded chicken and it was delicious. We went in for a small lunch and shared the ramen and they automatically bring a small bowl out with the order specifically for sharing. Such a great restaurant! Perfect portions and not grimy like a lot of ramen places out there. Definitely recommend!
author: Ashley C.

description:
Saw this place on instagram and instantly bookmarked it, having no idea it costs $18 for noodles. However, the ramen was fantastic and it came with a perfectly cooked, succulent chicken leg. It was lightly seasoned and just fell off the bone. 

The noodles were al dente and thick, just the way I liked my noodles. It was a chicken broth based soup, but still fatty enough to get a rich and flavorful broth. Came with half an egg.

I was honestly sad when my meal ended. I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Stella Y.

description:
When it comes to Paitan (creamy chicken broth) ramen in San Francisco, I'm definitely Team Mensho over Team Nojo. We ventured here after having a hugely positive experience trying Tori Paitan ramen for the first time at Mensho and had high expectations for this place given the hype and long lines. 

Starting dinner on a chuckle-worthy note, the chicken wing appetizer came with three puny little wings. Probably as thin and long as your pinky finger. We decided against ordering a second plate because the wings were quite dry too. 

The Soy Sauce Chicken Paitan Ramen was really just too, too salty for me. The broth is dark brown with a clearly visible and thick layer of soy sauce (I was expecting a more subtle and integrated flavor) on top. We both left the meal feeling over-sodiumed. I prefer a more smooth and silky tori paitain, which perhaps the other ramen dishes on the menu MIGHT offer. If that is the case, I would possibly come back. Otherwise, definitely prefer the creamier version at Mensho. 

TL;DR: 3/5. Long line, steep prices, trendy ambience. Moist chicken but way too much soy sauce.
author: Arushi S.

description: Nojo is undoubtedly my favorite restaurant in SF. I've been here multiple times and always left satisfied with the food and service in spite of how busy it gets for dinner. Their signature dish (and my favorite) is the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen. Just the perfect amalgamation of umami, spicy and savory, topped with a tender and flavorful chicken leg. Highly recommended to all.
author: Shourya K.

description: Came here on a Friday night. Entered the wait list via Yelp, but it was still a 1.5hr-2hr wait. Didn't get seated until almost 10:15pm. Nonetheless, though, the food was worth it. We ordered edamame and two bowls of noodles -- the chicken soy sauce and the chicken with tomato. The latter was interesting, a bit of a mediterranean inspired ramen. The broths were SUPER thick and flavorful, and the bowls are pretty big portions (I couldn't finish). Overall, an enjoyable experience minus the very long wait!
author: Joey X.

description:
On a rainy weeknight in the city, the boyfriend suggested that we try Nojo. I asked him what they serve, and he replied ramen. The ramen addict in me perked up and got excited. Then he said, but it's chicken ramen. The ramen addict in me deflated a bit. I was looking forward to some thick, artery-clogging, intensely flavored tonkotsu broth to warm me up. He insisted that we should still give Nojo a shot since people seem to rave about it, so I decided to give it a shot.

If you're like me, you probably think that chicken ramen will be a bit bland with a much lighter broth than traditional ramen. Fortunately, Nojo's chicken paitan ramen pretty much takes everything we love about tonkotsu -- the intensity of flavors, the thickness -- but makes you feel sliiiightly healthier because it's chicken.

The wait time for us wasn't too bad, but then again, we walked in at about 9PM on a weeknight. We were seated after about 10 minutes. The place itself isn't huge, so I could see it getting super packed during peak meal times.

I went classic and got the chicken paitan ramen with an onsen poached egg, and the boyfriend ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen. The chicken paitan came with a few super tender chicken meatballs and the typical bamboo shoots, daikon sprouts, and green onions. It definitely had flavor, but it seemed to be lacking a bit of something, in my opinion. The onsen poached egg is a Japanese-style poached egg served cold. (Traditionally, these eggs would be cooked in the onsen -- Japanese hot springs -- and then chilled until ready to serve.) It was definitely a more unique topping than I've seen in other ramen places.

The soy sauce ramen, though. I stared at my boyfriend devouring that bowl of deliciousness. Thick soy sauce broth, a slow-braised whole chicken leg, blackened garlic oil... dang. I knew I made the wrong choice.

At a minimum of $15/bowl (the soy sauce is $18/bowl), prices are a bit steep. If you're willing to splurge, go all out and get the chicken paitan soy sauce. You won't regret it.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
The tomato ramen sounds gross, but it's actually amazing. If you want experimental ramen grounded in the fundamentals of great ramen, try the tomato ramen. I can best describe it as chicken pizza ramen, but that's a horrible name lol.

If you want sometime more conventional, try the Tori Paitan. Best tori paitan in the city!
author: Colby S.

description: Noodles were good, broth was very rich.  Onigiri was not really worthwhile.  No reservations here - come early or at off peak times.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Food is quite good. Tasty when it's available to order. I don't understand why when I've come for Sunday lunch service the last 2 times, you've been out of at least 2 types of ramen, and both times your signature ramen with the braised leg. I just don't understand how that happens repeatedly at a "Ramen Tavern," especially if you're closing after lunch and reopening for dinner service 1.5 hrs later when the items will magically reappear. If you're consistently busy throughout service with a considerable wait all the time, it shouldn't be that hard to manage inventory for your signature dish. Either that or just put on your menu that you usually run out and then we as customers can make the judgement call whether or not to try and come and wait in line. 

Look at marufuku, where it explicitly says on the menu how signature dishes are limited and that it runs out early. Or just braise a few more chicken legs and don't run out...
author: Panjit S.

description: Exceptional. Hands down my favorite ramen place in SF. I don't like lines but I wouldn't mind waiting for a seat here again. Service was a bit meh, but if they hired a couple more waitstaff I'm sure it'd be fine. Ambiance was great, it was a full house but I didn't have to shout at my friends to speak to them during dinner.
author: J Y.

description: My new fave ramen spot in the city. I'm a vegetarian and their Veggie ramen has the best broth I've ever had - on the thick side, but so flavorful! The staff is always incredibly attentive, too. They're on it with the water service. Highly recommend!
author: Kelsey C.

description:
It was just ok. There was a wait on a Tuesday night for two people. We waited about 20 minutes which isn't terrible. I was excited to see the paitan ramen was an option here. They ran out of veggie ramen so I got the chicken paitan, and my husband got the soy sauce chicken paitan. 

The chicken paitan had good broth flavor but it lacked any sort of sides. It came with three chicken meatballs, and then a mysterious white stalky vegetable (maybe the stalk of some cauliflower??). The soy sauce chicken paitan, while it was more IG-worthy, was not as good. The chicken was really dry. At least that order came with a soft boiled egg. 
The noodles in both were good - nothing special. 

It's definitely a spot for young people (with money because this ramen is around $20 with tax and tip).  Didn't really see any families but there were a few groups in line. Your whole group has to be there to be seated.
author: Veronica L.

description: Use the Yelp waitlist tool and go to a nearby bar or cafe while you wait!  The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen is always the winner. I can't imagine trying anything else. I swear there is a Vegan option my sister has had before... and she loved it.
author: Camille R.

description: I very much enjoyed Nojo Ramen Tavern when I ate here in January. So much so that I dreamt of the Chicken Paitan Tomato Ramen last night - but more on that later. Since it's quite popular, plan to either make a reservation, have your meals at odd times, or request your date to stand in line ahead of time. The first thing that arrived to the table were the Nojo "Takoyaki" Fries. The fries were nice and starchy, and served as a nice base for takoyaki sauce and fishy tako placed on top. Then came the ramen of my dreams. When I first read the name of the dish on the menu, I was intrigued. As soon as I tasted the first ramen noodle, I was transported to both Italy and Japan simultaneously. The flavors were in opposition yet in harmony all at once. Next time you are in Hayes be sure stop by - I gaurantee you will be dreaming of their ramen noodles for many nights to come.
author: Cindy L.

description: So I tried their vegan ramen. It was too salty and too heavy. Also, there are only 2 vegan options on the menu. I wouldn't say this vegan friendly.
author: Sevda G.

description:
Ramen right down the street in fancy Hayes Valley?! Sign me up!
A huge fan of ramen, the hubs and I made this our date night destination on a Friday night. We arrived around 7pm, placed our name on the waiting list, and we hung out about 45 min before getting called in to feast.
Famished, we started our eats with the takoyaki fries- overall, the small plate was tasty. The sauce gave it the umami flavor I was craving making it ultimately quite satisfying.
For the mains: having heard the "limited edition" veggie ramen sells out quick, I knew I had to have it! The hubs got the infamous chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso.
Without a doubt a true fan of MenshoTokyo, I was mildly disappointed with my veggie ramen. A bit bland, it did still host a myriad of veggies, and the noodles were good. In contrast, the chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso ramen was delicious!!! A good mix of spicy, tangy and JUST the right amount of creamy. The husband was without a doubt happy, and I certainly decided I would have this dish when we return- because we certainly will!
author: Roma R.

description: The chicken leg is extremely tender. The soup tastes like a mix between soy sauce and tonkatsu. Definitely recommend this place if you're in the area.
author: Lin Z.

description:
This place was on several "SF Best Food" lists. Since it was a short walk from my hotel I decided to eat outside of my zone of comfort and try something new. It was oh so delicious! The chicken bun app was crazy good. I got a chicken meatball Ramen bowl and it was really amazing! Wow! The flavors were striking.  Who knew I would adore ramen? 

Short wait time, maybe ten minutes max for me but I hear they are busy. I think I get lucky because I am a table of one. I sat at the counter and really enjoyed watching the staff make their creations. Good job Nojo. Oh yeah, the servers were delightfully nice and efficient.
author: Mary S.

description:
This could be dangerous. Nojo Ramen Tavern is just a few blocks from my office and is delicious. The price is a little high, but it's okay to splurge here and there. That's where the location comes in. I'm afraid that because I enjoyed it so much and it's close to the office I may find myself wandering over frequently.

Okay, so let me get into the details. We went right when Nojo opened, so there was no wait. The place was starting to fill up when we finished. I ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce and it was perfect. The chicken was tender and delicous. The broth was just thick enough without being overwhelming and was tasty. The noodles were chewy and had the right consistency. All the ingredients they put into the bowl worked well together and created what could be the perfect bowl of ramen.

So, you could probably say I'll be back...again...and again...and again.
author: Ruben P.

description: Delicious! Customer service 10/10. We went on a Sunday afternoon at 1 and only waited about 10 minutes. Food was amazing, authentic and worth it.
author: Foodie A.

description:
We tend to eat out in the City on Friday and therefore I am able to try a few different things. 

This was a spot I've had on my list of places to eat for a while so we dropped by. Even though it was rainy and a bit cold, we waited for about an hour. We drank wine while waiting. 

We ended up getting 2 appetizers and 2 ramen dishes. We ended up getting the Teriyaki Chicken Bun and the Nikumaki Rice Ball. The teriyaki chicken bun was delicious - highly recommend the dish. The rice ball was interesting, but not the best here. 

I ended up getting the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce - so good. I really enjoyed the chicken leg in the ramen. Nice and moist. He ended up getting the spicy ramen which wasn't that spicy but was great! 

Protip: chicken bun and ramens.
author: Nina Y.

description:
WHOOP finally a good ramen place on the city. Hands down WAY better than Mensho. I came here after the Nutcracker and inside was pretty packed already. 

We ordered:
Takoyaki Fries: YUM! Fries are well done and tastes exactly like takoyaki, but with fries!
Tomato Chicken Paitan: Pretty delicious! Ramen was chewy and soup was super flavorful, wasn't overwhelming at all! I added a dashi egg and the egg was SO good! Squeeze some lemon to it to enhance some flavors :D
Soy Sauce Chicken Paitan: This was very good also, my boyfriend really enjoyed it. He likes how the soup wasn't too heavy, the chicken leg was done right and super flavorful

Overall, would definitely come here again! This place by far is the best in the city in my opinion.
author: Natalie L.

description:
The first time my boyfriend and I dined at nojo ramen was the very first night in our new apartment. After a full day of packing, ramen sounded scrumptious. After searching on yelp for the closest ramen place, Nojo was the one. However, looking at the menu, I was thinking 'hmmm where is my pork or lobster broth?? Where is my my slice of pork!?' All the ramen options were chicken only which we thought was strange but we figured we'd give it a go because the pictures looked really good.  And we're glad we did!

Come to find out, the owners of Nojo own their own organic chicken farm (makes sense, right?). Anyway, we both got their standard chicken paitan which is way different than typical ramen you'd expect but it doesn't leave you feeling unsatisfactory. The one server we had wasn't great but as being a former server, I was observing the other servers. I think we just got our guy on a bad night. 

We've been multiples after that and that server is no longer there and the food is always stellar no matter what you get. I haven't gotten a dish I didn't enjoy. 

My favorite is the chicken paitan soy sauce add spice bomb. The avocado nori appetizer is always amazing. 

We have brought our friends and family and everyone agrees, this place is legit. Go get some Nojo Ramen!
author: Katlyn H.

description:
I can confidently say that I've had good ramen, but Nojo exceeded all my expectations. I usually try to avoid going to the same restaurant twice, but I 100% will be a returning customer. I ordered the most popular dish, the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen, which had a large, slow-cooked chicken leg. The leg was so tender; The meat just fell of the bone. The noodles were cooked to a perfect al dente, and had that great chewiness about it. The broth was tasty, with very intense flavors but was almost a bit too salty. 

I noticed that almost all the dishes were entirely chicken based; Very different, considering that most of the ramen I've had have always been pork or beef based. Didn't know chicken could go so perfectly with ramen! 

Small but delicious restaurant near the Civic Center. Cozy but upscale atmosphere, and as expected with all great restaurant, long lines after 6:30! For a ramen place, it is on the pricier side, but for the food and quality you get, it's a non-issue. So excited to go back and try their other dishes!
author: Arielle I.

description:
Best non pork ramen I've ever had.  In fact, I'd go so far as to say they beat a lot of the pork ramen places!

So far, I've had the soy sauce, spicy miso, and tomato flavors and I can definitively, they are all good!  I'm definitely coming back to try every flavor, though it's taking longer than expected since I keep ordering the ones I've had!

All:
+Thick, chewy, al dente noodles that the chefs in the back are carefully cooking for each order
+Warmed up bowls for each order. A really nice extra touch that just makes me appreciate the effort they're putting in.
+Delicious, flavorful broth that makes me want more noodles.  When the bowls come out, approximately 3/4 full, my first thought is always that it might not be enough food, but I'm always almost overly stuffed by the end of dinner, even though the broth is so delicious I want to keep spooning it up.

Soy Sauce:
+The star is the chicken leg. Simply marinaded in a soy sauce, mirin, ginger sauce, it is perfectly cooked, falling off the bone, and so flavorful the bones are even flavored (yes, I chewed on them a bit. Lol)
+Chives add a nice bit of greenery and go really well with the garlicky broth. I couldn't get enough, even though without the noodles, it was just on the edge of salty.
+Yummy crunchy fried gobo (adds another layer of flavor) and the addition of the dashi egg.

Spicy Miso:
+In the wintertime, the spiciness is just enough o keep me warm walking through the cold windy streets of SF, without being too spicy to have indigestion even I'm eating late.
+Cilantro is the nice bit of green as long as you like cilantro.
+Fried gobo is yummy and has every bite is layered with flavors.

Tomato:
+Best, most tasty tomato soup I've ever had. If only all other tomato bases were this flavorful!  Really worth a try.
+Cheese. Soooo good. Almost Italian inspired, but keeps it within an Asian realm with the other flavors.
+Fried garlic. Need I say more?
author: Anna D.

description:
This is one of our favourite Ramen places in the city. Get here early because there's always a wait, but it's well worth it.  I've waited out in the cold for an hour several times. 

The Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso with an extra soft boiled egg is usually my go to, but really you can't go wrong with any of the ramen dishes.
author: Laurens D.

description: I went here with my parents and boyfriend at 6pm and thought it wouldn't be busy since it opens at 5pm. We waited for ~45 minutes, but the food made up for it. The ramen broth was very flavorful, though a little salty, and the chicken (their specialty) was awesome. It was the best chicken ramen I've had so far. A little bit on the pricey side for ramen, but would definitely come back every now and then. The portions are also smaller than other ramen places.
author: Lillian B.

description: Good to have a vegan ramen option (though very salty) but it's one of those SF overcrowded trendy places where they aggressively try to rush you out and people hover over you waiting for your table while you're eating. It's also super loud so not a relaxing dining experience.
author: Lily G.

description:
Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen is great! The braised chicken leg is super flavorful and juicy, broth is also delicious and has just the right level of 'thickness'. Although it is a tad bit pricy for a bowl of ramen with not much toppings.
Service is quite nice and friendly with a cozy and modern interior! Minus one star because they messed up my order twice when I just asked for no green onions added.
Would definitely come back if I'm in the area and craving ramen!
author: Mandy H.

description: Wonderful Ramen Noodle Restaurant located in the corner of Franklin street! Waiting game is a bit intense (30 minutes wait on Sat around 5pm); but the food comes out pretty fast and yummy! Hearty food! Chicken pantai ramen is very tasty, the broth is heavy and salty on the side but the chicken drumstick sweetness balances out.  Takeyoji fries is highlight point!!
author: Jenny N.

description:
The best thing about Nojo is that their ramen is decent but there isn't a ridiculous line. Even though other ramen places are pretty hyped (like Mensho) the line still deters me from wanting to visit.

Nojo has decent ramen, it's SF priced (read: it's going to be over $15 just for a bowl of ramen) but the ramen is good! I like their chicken paitan tomato ramen - it sounds like a kind of strange combination, but you won't regret trying it! The tomato is really fragrant and somehow matches the flavor profile of ramen. YUM.

They have a nice selection of beer/wine/sake and other non-alcoholic drinks, so it makes for a nice casual date spot too. Swing by if you're craving good ramen and don't want to wait too long!
author: Theresa L.

description: Never before have I had Patian ramen before, and not the tomato broth version. The ramen is a bit on the expensive side but it has unique flavours. You must get there early for the popular soy sauce paitian ramen and expect line ups!
author: Lesley Y.

description:
Nojo Ramen really adds to the new trend of ramen joints serving Chicken Paitan. Nojo ramen really gets the meal right, the 4.5/5 stars is really more for the long wait and high prices for a bowl of ramen. I came at lunchtime at 11:30am and there was already a long queue outside the restaurant to be seated.
