The restaurant definitely has a disproportionate amount of two table seats, but does have tables for larger parties. The restaurant will also not seat you until the whole party has arrived. 

[Ramen]
I really love the broth of the Spicy Paitan. Normally, spicy ramen can be really oily and make you feel extremely heavy after finishing the meal. The broth still can be a little on the salty side like most ramen broth. However, this bowl was the perfect size and texture. Only negative here is that there could've been a little less cilantro on top. I also had the fries that were super yummy and a great shareable appetizer. 

[Service]
The ramen came out very fast and the service was fast and attentive. Servers take the time to explain the menu and give you their recommendations. 

Definitely the ramen star of Hayes Valley. I highly recommend giving Nojo ramen a try, but make sure that you come before the restaurant opens to wait in line if you want to guarantee a first seating.
author: Alice Z.

description:
If I have to take sides, I'd say Mensho Tokyo is better than here.
But this is closer to me and the line seems a bit quicker (at least they don't make you wait in a literal line---!  You can put your name down and come back later)

They run out of vegetarian ramen early every night, so come earlier than 7:30 if you want it.  They also will run out of their popular Soy Sauce (Shoyu) around 8:30 or so.

They're popular for having their whole braised chicken legs, but I don't really see anything particularly special about their chicken legs or their chicken meatballs, although both are good.  It's just not really something really special to me.

What is special is the fact that they allow you to order sides of other toppings and are generous with the amount of extra.  I like the texture of fried crunchy sweet things, so I normally order a plate of fried gobo ($1.50) to accompany my ramen, and it is absolute heaven when taken in a bite with the rich umani soup-- crunchy sweet fried veggies (think like flakes of veggie tempura) with the salty paitan broth.

Just get the paitan or the shoyu ramen if they have it, everything else is pretty normal.
author: Alice S.

description:
Thickest ramen broth I've ever had!! My friends and I had a discussion about this... do we think they put starch in it? Flour? Do they boil it for a long time so it's basically a stew? Who knows but I loveeeeee the thick broth. It's so flavorful and yum. And the meat is so tender and soft and slides right off the bone! 

Got the poke bowl the second time I came here which was fancy and pretty good - but I'm the type of person who'd rather get poke bowls at an actual poke bar or from some truck cause I like my bowls simple.. this one had a lot of flavor and a little kick to it, also on the very saltier side. I'll probably stick to the ramen here.

Our waiter brought our sake carafe, spilled a decent amount of it on the floor as he was putting it down on the table, splashed on my friend, wiped it up nonchalantly and left. Didn't get us a new one or say anything. Too rushed and too busy to pay attention to their customers, which is on the lower end of the spectrum of service for a Japanese ramen place..
author: Nicole L.

description:
This is my third time coming here and the third time I've ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce because it's just SO good.

The broth is meaty and creamy with the perfect amount of soy sauce mixed in to accentuate the flavors. Chicken leg was delicious and the egg was cooked perfectly. It's super filling so I had to take the rest of my food to go. I'm excited to eat my leftovers!

Each time I've been here the wait was around 20-30 minutes for up to 4 people on a weekday, which isn't too bad and definitely worth it in my opinion.
author: Alexis N.

description:
Oh boy. One, come early to sign up for the waiting list. The waiting list stops taking down people before their closing time to accommodate for the limited broth and noodles they have. The wait was an hour getting there at 6pm on sunday. They close at 7pm but if you are on the waiting list prior to when they stop taking names, youre good. 

By the time we were seated.. they only had a few options of ramen left. Its pretty expensive for a standard bowl of ramen. Tried their chicken paitan tomato ramen ($16) which had a creamy quality to it that was unique to ramen for sure. It was tasty! Also tried their takoyaki fries and chicken nanbans. They are both appetizer size but sround $10, which is also pretty pricey. I cant say this is the best ramen ive had or anything like that.. but it was different, service was friendly, and the ambianc was nice. Id say its too pricey for hitting up ramen regularly... but a good experience.
author: Dana O.

description:
Nothing special at all.  Not worth the long place and it's overpriced.

Will not return.
author: TopCat W.

description: My favorite Ramen in the ENTIRE Bay. First Ramen place I've gone to and not had to ask for more season or said it's missing something!!! And if that's not all, my 7 year old who totally frowns when I say we're having Ramen for dinner actually didn't eat from the small plate menu this time around. She really loves the Ramen. If I have one complaint it would be it left me wanting more but I didn't want to embarrass myself and order another chicken tan tan!! Also the Unami wings are out of this world!! There is not substitute for great Ramen once you have tried it and I also love the chicken options as I am not a pork Ramen fan! 4 thumbs up!
author: Keyana H.

description:
There is no ramen shop like Nojo. I love the location (across from the Jazz Center), the atmosphere (wood interior and large windows), and the food! 

I ordered the takoyaki fries and it was so good that I had to order another plate immediately. The ramen is on the pricier side but it is to die for. You MUST get the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen! It comes with a whole chicken leg in your ramen that is braised to perfection... The meat literally falls off the bone right when you touch it. *drool*

Nojo is pretty spacious for a ramen shop and the wait isn't too bad, but it does fill up quickly and it seems to be getting more popular!
author: Chanel H.

description:
I was looking for a ramen place nearby before we headed back home and found Nojo. It was located in a quieter part of town, and we even found parking right in front. I didn't even know that was possible in SF! 

This is definitely a more modern take on ramen - not your average hole in the wall spot. Everything from the menu to the decor to the bowls were unique but modern. Nice enough for a date night but casual enough for a quick bite. There were lots of tables and even bar and counter space, and the place filled up quickly as it became closer to dinner time. 

I ordered the chicken paitan ramen. It's plain, but still had flavor. There were "fluffy chicken meatballs" as indicated on the menu - I didn't know meatballs could be fluffy until I tried them. They were light and flavorful. I wish I would've ordered something different though with some heat and more toppings. I ordered mine with a side of a soft boiled egg - always necessary for ramen!
author: Ashley C.

description: To be honest I am not the biggest fan of ramen but will usually cave and eat it because my boyfriend loves it! I have heard about Nojo from several friends and decided to do a dinner celebrating my boyfriend at this place. Although the wait was long, the area is so fun and you can easily get a quick drink nearby. The wait was completely worth it, I got the spicy ramen with chicken and gulped it all down! The perfect meal on a cold rainy day. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Rachel N.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite ramen spot in the city ! I actually prefer this over Mensho in my opinion. We ordered their special "chicken paitan soy sauce" and it was absolutely delicious ! The broth was rich and creamy, but not too heavy and thick. The ramen noodle has that thick, chewy and bouncy texture which reminded me a lot of the noodles you get in Japan. Also, it comes with a whole chicken leg ! The meat literally falls right off and it's super soft, not dry like you would imagine it to be when you first see it. 

Definitely come early because there's always a wait ! The servers are very attentive so that's a plus ! Would definitely come again !
author: Cindy Jane Y.

description:
Before getting seated, myself and a group of 6 others had to wait about 45 minutes or so.  It's not the largest place so the wait time was expected. They had heaters outside which made the wait a little more pleasant. However, since they were sitting other groups before us who came after, we just requested to be split up because it was nearly impossible to have a table of 7 sit all together there. Now on to the food, 

Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen: 5/5
Yes just yes. Those are the only words I could say after eating my $18.50 bowl of ramen. And that chicken leg doe! The meat was so tender and falling off the bone. I really was impressed by the broth. It was just right & not too salty. What really made the bowl of ramen was how fresh the noodles were. In each bite you can notice the quality of it. If you like an extra kick, get the spicy bomb and put it in your ramen. To be honest though, it was alot for me, you could probably get away with sharing a bowl and an appetizer if you wanted too. 
 
Wings: 2.5/5
An order comes with 3 wings. It was alright, I think I expected alot more from what I read. We asked for the dipping sauce which went well with the wings. I would not recommend them, try the other options lol. 

Chicken Paitan Tan Tan Spicy Miso: 4/5 
Not the spiciest but has a tiny kick. The bowl of ramen comes with grounded chicken, toasted sesame, cilantro, scallion, fried gobo, and spice bomb. As expected, the broth was a lot thicker compared to the soy sauce ramen. I only had a couple of bites but the flavor was very strong. A little on the oiler side for the broth but still worth trying if you like a spicy miso based broth. 

Side note: They give you a big spoon and the chopsticks are unique which make enjoying your ramen that much easier. I'm not sure why I remember this small detail but I thought it was worth mentioning. 

Nojo is definitely worth the visit and will warm you up on those chilly San Francisco days. The noodle quality is A+ if you are in the area I would recommend.
author: Asia P.

description:
#72 ramen review haha. Can you believe that? #ramensheriff 

Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen
- BROTH: I was expecting a light broth since it's "chicken" ramen, but it was actually REALLY thick and heavy. Not as thick as Mensho, but thicker than Ramen Parlor in San Mateo. I would prefer a lighter broth, but this was still very flavorful and delicious. I was surprised it was chicken broth, because it tasted just like tonkatsu
- NOODLES: Noodles were good! Very firm, just the way I like them. 
- EGG: half soft boiled egg was cooked just right
- CHICKEN LEG: OMG. This chicken leg was fall-off-the-bone tender!! I was able to use my chopsticks to take the meat off. Very impressed. Great job Nojo!

The wait was about 40 minutes which we went over next door to grab a drink while waiting. 

OVERALL: This was a satisfying bowl of ramen. Impressed with the extremely tender chicken leg, and noodles, egg, and broth were all on point. My perfect bowl of ramen wouldn't be as thick, but that's just my preference. However, overall a good spot for ramen in SF, and better than Mensho imo! 

Happy Slurpin :) 
-Ramen Sheriff
author: Raquel Y.

description: Came in around 1:00pm on a Sunday and there was about a 20 minute wait. Got seated at the bar and ordered some of the Nojo Fries (think takoyaki but instead, french fries) and their Soy Sauce Ramen. The fries were delicious and the ramen was sooooo good. It came with a huge braised chicken thigh. I felt the place was a little pricier for what it was, but overall the food was delicious.
author: Christine Y.

description: Got the chicken patina sit sauce ramen and it was okay. The broth was not particularly flavorful, the noodles were kind of soggy, and the chicken was average. Overall it was a decent experience, but I wouldn't wait in line for this place again.
author: Chang L.

description:
The chicken paitan soy sauce ramen is a must-try here! The chicken leg is a good comfort food if you are looking for something to make you happy. This place may not serve the most authentic Japanese ramen, but it adds very interesting twists to the ramen dishes. 

The atmosphere is quite modern and intimate too, good for a small group of friends to gather or dates.
author: Amy Z.

description: Amazing food, beautiful atmosphere, friendly staff!! The wait was a bit long, but we were able to order drinks from the bar which made the time fly by. I try to eat a plant based diet, and their vegetarian option was the best veggie miso ramen I have ever had. I can't wait to go back when I am in the city again someday. I highly recommend Nojo Ramen!
author: Sydney D.

description: This Saturday was my 2nd attempt to try Nojo Ramen. Finally got seated right when they opened. If there's a line already at 5pm, that only means their ramen must be really good. Most people go to Nojo for their Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen, but I did not get that. Last Saturday, I was craving for more creamier and richer broth so I got their Chicken tsukune meatballs ramen (chicken Paitan). I was really nervous to try this since it's so hard to please me to like a certain flavored ramen, I always compare it to Japan's and they rarely have chicken flavor too. Nojo successfully won my heart. The noodles were perfectly cooked. The meatballs tasted amazing and broth is so flavorful. Definitely satisfied my cravings. Oh and service was also exceptional.
author: Gwen M.

description:
Been wanting to try this place and finally got to 2 weeks ago! 
We got here around 1pm and we beat the rush.

We ordered the following:
-Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce: The broth was so good but the chicken was even better. I literally lightly grazed the chicken with my chopsticks and the meat fell right off, it was that tender. Super duper tasty and would totally get again. 5/5

-Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso: My BF ordered this and instead of having a whole chekcn leg in it, it had ground chicken. I liked the broth in his ramen more because I love spicy miso. Only had a bite of it but my BF really enjoyed it. 

-Teriyaki Chicken Rice Bowl: Ordered this for my baby brother and his first reaction was "This chicken is really good! Try it!" I didn't try it because I had a whole chicken leg to eat but he really liked his rice bowl and the chicken was the major star in the dish. 

-Chicken Nanban: We got about 5 pieces of lightly fried chicken topped with a house made tartar sauce. The chicken was tender but the sauce really makes the dish. The tartar sauce was homemade and had bits of eggs in it so it was like a hybrid version of a tartar egg salad sauce. Wish I could buy that sauce by the jar, it's that good!!!

I would come back here again, just wish that the prices were a little friendlier. $18 for a bowl of ramen is prettyy darn steep.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Good ramen, long wait. 

Our group of 4 waited about 45 minutes but the wait was much better than at mensho. You just put your name down and can hang about, instead of waiting in a line. 

Got the soy sauce paitan, very delicious. The chicken was fall off the bone tender. Broth was not bad, not as thick as other spots, which is nice. I don't like to feel like I'm sipping on gravy with each bite. 

Would definitely come back.
author: Tu T.

description: This might be my favorite ramen shop in SF. Mensho Tokyo might be more popular but their ramen is way too heavy for me. Nojo's broth however is just right and their menu is much more innovative. If you're a spaghetti fan, the shredded chicken ramen with tomatoes is like the best of both worlds and strikes the perfect balance of sour and savory. My favorite though is their chicken meatball ramen, which has one of the best chicken broths I've had anywhere, and the juicy meatballs make other ramen shops' chashu taste like leftovers. A must-visit for ramen aficionados.
author: Carl W.

description:
PSA: The broth is 99% chicken and 1% pork. I was unaware of this until I was seated and asked my server for clarification. This probably doesn't matter to most people since ramen broth is always pork-based, but I don't eat pork so hearing about Nojo's chicken-based ramen was music to my ears. I stopped by with the intention of getting the Soy Sauce Chicken Paitan, only to find out that I couldn't have it. Instead, I opted for the vegetarian ramen... Womp womp womp :(

For appetizers, I had the crab and avocado salad ($12). Essentially just avocado and crab tossed in a creamy dressing with two tiny crostinis on the side. 

The vegetarian ramen was $16.50 and included "soy meat," corn, okra, and some greens. The broth was pretty flavorful considering it was vegetarian and the noodles had a chewy texture to them. However for a meatless ramen, I did find the portion to be a bit small. I usually get stuffed pretty easily but I still found myself a bit hungry after I finished my bowl.

My bf had the Soy Sauce Chicken Paitan ($18.50) and he seemed to enjoy it. He did mention that the chicken fell right off the bone so I sort of just watched him eat it and imagined it in my mouth. lol. *cries*

I just wished the menu had specified about the use of pork broth in the chicken ramen, even if it is an extremely minimal amount. I do appreciate my server being honest about it though, and not to mention, he was super friendly. In short, my dreams of 100% chicken ramen is just that-- a dream.
author: Marny N.

description: Great place to get a quick but delicious bite before heading on to the Symphony. Food is hot, fresh and oh so yummm! And the service is fast and courteous but give yourself an extra 20-30 as this place does get busy.
author: Rashida L.

description:
Solid ramen joint that focuses on chicken based broth. Portion isn't huge, but the flavors were delicious and the noodles were just springy enough. The spicy chicken paitan was superb--full of flavors but not overly salty. The fluffy chicken meatballs were a great addition to the ramen. By 5:45pm the place is pretty packed, but they turn over the tables rather quickly. 

Can't wait to come back and try other items.
author: Lynn C.

description:
I was thoroughly surprised!

Walking around the Hayes Valley area looking for dinner, my friend and I opted for noodle soup on a cold SF summer night. I hadn't heard of Nojo but I'm glad I discovered it!

The ramen is not traditional and there's a lot of chicken on the menu. Ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce (recommended per Yelp highlights) and enjoyed most of it! (Except the bottom broth got a little salty) the chicken drumette was moist and fell off the bone with little effort. The broth was light and flavorful but not too overpowering. The noodles were a little harder than preferred but maybe this is their definition of "al dente". Overall, I enjoyed my meal very much and was glad I missed the crowd that started coming in around 6pm on a Sunday night. 

Tl;dr give it a try and add it to your SF ramen list! Get the soy sauce paitan chicken one.
author: Carissa G.

description:
Tasty? Yes. Super memorable? I don't know. I think the only thing that makes it memorable is that they put a whole chicken leg in the soy sauce paitan ramen.

However, it's a pretty hefty price tag for ramen. Luckily, my friends came early on a Friday to grab a table (around 5:15)...so the wait wasn't an issue. I didn't show up until 6:15, which according to yelp, there would supposedly be a long wait. However, I didn't see any lines when I walked in (except maybe for the bathroom). I also saw an open table still, so not sure if that's the issue. 

Since I came late, I missed out on all the appetizers the table ordered, so might come back to try that. 3.5 stars...
author: Cynthia X.

description:
This place is king of Chicken Ramen.

The thing to get: Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen. It comes with a leg and thigh of a chicken that has been cooked like a confit. The broth is what you expect from good ramen - white and thick and rich. The noodles, slightly chewy of course.

The thing you have to watch out for is the long ass wait. Because this is so popular and close to the center of the city, if you come at dinner time (like 6:30-7PM) the wait gets to be about an hour for groups of 4-6. Also, this place is expensive - it's like $16 bucks a bowl + tax and tip. But they are THE BEST chicken ramen, and that comes with a price.
author: Albert C.

description:
Delicious! I really enjoyed the Chicken Paitan, Chicken Paitan Soy, and Spicy Miso. The flavors were clean, though to me there was a pretty strong nori/seaweed flavor (which I like). I still prefer the tori paitan at Mensho, which is a lot thicker. Still, I'm glad to have nojo as an option. 
 
I thought most of the appetizers were just meh. The only one I've really liked so far = chicken wings.. but who doesn't like chicken wings? The other chicken appetizers I found acceptable but kind of bland and not juicy enough. I've also tried the takoyaki fries (not nearly as good as real takoyaki), avocado with seaweed topping, and salad with tofu. I would recommend getting an extra bowl of ramen to share instead of the apps. :)
author: Jean L.

description: Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce: thick, flavorful broth, noodles have good chewing consistency.
author: Anthony W.

description:
MOVE OVER RAMEN DOJO!! This new-ish joint in Hayes Valley is now easily on the top of my ramen joint list in the Bay Area. I'm always looking for a place that serves good quality ramen and has other options aside from the traditional pork broth. Im no ramen guru and understand most people prefer pork based broths, but I def love chicken broth a lot more and really do feel like its much lighter! They also have a vegan option here! 

Nojo is def pricey but I dont mind because I can taste the quality ingredients being used. The location is very well decorated and most importantly the servers actually understand customer service which I have not seen at many ramen shops who are trying to get you in and out.

I brought my 15 year old cousin here who is raised in San Antonio, TX. He, like most people who have never had ramen, did not understand why I was taking him to eat Top Ramen (lol). Hes got quite the picky palate being raised on Tex-Mex and BBQ. We both ordered the Paitan tan-tan spicy. If you love cilantro you must get this! The fresh cilantro and with the extra spicy was amazing! 

As always I almost ate myself to death by trying to finish my entire bowl. With 1/4 left I did not feel as heavy and bloated as I do when I have had pork based ramen. Although I could not possibly afford  (monetary and caloric) to eat here often, I cant wait to come back on a cold gloomy day and indulge!!
author: Hetal P.

description:
Another hipster ramen place with a long wait. Actually, the space was bit fancier than your average hipster ramen place. Meaning, it was a nice space to be in for a night out. Opt for a private table if you don't want to be at one of their communal tables.

In regards to the ramen, I didn't care for their broth especially towards the end--I left about a third of it. But their chicken was tender and flavorful--I enjoyed that thoroughly. 

Would I go back? Sorry, no. But if I were walking pass and saw that there was no line, then sure!
author: Yad L.

description: Showed up at 10:05pm and was turned away - CLOSED. Why does time say open until 10:30?
author: Abigail T.

description:
I'm all for hipster, San Francisco, but this is just getting absurd. Ridiculously over priced for how much food you get. If this was fine dining, it would have been more understandable, but this is ramen we're talking about. I was still hungry after eating my $20 bowl of chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso ramen (which came with too much cilantro). And I'm a tiny person. Adding to the ridiculousness, did I mention that you can get EXTRA cilantro as a topping for an additional $2? Much disappointment. 

However, the soup base was tasty. The broth was rich, salty, and mildly spicy. The noodles cooked al dente. Service was decent and friendly, nothing that stood out. Dinner rush on a weekend was insanely busy for them and our party of 6 had to wait an hour to get seated. Frankly, I don't see the hype.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
My favorite ramen spot in SF. Something about their ramen style hits the spot. 

I've had the creamy, rich, thick and authentic broth of Mensho, the Americanized Cheap Katana Ya, the mediocre and yet appealing Izakaya Sosai, and  decent Iza Ramen, Nojo is hands down my preference.

The broth isn't gaudy or too light, it's flavorful and delightful. There are enough selections to appease most and I leave full and happy.
author: Angeline K.

description:
Good ramen. But call before you go. I've been there 4 times, at least 3-4 hours before they close and they always run out of ramen and close the restaurant by 5:30pm. I think they got really popular and don't know how to plan correctly.  Regardless it's good ramen - especially if you're a vegetarian.

EDIT: I think they purposefully limit the quantity to drive demand. A good business tactic but sucks for the consumer.

EDIT 2 - they've figured how to better operate and this is one of the favorite restaurants in the city. With the new Yelp wait-list you also don't have to wait forever outside. Great improvements.
author: Sai M.

description:
Sometimes I wonder how I can spending half an hour debating whether I want to buy a $10 shirt and I don't hesitate at all when dropping $18.50 on a bowl of ramen. 

My sister wanted to come here because of their half chicken yeah, it looked instagram worthy, but was it good? Hell yeah it was!

I got the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce and it's one of those dishes where you just don't want to share. The ramen was cooked perfectly, the broth was flavorful - not to salty and a little on the thicker side (which I enjoy), and the chicken leg was cooked perfectly, seasoned well, and falls of the bone. I finished the bowl feeling completely satisfied. 

Overall, probably my top ramen spot right now and so worth the price tag.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Finally, we got here before 6, so was able to get seated right away. They do not take reservations and will not seat you till everybody is there. 
We started with wasabi tuna tartare. Great dish to share. Then we tried the bun. It's only one bun so if you are hungry, get a bun each.
Then the ramen. We had spicy Tantan miso and chicken taipan soy sauce. They were both delicious! It's great dish for a cold night. Tantan miso has a lot of garlic in it!
author: Akiko I.

description:
So the ramen here is just so heavenly. This is definitely one of the most memorable bowls of ramen I have had so far. I'm still drooling about it while writing this review. I see a lot of Yelpers comparing this place to Mensho Tokyo and to be honest, I think this place is actually better than Mensho Tokyo. The prices are roughly the same but I find Nojo to be more unique with a better overall ambience. Nojo has great seating variety and a nice upscale feel to it. I came here with my boyfriend and I do have to mention that the servers were a big cockblock constantly sticking their heads between us, but at least they were sweet at first until they tried to kick us out later. 

My friend got the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen and I got the Chicken Paitan Ramen. The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen gets a lot of attention due to that huge chicken leg they throw in there. That chicken leg is DELICIOUS. The meat really just melts in your mouth and was absolutely amazing. It's comparable to amazing chicken I have had in France. The soup is also very strong and bold and adds well to the dish. 

However, my personal FAVORITE was actually the Chicken Paitan. The broth is nice and thick without being too rich and it's just really packed with flavor. The broth reminds me of nice homemade chicken broth. Words can't describe how good that broth was. The noodles here are also nicely fresh and chewy. I have no complaints about the food here. I hope to come back and try their gyozas as well!
author: Catherine S.

description: Nojo isn't your traditional tonkotsu ramen place but it's really good (though definitely on the more expensive side). Their chicken-based ramen broths are pretty thick but incredibly flavorful. I've had pretty much everything on their menu and you can't really go wrong. If you're dying to try this place, definitely come on a weekday as they get pretty busy on the weekend.
author: Charles L.

description: Fantastic broth with the noodles. The down side there are no reservations and you will have to wait.
author: Alexander S.

description:
I spent last week craving ramen like nobody's business. By Friday, I'd landed on Nojo and was stoked for a hot bowl of ramen chased with a monaka ice cream sandwich. You can imagine my disappointment when, after a 45-minute wait, we sat down to order, and were informed the veggie miso ramen is prepared and served in limited quantities only (and was sold out for the evening) -- a small fact the online menu fails to mention. 

No Nojo for me, last week or probably ever. I can definitely get behind small batches and unique opportunities, but leaving that information off a website, when it's the only vegetarian option, is kind of a bummer for non-meat eaters.
author: Caitlin D.

description:
Believe the hype and brave the line.  And that's saying something since that line can be over 30 minutes.  

But don't go here for that famous ginormous piece of chicken ramen (whatever it's called).  I know this is going to sound crazy, but get the second most famous chicken meatball one instead.  It's the best meatballs I've ever had in my life, and by far the best chicken meatballs.  It tastes like they somehow figured out how to take just the juiciest, most tender (and I'll admit, fatty) parts of the chicken and form them into the most perfect, non-overcooked balls ever.   They are so magically moist and rich that the (completely non-dry, broth soaked, perfectly cooked) chicken piece ramen seemed dry in contrast.  While I think there's no comparison when it comes to the meats, there is comparison when it comes to the broth.  Both are excellent even if the light colored one pairs with the chicken meatballs better.

Also, I kind of suck at reviewing because I haven't called any of these things what they're called on the menu.  This is what happens when your fiance does all of the ordering while you stare at the beer list.  Speaking of which: they had a delicious amber beer on tap when we went, which I highly recommend.  They also had some avocado plus nori appetizers that were a perfect contrast to the richer ramen dishes.  Will be going back asap!

Update: we've been back a couple times since and yes I STILL say get the chicken meatball one... OH and they now let you order MOAR CHICKEN MEATBALLZ a la carte, which you absolutely should, even if you are not getting the chicken meatball ramen (which I think is called "fluffy chicken tsukune."  They've also added a "teriyaki chicken bun" recently, which is a deviled egg and chicken on a steamed bun, and highly recommended.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I eat a lot of ramen and this is my favorite place in the city at the moment. I've been there three times and each time the meal has been a knockout! 

The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen is their signature dish and one worth visiting for thanks to the slow braised whole chicken leg that comes on top of an already killer bowl of ramen, it's amazing! The Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso Ramen is also a winner thanks to the ground chicken, toasted sesame and a "spice bomb" of heat. All the ramen here is chicken based which is great but fear not they have a surprisingly rich vegetarian ramen as well, but this is SF and it runs out quickly! 

Nojo is pricy and be prepared to wait as the joint is always busy and ALWAYS has a line - but trust me, it's worth it! This is a bowl of ramen worth waiting for!
author: G C.

description:
Ok, yes, this is a damn fine bowl of ramen (as long as you're not expecting it to be super-traditional). It's conveniently located, delicious, and efficient. We were in and out in under an hour!

It's also $18.50+, and the restaurant gets full quickly. We walked in at 5:01 (after forgetting to eat lunch prior to our matinee ballet performance) and were seated immediately. Worth noting 4 other tables were already seated, so eager beavers might get in earlier than 5pm opening if they're ready. By 5:30pm, tables were full and people were waiting outside.

We ordered wings ($4.50 for 3) and two bowls of ramen. The total was ~$55 after tip. We left _very_ full; probably could have skipped the wings. We wanted to try the sake but it was pricier than wine, which we thought was too expensive considering the excellent sake we've had elsewhere for much less. 

I'd describe the entire experience as an occasional treat; not a regular stop. Between the richness of the food, the cost, and having to get there early to get a seat... I can't see myself visiting here often, and probably never if the wait is longer than 10 minutes. 

I have two warnings: 
-if you pull your chair in, beware that the crossbars are made of thin metal that will dig into bare ankles if they're caught under. Some of the bar stools also appeared unsteady with the adjustable feet falling out.
-either tuck your napkin into the collar of your shirt, bend over into your bowl, or expect occasional splashes to stain delicate fabrics. My shirt now has a permanent spot on the chest which has demoted it to around-the-house only :(
author: Krista L.

description: We arrived here very late,around 9pm, so we don't need to wait. The environment is good, and the ramen is tasty. Highly recommended.
author: Jenny H.

description:
Pretty close to 5 stars! Delicious ramen! $16-$18/bowl. Came around 4:30 pm on a Sun, and luckily only waited about 20 minutes. Fast service. Rich, savory broth. 

Hubs and a friend ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen. Thick pork broth w/ finely chopped onions, diced green onions, a moist chicken leg...

I ordered the tomato ramen-- juicy diced chicken, al dente ramen, and garlic. Lots of it! Next to my hubby, garlic is the thing I love most! Also came w/ shredded reggiano cheese. Wasn't too sure about it on Japanese food, but it works! Oh so insanely garlicy, fresh, delightful! Slurped it all up! Japanese meets Italiano. Oh so good! 

Yes, yes, yes! Can't wait to go back! Thanks Ed U and friends for your yelp reviews that are spot on!
author: Lisa B.

description:
Last few experiences here have unfortunately not been great.

Came here with 2 friends on Sunday and we all got food poisoning. We had the spicy miso ramen, rice balls, and the tuna tartare.
author: Laura D.

description:
This place is sooo good. Definitely worth the wait. Put your name on the (long) list, go grab a drink nearby and come back in half an hour or so. They could have a high tech notification system, or take reservations, but they don't, and that's fine. 

The chicken nan ban is yummy and the chicken paitan is really special too. Get a soft boiled egg. You will be glad you did. The great thing about this place is they also have a vegan option that is excellent if you are in mixed dietary company. 

I love this place and although it isn't cheap, it certainly isn't prohibitively expensive. Like most things, you get what you pay for. The quality, freshness, and presentation is next level, and I'm happy to pay more for a superior product.
author: Nina N.

description: Nojo has been really trendy for people, but I personally find it okay. My caveat is that I don't like heavy paitans - I'm more of a chicken shoyu type, so paitan is a bit rich. Overall, great portion size here - lots of noodles, huge amounts of chicken, and a really filling bowl of broth. It's just a bit too heavy and oily for my liking, especially because there's always a line here, but not bad if you love paitan.
author: Jasmine X.

description: Hipster snacks. Not for those who set the bar via the best in Japan. Flavor profiles are weak, but, they do their best in terms of quality. Still, creative before taste... next.
author: Dan M.

description: Another long distance ramen review coming at you. I ordered the chicken paitan and tried the chicken soy paitan, and I was honestly surprised by the richness of the broth while still having a strong punch of flavor. Every time I took a slurp of broth I felt a blast of flavor flow through my whole body. The regular chicken paitan came with chicken meatballs, and I was really expecting dry and flavorless experience, but as soon as I cut through with my chopstick I knew I had something special on my hands. The chopsticks sliced through the tender meat ball like butter, and when I took a bite I was just blown away. The sharp yet rich flavor of the chicken meatball felt like an explosion in my mouth with each bite, and I was overwhelmed by the chicken flavor. Each bite made me feel like I was standing in a chicken broth tsunami, and the meatballs were a true pleasure that knocked the experience to a 5 Star review.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I like this place WAY better than Mensho (which has a thicker consistency in the soup). It's pricey but you're in SF, wtf do you expect?!

I took my classmate here. He's from Japan so I . He liked it better than the ramen in Japan. He usually eats ramen at mom & pop shops so he was use to the waiting, the price, and the gourmet bowls. We ordered the spicy tan tan and DEVOURED IT. My Swiss classmate added cheese to his bowl and he LOVED it.

I definitely think Nojo is on par with Santouka in San Jose (don't like Orenchi) and Ippudo in NY (almost). And I would rather go here than Daikokuya in LA (the tasteless noodles ruin the bowl)!

While you wait, there's a cafe next door. Grab a beer and sit outside so you can check on your status periodically.
author: Lisa N.

description: This is probably my favorite chicken ramen restaurant. The soup is thick but not cream. The real chick leg is another surprise compared to other sliced chicken breast.
author: Nan J.

description:
Nojo blew me away. 

Having never tried chicken ramen before, I was expecting the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen broth to be thin and bland, but it was actually incredibly flavorful and delicious. It's priced a little high at just a little short of $20 for the bowl, but I suspect it's the star of the menu, and if you're already waiting anyway (which you are--this place is tiny and popular), you might as well order it. I also tried the chicken nanban, and while you hardly need more food, it is totally worth pushing yourself over the edge into a full-fledged food coma. 

In short, my very favorite bowl of ramen in the city: unique, tasty, and worth the wait.
author: Kelly R.

description: I had a fantastic time here. The food was good and the company was good. However this was all ruined when this Asian girl employee came back and pressured me to increase my tip. Never coming here again just for that.
author: Serena C.

description:
We (2 people) waited for 15 min for a Sunday lunch. Unfortunately they forgot to give us menu after seating us, but the service and food afterwards made up for it.

The spicy miso ramen was delicious and I think the portion is bigger than other ramen places? So maybe that justified why the bowl is more expensive here.
author: Novalina N.

description: I've been here a few times and can never get enough of their ramen options. The ramen here is so rich with flavor. The wait can get long, but they have upgraded to an iPad waitlist so it's pretty efficient. Sometimes Ramen can get pretty heavy, but there are alternative options - such as no butter or veggie - that lightens the heaviness a little bit, but doesn't relent on taste. They used to have a kale beer here that was actually very delicious, but the last couple times I went they no longer have it...otherwise this would be 5 stars if they brought it back!
author: Annie M.

description:
Oh boy! What good ramen!

Famished after a late evening yoga class, my friend and I were looking for any place to have dinner when we found Nojo on Yelp. Being non-pork eaters, we were super disappointed when we walked into the store and read that they were out of the vegetarian broth. We were just deciding if we should walk out, when LO and BEHOLD!, we realized that their ramen has chicken broth.

Sitting in a quasi-mordern setting by a window, we shared a 3 course meal picking a Teriyaki Chicken Bun, the Tan-Tan spicy Miso Ramen and finishing it off with the green tea creme brulee for dessert. We added a soft-boiled egg to our Ramen. Everything was just so so good; I was so sad when the meal got over. Easily one of the best meals of my life.

Will go back, several times! The only caveat being that it is quite pricey; it did work out for us since we shared the meal, but if we had bigger appetites, it would become expensive very quickly.
author: Divya S.

description: Amazing chicken + bonito broth. The wait is a bit long (45min and up) but we sorta knew it so we didn't get there hungry. The dry noodle is on a spicy side but very tasty. Minus 1 star from their off-sequence food as we got our main courses before appetizer and we had to wait for it after all the food was eaten. Obviously communication between floor and kitchen needs some improvement but overall, decent dinner that left us want to come back for more.
author: Craig W.

description:
Photogenic ramen and photogenic ambiance, like real-life Pinterest. Sounds about right for SF. 

Nojo specializes in tori paitan, a hearty chicken-based ramen broth that's the new trend most well-known at the legendary Mensho and now also served at Hinodeya in Japantown. There was some disapproval over Nojo being brought by a Japanese restaurant group, but their ramen is SO GOOD. Especially in SF which is perpetual ramen weather.

We all got the signature CHICKEN PAITAN SOY SAUCE. $18.5 is a hefty price tag, but it was heavenly.
- The TORI PAITAN was rich and creamy, full-bodied yet not as heavy as tonkotsu. The combination of chicken and soy sauce created a distinct umami taste infused with subtle smokiness from the black garlic oil, in addition to a layer of dashi-like overtones from the fish powder. The ample scallion toppings added a floral and nutty dimension. I was also impressed by how they got the temperature just right, with a comforting degree of warmth, neither scalding hot nor a lackluster lukewarm. 
- The BRAISED WHOLE CHICKEN LEG is hearty, meaty, and a luscious fall-off-the-bone; the avian counterpart of badass slow-braised pork belly (minus the fat!) Besides the melty texture, the thorough soy marinade imparted great flavor. I would have liked more of a crisp on the skin, like the fried chicken leg at Hanabi on the Peninsula. At the end of the day, I still can't get over how much meat you get with this walloping chicken leg, when the rest of the ramen world pretentiously doles out paper-thin slices of chashu (or the baby chicken wing at Hinodeya)
- Expect no less than perfectly soft-boiled yolk for the DASHI EGG. Although I cannot claim to detect the nuanced dashi, it was delicious and even more spectacular when devoured with a spoonful of the savory tori paitan.
- The flair of FRIED GOBO fostered the excitement you get from fried toppings (like fried onion), except the slightly chewy texture was interestingly reminiscent of vegetable root chips. Delicious and unique.
- I think the NOODLES were the only component in my ramen without a wow factor, but that could just be my personal noodle preferences because my friends liked it. In my opinion, the noodles were not al dente enough, and they used thick egg noodles that tasted a bit too much like chow mein.

We also shared the GREEN TEA CREME BRULEE ($7). It was like a soft panna cotta with a crispy caramelized coating, with very good green tea flavor. It's a bit pricey given the portion size, but a memorable and excellent ending to the meal.

The space is predominantly wood, in a corner surrounded by large windows. The metal stools and chairs have these weird suction things on the legs that make it difficult to lift, but I guess it's a safety measure? 

While the wait isn't as crazy as Mensho and the place isn't tiny, I suggest getting here before 6pm because it fills up quickly.

Overall, Nojo was outstanding in its mastery of chicken-based ramen. You feel slightly healthier compared to fatty tonkotsu and fatty pork belly. 

I'm also enticed by the chicken paitan ft. meatballs and soboro tossed noodles ft. a raw egg, but mainly only because it looks so beautiful. I'm too satisfied with my chicken leg ramen.
author: Edna C.

description:
Today was my first time at Nojo and I don't regret a thing! I went with my friend to catch up with her. She ordered the Chicken Paitan Ramen and I ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce. The Chicken Paitan came with meatballs while the one with soy sauce came with chicken leg. The Chicken Paitan soup tasted delicious and so did the one with soy sauce (it was on the saltier side probably because of the soy sauce). Chicken Paitain Soy Sauce also came with a lot of chopped green onions and dashi egg (my fav. kind of boiled egg in ramen!). 

Nojo also has a really modern and hipster style environment that we really enjoyed. There was natural lighting from the windows so we could take nice pictures of the delicious food! 

Overall, this place has great ramen! A little bit pricier than others but so worth it!
author: Jessica C.

description:
As a lover of ramen, I was disappointed with my meal. I was initially intrigued with tomato and parmesan in a ramen dish, and decided to get it - why not. It simply did not work, first of all, if I wanted pasta, I would not be having it at a Japanese restaurant and secondly it's not dish worthy of fusion. While I did like the taste of the broth, the noodles itself was too much like pasta. 

Unfortunately, I have to say I prefer Ramen Underground here in the city or Ippudo in New York.
author: Alex C.

description:
I was craving ramen on a cold
night and I think this has been one of
the best tori paitan I ve ever had! I tried the Shoyu tori paitan with the whole
braised chicken leg, entirely emptied my bowl ! Amazingly tender and flavorful chicken, rich broth, plenty of chives and the  gobo chips were delicious as well. We also got the chicken nanban and the yuzu miso cucumber, everything was very good! 
The only negative point is that we had to wait over an hour to get seated
but felt really rushed. Servers were eager to take plates out and bill was dropped when we had asked to see the dessert menu. 
Will definitely come back on a less busy night!
author: Sarah B.

description:
2.5 STARS

There's always going to be that guy or that girl. 

I'm going to be that girl - the black sheep. Seeing as how I'm the first one here who didn't care for the ramen at Nojo Ramen Tavern. 

As I feared, my experienced at Nojo Ramen Tavern mirrored my experience when they were previously an izakaya restaurant - mediocre and unjustifiably expensive. An extra $1.50 to add cilantro to your ramen?! WTF, that's like a pizzeria charging customers for red pepper flakes. But, I digress. 

My friend and I went to Nojo on a Sunday which has a limited menu: Small Bites ($4-$12) - Edamame, Yuzu Cucumbers, Takoyaki Fries, Tuna Tartare, and Crab & Avocado Salad, Specialties ($4.50 - $12) - Chicken Nanban, Nikumaki Rice Ball, Teriyaki Bun + Rice Bowl, and Ramen ($15-$18.50) - Chicken Paitan, Paitan Soy Sauce, Paitan Tomato, Paitan Spicy Miso, and Soboro Tossed Noodles. Additional toppings for ramen ($1.50-$7) include a chicken leg, tsukune, cheese, soft boiled egg, onsen egg and can't forget about that $1.50 cilantro. Prices are high and portions are small. Beer, wine, shochu, and sake only. Their beer selection was disappointing - just one Japanese beer available (but a handful of local ones) and it was the standard Sapporo. 

We started with the Nikumaki Rice Ball which was underwhelming and not worth the $4.50 price tag: http://bit.ly/1Lx90Ci. A 2-inch rice cylinder wrapped with a paper thin slice of pork belly and brushed with a sweet soy ginger sauce. It would of tasted much better if the pork belly actually had some texture. 

The next shared app was that Nanban Chicken ($9.50) which was deliciously addicting: http://bit.ly/1QqqmBW! The fried nuggets of chicken (5 pieces) were very moist and flavorful. It was dipped in a soy vinaigrette that lightly softened the crisp exterior while adding a layer of savoryness. Loved the tartare sauce, similar to thousand island dressing with diced eggs. Gimme a bowl of steamed rice and I would have been a happy camper! 

So...Nojo's specialty is ramen, Tori Paitan to be exact which is like the chicken version of tonkotsu. Nojo and Mensho are the only ones in SF (that I know of) that serve Tori Paitan Ramen at $15-$18 a bowl. The difference is Mensho is infinitely superior. Maybe if I hadn't gone to Mensho two days prior, I would have liked Nojo's ramen better?

I wanted to taste the Chicken Paitan ($15) in its unadulterated form so I ordered the plain version without soy sauce, spicy miso or tomato: http://bit.ly/1KuWUih. It was boring and unsatisfying; like something I would eat if I had a cold or recovering from the Hershey squirts. The broth lacked depth and was one-dimensional. The tsukune was fine, fluffy as stated and gingery. Noodles were al-dente and springy. I added a soft-boiled dashi egg (+$1.50) but it was just a plain boiled egg. I prefer a more runny, molten center. 

My friend ordered the Spicy Chicken Soboro Tossed Noodles ($16): http://bit.ly/1Ww65Q7. Upon arrival, the soboro looked fantastic with all the vibrant colors and that raw yolk! However, it was basically Sichuan Tan Tan Mein except at twice the price (didn't see organic or free-range ingredients listed on the menu). My friend ate several bites before giving up. She said, "the spice isn't addicting so you don't want to eat more and more". I took a bite and the spice was so overpowering (I love spicy) that you couldn't taste the different components. 

Service was polite and the staff was friendly. However, some training is needed as one staff took away our share plates while we were still working on one of our apps. 

The minimalist and hip ambiance hasn't changed much from when I went to the former Nojo five years ago. Good for a casual date, solo dining at the counter, or for larger groups (two communal tables). Most of the diners seem to be pre-show goers and those who didn't want to wait 3+ hours at Menso (there's no wait at Nojo when we went). 

Street parking is relatively easy especially on a non-performance night. 

Overall, the food was 3 stars but the prices are just too high. I have no qualms about paying $16-$18 for a bowl of ramen but it has to be worth it; it's not at Nojo. Plus, visiting Mensho beforehand totally ruined it for me as they're just on a w-h-o-l-e other level. It's like living the tech bro life driving a M4 and going back to driving your dad's minivan after the tech bubble bursts.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
First Time !

Group of six loved this place and the food.
I ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce; comes with a whole braised chicken leg over a bed of slightly chewy (yeah!) ramen noodles, veggies, 1/2 egg in a soy sauce broth. It's a big bowl of tasty Asian Persuasion!

We also split a plate of sashimi: Yellow tail comes with minced green onions. It was ok tasting.

Customer service: excellent. My water was always being filled; I felt taken care of. We left a generous tip. Thanks Nojo!

I had an IPA brew, comes in a green labelled can. It tasted bubbly and refreshing.

Decor: cool and modern.

Parking: you might find a spot; there is public parking at Gough/Grove.
author: Bert K.

description: I came here on Sunday for an early dinner with my brother, his wife, and their friend. And they all work at a ramen restaurant and we all agreed Nojo is the best ramen ever! We also ordered the fries and a salad. All delicious but when you come here just stick to what they are known for and order the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen!!! Absolutely amazing!!! My only regret was eating a late brunch before coming here and not finishing my bowl. What a disgrace, I know! But if I knew I was going to eat here I would've skipped a meal before arriving just so I could finish my bowl on my own. Don't worry, my brother helped me with the leftovers.
author: Tere V.

description: If you eat their ramen, you must say "OMG.". It's really crazy! I waited alomost 30 minutes, but It worth..
author: Uijin J.

description:
Hipster ramen shop. 

$15-$18 for ramen? It better be made out of gold...

All ramen is chicken based. The soy sauce with half chicken thigh had the best broth. Spicy and dry ramen we're horrible. Bad flavor, ground chicken with small portions for the price you're paying.... no thanks. 

Gyoza that's freshly made per order so it takes 20 minutes to cook- wish it wasn't soggy...

All in all, save your money. There's a reason they don't have much of a line compared to other ranen shops in the city.
author: Mandi W.

description: Good ramen but they rush you out. Damn, can a girl eat! I went for an early Sunday dinner around 5pm. It wasn't too crowded yet but you could tell a rush was likely coming soon.  I was halfway through my bowl and was asked on several occasions if I was done. Finally I said yes and allowed them to take the bowl away out of frustration. We had only been seated for around 30 minutes total. I would hesitate to go back here simply because of this experience.
author: Makala K.

description: Success brings criticism, but Nojo is worth it.  You need to go right when they open to avoid the long waits.  The spicy ramen is some of the best I've ever had, here or in Japan.  The salads are also remarkable if you can fit them in while you wait for your main course.  The sake selection is also interesting and worthy.  Highly recommend, especially if you go on a night when I'm not trying to get in.
author: Penny L.

description:
Absolutely superb.

The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce here is absolutely bursting with flavor - the addition of an entire chicken leg to the ramen, in addition to some excellent but not overwhelming flavor, makes the entire meal simply jaw-dropping.  The noodles are easily some of the best I've ever had, including but not limited to in Japan.

The poke bowl here is equally good - I'm genuinely surprised a ramen place has such good quality fish!

The only real detriment to this place is the crowd and the fact that you'll likely have to stand in line, which just says a lot about the quality of the food.
author: Kirk S.

description:
Love the food here. 

The spicy Nikumaki rice ball is amazing! Watch your bite though...they are serious about the spicy. 

The tan tan spicy miso was just the right amount of curry ramen. Not too spicy.
author: Yesaswi D.

description: Very Very good ramen. Would say Nojo is definitely the best ramen I've eaten. I always order the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce. Line is also very long but definitely worth waiting. I will always visit Nojo whenever I drop by San Francisco. Recommend to come here and try! Best ramen ever!!
author: Michael C.

description:
Wow i am super impressed with their broth here, have never had such a rich chicken broth. Ordered the spicy tantan-men miso ramen whilst waiting for a show to start at Rickshaw.  This ramen is spicy! Beware u will be sweating. 
The chicken broth seems smoother than tonkotsu, no little floating pieces of fat like with the pork soup.

Noodles - aldente 5 star
Broth - rich and spicy 5 star
Toppings - good!! Could use more meat for price 4 stars
Price - mm 3.5 stars

Conclusion, def worth trying! All chicken broth, but as rich as tonkotsu. Server said it takes 3 days to make their broth.
author: Spencer W.

description: 2.5 stars for me. I think the ramen is great, not mind-blowing. What kills it for me is that the last 2 times I've been the hostess skipped our party, even when we were complete BOTH times, by a lot. One of those times she proceeded to seat me and my 2 over 6'3 friends at a table for 2 against the back wall with no extra chair and sat a party of 2 petite guest who arrived after us at a communal table that was clearly bigger and had 2 extra seats. The petite party and I had to switch ourselves because they clearly agreed that it all did not make sense. I think the brains in the hostesses might be ramen. I would say from the last bad review that you should maybe think about refreshing your staff.
author: Zack V.

description:
Oh, I tried this spot for Sunday brunch about 3-1/2 years ago when Nojo was a more modestly priced izakaya. Coincidentally, I had a $12 bowl of ramen with a thinnish broth and two thick roulade slices of Grilled Confit Chicken but came away somewhat unimpressed. Still with the same name and the same chef, Greg Dunmore, but under different ownership, evidently a Japanese conglomerate,  Nojo is now calling itself a "ramen tavern" (seriously) serving an "artisanal noodle and mall plate concept from Japan". Uh OK. Well, on a Thursday evening around 6PM. it was bustling mostly with young, hip Asians slurping with abandon.

Even though groups were waiting for tables, I got lucky and scored a counter seat. The menu does indeed focus on ramen but also offers some salads, seafood and sides including small plates that focus on umami flavors. I decided first to try the $5 Teriyaki Chicken Bun because frankly it was the cheapest food item on the menu. It was pretty good with plenty of poultry albeit a tad overcooked nestled on lettuce in a steamed bun. It was drizzled liberally with a house tartar sauce that reminded me more of Long John Silver's Fish & Chips (photo: http://bit.ly/20oZi0X). It was a tasty enough bar bite, but it won't keep David Chang up at night.

Much more satisfying was the $8 Soy Milk Cream Cheese Crostini. The faux-cream cheese was whipped into a light frenzy of flavor seasoned with Maddon salt. Dollops of this concoction were placed on four toasted mini-baguette slices, drizzled with maple syrup, and sprinkled with pumpkin seeds and almonds (photo: http://bit.ly/1o53GRx). Those were genuinely heavenly bites, so much so I couldn't believe it was soy based. I think I should have ordered more. The main event came next, the $18.50 bowl of Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen. The paitan broth was an intentional substitute for my favorite, pork tonkotsu, and I liked it. The richness was definitely there as it was blended with blackened garlic oil and obviously soy sauce.

A slow-braised chicken leg was the centerpiece instead of my usual pork belly, and it was accessorized with thick al dente noodles (they had excellent consistency, not chewy), a dashi egg, red onion, scallions, fish powder, nira (garlic chives) and fried gobo (burdock roots) (photo: http://bit.ly/1TCvZCK). It was genuinely delicious, but the portion struck me as skimpy for the exorbitant price. Something sweet was in order to end the meal, and I had a Japanese bit of a trifle, the $5 Monaka Ice Cream Sandwich with Matchadoodle-flavored ice cream, Humphry Slocombe no less (photo: http://bit.ly/1UIQ1tF). Tasty and gone in about three aggressive bites. I shall return...with my credit card.

FOOD - 4 stars...superb tasting paitan and creative crostini, just a bit pricier than I was expecting
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...still feels like the old Nojo, very modern and a bit loud
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...a bit rushed though everyone was still getting into their rhythms since they are still in soft opening
TOTAL - 4 stars...a definite improvement over the other Nojo
author: Ed U.

description: Ramen tastes just fine, however, it took us half an hour waiting in the line. Service was not very good. The waitress came over to ask us if done at least three times during our 30 minutes eating time! It's obvious that we were still working on it but they just wanted us to finish quickly so they can serve more groups! Besides, the price is surprisingly high. Hard to imagine how's $20 ramen like before but now I know. Would never go again
author: 雨薇

description: The food here is actually pretty delicious. I typically go for a more classic tonkotsu ramen, but this place specializes in chicken. As many have mentioned, I got the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce.  I was pleasantly surprised about how good the broth is and the chicken leg was "fall off the bone", so you can just pick at it with chopsticks.  The Fort Point IPA was on-point as well. The service was good, and the fact that I could get onto their long waiting list via the Yelp app as I made the commute over to the restaurant pushed my rating to a 5!
author: Mai O.

description:
Ramen is good and flavorful, definitely on the salty side. The decor of the place is great, wooden tables, interesting forks/spoons, fancy lightbulbs & nice ambient lighting. 

Here is where it went wrong. We went on a strangely hot Wednesday evening (75 degrees at 7pm), so not supposed to be super busy right? Well, the line in front seemed shorter than usual. After seeing 10 people leave, I put my name down for a party of 2 around 7:30, with 5 parties of 2 in front of me. We stood outside waiting, and 3 parties of 4 who all arrived half an hour after us were seated before us. You're telling me you prioritize walk-ins groups of 4's more than smaller parties?! what... Even with communal seating??

So from the time I put my name down to sitting down to even get a glass of water, about a whole hour has passed. Waitress who seated us didn't say "thanks for waiting" just assumed they're so popular people would just wait hours. After we were seated, nobody paid attention to us (no water no nothing) for another 10 minutes. 

We won't be back. This is just so typical SF, in the worst way possible.
author: Mingmei N.

description:
*** In Short ***

No Mensho, but with shorter waits and more extensive menus.

*** In Depth ***

I had the lofty goal of visiting five new ramen joints in a single week, several months ago. Alas, I only managed to make it through three of my list, missing Mensho and Nojo. But, having finally tried Mensho several weeks back, I knew I had to try Nojo soon after, to properly compare their toripaitan ramen dishes. Coming along with another ramen-loving friend, we ate:

* Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso - With a rich broth that wasn't too salty, and had good flavor and springy noodles, their spicy miso ramen was a pretty solid choice. While not at the level of Mensho's dazzling flavors, still quite enjoyable.

* Chicken Paitan - The more direct comparison to Mensho's toripaitan, this also came with a rich, creamy broth, albeit one that's much lighter than that of Mensho's, for better or worse. I myself prefer the richer one at Mensho, while my friend found Nojo's to be more easily drinkable.

* Pork Onigiri - I've found onigiri to be pretty disappointing up here in SF, and while Nojo's version of it is simultaneously fancier and simpler than onigiri I've had before, it was the best I've had up this way, with great flavor and satisfying crunchiness.

* Chicken Bun - Not bad, but by far the least noteworthy item among everything we had, mostly because it was sweeter than I expected or enjoyed.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Another large venue with plenty of seating, many accessible, and some less so.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description: This place has the most delicious and flavoursome vegetarian ramen. When we went the first time and waited for 1.5 hours and when we got our table they had sold out of vegetarian ramen. The next time we went they specifically kept our vegetarian ramens which was the best I have ever had. Their service is incredible and even when the vegetarian ramen was sold out they accommodated us to everything else available. Can't wait to go back! Highly recommended.
author: Ruchi M.

description: This place is absolutely delicious. Always a wait (because it's so good), but worth it. You can sit in their little lobby with a drink, or cruise the neighborhood in the meantime. Chicken based, instead of pork, which I think is a nice switch up. The chicken falls off the bone, broth is incredible, and the noodles are legit. This is nowhere near a Top Ramen knockoff (like many restaurants in the city replicate- gross!). You will truly be transported to a very warm and happy place eating a bowl of ramen from Nojo, and if you're anything like me, you'll finish the entire bowl. :)
author: Olivia G.

description:
One of the top ramen places in the Bay Area by far. Also, Nojo is one of the most expensive places ever. You're literally paying $18.50 for a bowl of a ramen with a chicken leg.

I tried the chicken-flavored broth based on the waiter's suggestion and let's just say, it was a pretty damn good recommendation. Get it. It's the Chicken Paitan Soy Ramen.

Temperature? Very hot. 
Portion? Average, but filling.
Noodles? Deliciously chewy and cooked well.
Chicken? Very tender and juicy. The chicken was so tender that the meat fell off the bone.
Restaurant? Super clean and classy.
Waiter? Attentive and super-friendly.

Overall, this restaurant was really good and I would not hesitate to recommend this place to anyone interested in trying out a new, trendy, but delicious ramen place!
author: Chinsin S.

description:
Came here to check out what the rave was all about for Nojo! I know the reviews are everywhere, but since I love ramen, I thought it was worth giving a try if there was a good chance it was going to be delicious! 

And I'm glad I did!

The girlfriend and I came here, so it was just a party of two on a weekday night at around 9 PM. The wait wasn't too long for us -- about 10 minutes. This place isn't massive, so I can imagine the wait being long if you're with a large group or if it's prime lunch or dinner time.

There are a lot of things on their menu, but we weren't terribly hungry, so we went straight for what we came in for: the ramen. 

What I like about this place is that they want to take the allure and the flavors of pork-based ramen (i.e. tonkotsu broth), but make that happen with chicken-based ramen. At first, I was a little skeptical. I was thinking it would taste more like chicken soup and be very light. 

I was so wrong. 

The girlfriend got the Chicken Paitan ramen, which is pretty light, and I ended up getting the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen (which was also the priciest ramen on the menu at around $18).

I wasn't a huge fan of the regular Chicken Paitan ramen, which did have good flavors, but seemed like it was missing some extra toppings to be worth coming back for. (If you don't eat pork but always wanted to have ramen, I'm sure any of these would be delicious.) 

The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen though. Let's talk about that.

Imagine your traditional ramen noodles and instead of thick pork-based tonkotsu broth, you have equally thick chicken broth (it's almost half gravy to be honest). Then topped on top of the noodles and the broth is a slow braised whole chicken leg, blackened garlic oil, nira chives, red and green onions, dashi egg, fish powder, and fried gobo. Are you drooling yet?

If not, I've attached a photo to help your salivation get going. 

Having tried both the regular Chicken Paitan and the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce, I will hands-down recommend the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce if you are a fan of flavorful dishes. 

Questions?

Would I recommend this place to friends (who likes ramen)? Yes.
Would I come back for this ramen? Yes. 
Was the 1 ramen alone worth the $19+tax+fee+gratituity? No.
Would I drive 20+ miles for this ramen again? No, not unless I was with someone who didn't eat pork. (I love pork too much.)

For chicken ramen in San Francisco (one of the most expensive cities for cost of living), I'm going to say this is probably about as good as it gets!

Now..back to my other favorite ramen places, where I can order tonkotsu flavored ramen topped with pork belly upon pork belly...
author: Mitty C.

description: Absolutely the BEST!!! Great ramen!!! Chicken buns are SO GOOD!!! Service is always delightful!!! Highly recommend if you're in the neighborhood-- expect a wait!
author: Ginny W.

description:
What an AWESOME bowl of Chicken Paitan Ramen! The portion size is great, so you don't even need to order any of their appetizers and you will be in food coma after. Trust me! Save your tummy for the delicious ramen and broth! I have been to many many ramen places in the Bay Area (i.e., Orenchi, Dojo, Parlor, etc.) and Nojo is now one of my new favorites! Even better that it's in SF, more close to home.

My friends and I all ordered their Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen. It comes with a whole leg of slow braised chicken.. a WHOLE leg! The chicken leg is so tender that the meat falls off the bone. They char the chicken skin so it's nice and crispy while the meat is super soft. When you taste your first sip of the paitan soup, the deep, densely-packed chicken flavor will hit your taste buds almost immediately. It was more like BAM! Have you ever had that moment where the food is so good, you uncontrollably say "Wow it's sooo good" multiple times? Well that happened to us while we were savoring our first bites. The soup is very rich and thick, almost like chicken gravy, while not being overly salty (in the beginning). The soft-boiled egg is perfectly cooked, but the chicken broth and the perfectly cooked thick al dente ramen noodles are the highlights of this perfect bowl of ramen. However, the soup does get a little too salty once you hit the half-way mark of the bowl, so ask for more water. 

While the price tag of this delicious ramen is a bit steep at $18.50, I definitely think it's well worth the price and the wait. This place is packed even on a Wednesday/Thursday night, so do come ahead of time and put your name onto the list! We waited for almost an hour on a Thursday night, but my ramen tummy left the place very happy.
author: Hoyan L.

description: This place is perfect for lunch on a Sunday. I ordered the torigan (it's like Japanese curry bruschetta), soy ramen with extra meatballs and the black sesame ice cream sandwich. The ramen was just fantastic and full of flavor - the ramen alone can definitely fill you up. The dessert was just perfect size to cut out the savory flavor.  Service was good and attentive but they do get very busy.  I recommend going close to open time to avoid the crowd.
author: Andrew S.

description: Looks good but nothing special about the ramen. It was expensive and the line was super long.
author: Y W.

description: This place is by far my favorite chicken ramen place. I don't eat pork, and most ramen places use pork broth, but I love ramen. Nojo's dishes are amazing and use only chicken broth. I ordered the spicy ramen and it was so so good. My friend got the one with the full chicken leg in it and it had a different taste, more traditional, and I really enjoyed that too. I recommend both. I can't wait to go back this weekend!
author: Camille d.

description: Yummy, nice place, can be a long wait, but they've got community tables. Be sure to ask for the right spice level when ordering, can be spicy!
author: Lola D.

description:
Very delicious ramen restaurant. As a vegetarian, the veggie ramen dish was extremely flavorful! I thought it was more on the salty side but it was still yummy. I will definitely be back for more. 

The ambiance was really nice and had great service. We were seated within 30 minutes and food was at our table shortly after ordering. We also got the green tea creme brûlée which was okay, tasted more grainy than smooth. 

It's a nice place to come for dinner/date.
author: Jhankhana J.

description: Chicken paitan ramen: was good, tasty, and reminded me so so much of Chinese food, must be the soy sauce base. The soup was tasty and smooth. I liked that. I liked that the meat off the chicken bone fell right off, soft and infused well with the sauces they cooked it in. The dish is well prepared and cooked to perfection.
author: Mimi T.

description:
As a party of 2, we arrived around 7:10 on a Thursday and we're seated by 7:30. Score!

The service was busy, but friendly. The food was overall interesting, but pricey and rich. We had the chicken naban which is fried chicken with a glaze and a tartar sauce. Drenching the chicken in both sauces seemed like overkill and also made the fried chicken chewy rather than crispy. The cream / tartar sauce was interesting with some egg whites, onions and not sure what else that added interesting texture.

Their chicken paitan soy ramen was killer. I was expecting the taste of chicken soup to come on strong, but it was rich and flavorful without being too chickeny. The chicken bones literally come right out when you pull on them. The skin has an amazing rich flavor. The fried burdock chips were crunchy and amazing at first, but much more underwhelming once it got soaked and soggy in the noodle.  The first 10-15 bites of the noodle were amazing, but after that, I became overwhelmed by the heaviness of the dish.  The spice bomb helps to cut it. 

If there were good, lighter alternatives, I'd come back!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Nojo ramen is truly the best! The soup is delicious and not too salty, definitly warms the soul. I got the ramen with tomato based soup and it was bomb. 

Their poke bowl is great too, it comes with only tuna and salmon but no substitutions allowed. 

This place is Zagat rested and priced fairly.
author: Ming Y.

description: Amazing noodles. I didn't get the ramen but got the spicy tossed chicken noodles with a poached egg and it was actually spicy and soo flavorful. Would definitely come back and order the same thing again. Come early to avoid waits!!
author: Kaitna S.

description:
First time here and I went around dinner time so there was a line. You do have to put your name down on a waiting list. Customer service was fast and attentive. The ambience was nice.

I got the fries to share and a bowl of Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso ramen. The fries were delicious. The broth was very rich and flavorful. It was definitely more on the thicker side. It wasn't as spicy as I thought. The broth was just too salty for me that I found myself drinking a lot of water. Overall, the portion was good cause I was full. Or maybe it was all the water that I drank? Who knows...

I would come back to try other dish though before I give that one a chance again.

But don't just take my word for it, give it a chance.
author: Tu N.

description:
Open kitchen,  "intimate" (aka squished ) seating, and long wait are just some of the things you should expect when coming here. Came here for dinner before a show and waited around an hour for a "table" for two. We sat at a communal table with 4 other people. No biggie,  just expect to not have much of a choice where you are seated since the restaurant is a bit small and cramped.

We shared the Chicken Nanban (chicken fritters) and the peices of chicken breast were surprisingly juicy  since it can be easy to overcook.

I was not as impressed with the  $18.50 bowl of Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen. Yes, you get a whole chicken leg, which makes for nice pictures, but there was nothing impressive about the texture or flavor of the soy sauce  chicken.  I also didn't feel like the fried gobo was necessary or added much to the dish. However, my biggest disappointment was in the broth. They specifically say that they specialize in a chicken broth, not a pork tonkotsu broth. I have had very rich and heavy broths with my ramen in the past. While they were fatty, I still felt like there was a nice balance. However, the broth tasted fatty for the sake of being fatty and left my friend and I feeling quite uncomfortably bloated afterwards. 

Overall, I don't think I would come back here unless I was in a pinch or a REALLY good friend wanted to go and #DoItForTheGram.
author: Gloria S.

description: good taste and awesome cooked chicken leg. But not that good for someone wants a light meal
author: Xinyao Q.

description:
TLDR: Ridiculous wait (more than an hour), understaffed, food was overpriced and underwhelming. However, if you like novel fusion food, then MAYBE you'll like this?

Chicken Paitan Tomato: 4/5 in the beginning 2/5 after the cheese melted into the broth
At first it was really good because the tomato broth was very novel and interesting, and the chicken was refreshing (possibly because the broth was salty). However, the cheese soon melted, and at first it was good, but soon it was like eating lasagna soup.

Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing?
author: Sao B.

description:
I have been wanting to try Nojo for a while, and I thought this was an excellent ramen restaurant.  My friend and I came on a weeknight, and I was worried that it would be a wait given its proximity to several entertainment venues.  I was told that 5-6 PM is a good time to visit if you are not looking to wait a while.  Our dinner started around 6 PM, ,and while Nojo was already bustling, it did not take us too long to be seated.  

We shared two small plates: the yuzu miso cucumber and the nori avocado.  I found the cucumber to be quite refreshing, and the nori avocado expertly combined seaweed paste, horseradish, and a smattering of seaweed shreds.  I ended up choosing the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen, and I could understand why it is one of their top sellers! The chicken was tender, and the broth was superbly complex and chock full of umami flavor.  I will have to visit again to try the rest of the menu, but for now, I can safely say this place was fantastic!
author: Keith H.

description: The best and excellent ramen I ever had in Bay area, even better than Japantown.  It's worth to wait and worth with that cost
author: Hanns C.

description:
Came here with a friend and loved their ramen! We arrived around 7:00pm on a Thursday night and waited about 15-20 minutes to be seated -- they have both table and bar seating inside.

I got their Chicken Paitan Ramen, and it was delicious. The soup base was thick and flavorful, and the noodles were cooked perfectly, not too soggy.

Prices here are definitely on the higher side. The Chicken Paitan Ramen is $18 base, so with tax and tip, I paid almost $25 for just a bowl of ramen...

All in all, a really enjoyable ramen experience!
author: Jackie Y.

description:
Dinner review. 

Hand crafted gyoza - 4/5 - Good sauce
Chicken nanban fritters - 2/5
Nikumaki rice ball (pork belly) with cheese - 3/5
Chicken Paitan Tantan spicy miso - 3/5
Chicken Paitan soy sauce - 3/5
Noodles - 5/5
Egg - 2/5
Chicken legs- 4/5
Other toppings - 4/5

Overall, " I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
Delicious. Went before SF Symphony, perfect because it was just around the corner. It's definitely fancier than most ramen joint and you pay premium here. $18 for a bowl of ramen is high for me, but it was so good. I could not believe the rich broth was chicken based. 
Service was friendly and attentive.
author: Mom P.

description:
