A bit different from other ramen joints. They have a tomato-based ramen that sounded interesting and looked pretty good. I tried the Chicken Paitan. For me, it was too rich and thick. I'm sure it's supposed to be like this but I just found it difficult to eat after a few bites and a tad salty. Definitely has that umami flavor though. 
Price is very high - even for SF - at $17 to $18 a bowl. (what!) 
For 4 bowls and two appetizers, it was $101. Not sure if I would return.
author: Zara H.

description: SO YUMMY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! My go to ramen spot!!!!!!!!! I came here with a group of 4 on Sunday ~1pm and we got seated about 30 minutes later. I got the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen, and I loveddddddd it. The big chicken leg on top of my ramen was easy to eat because it was sooooooo soft and yummy. I loved everything about the ramen--the soft boiled egg, noodles, and thick broth!! The portions were generous, and my friends and I were all very full after our meal. Friendly staff. Pricey ($16-18 for bowl of ramen) but I'm definitely coming back!!
author: Annie S.

description: No extra noodles? Really?  I have eaten ramen all of the world and never ever have I been to a place that doesn't serve extra noodles.
author: zach c.

description: I never had Paitan ramen before, and now I'll be searching it out. The spicy ramen was rich and so savory, with wonderful chewy noodles and a perfect soft-cooked egg. Nori avocado and chicken wing starters were great too. The wait was LONG, about an hour, but understandable. These people are experts!
author: Madame W.

description: Best SF ramen restaurant ever! You know it's good when there is a line before 5 pm. This restaurant has awesome service and you won't be disappointed with their superb flavors! Their potstickers are a hit, and the chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso ramen is out of this world.
author: Jewel Y.

description: Love this place! The ramen is delicious. Thick noodles, tasty broth and the service is quick and efficient.
author: Shalini C.

description:
I've been here a number of times now, and the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen is definitely what keeps me coming back!

The broth is packed with flavor without it being too salty, which is awesome. The chicken leg in the soup is cooked perfectly, the meat just falls off the bone.

Besides that, I like their Chicken Nanban here. It's fried pieces of chicken topped with tartar sauce accompanied by a small salad. I prefer the spicy version, which has a nice kick to it.

I've also tried the takoyaki fries and crab avocado salad. The takoyaki fries were decent, but lacked flavor. I enjoyed the crab avocado salad, but the portion is really small. And they only gave two small pieces of crostini with it.

The servers here are really friendly and attentive. They always greet you with a smile on your face.

I would give this place five stars, but I think it's pretty pricey for what you get.
author: Derek T.

description:
The idea of chicken ramen never sounded that appealing to me, the pork lover. Nojo Ramen Tavern exceeded my expectations and made me a convert.

We arrived at 6:40pm on a chilly Friday evening and waited about 30 minutes to get seated. By the time we were seated at the counter, we were starving. The two of us shared Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen, Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso Ramen, Teriyaki Chicken Bun, and Chicken Nanban. Everything was absolutely delicious.

I liked the Spicy Miso Ramen much more than the Soy Sauce Ramen but keep in mind that Spicy Miso comes with ground chicken and no egg while Sauce Sauce ramen comes with a whole chicken leg and dashi egg. The chicken leg was tender and delicious; however, it's a non-essential for me. I was just as happy with the ground chicken. It was disappointing that the Spicy Miso ramen did not come with dashi egg but I suppose I can always add it for $1.50. And what is $1.50 when the bowl of noodles is already $17?

The Teriyaki Chicken Bun was excellent as well and I really enjoyed the tartar sauce that came with the Chicken Nanban. Nojo is a definite winner!
author: Yi Z.

description: Pretty decent, but nothing special. I tried the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen with an extra dashi egg. The egg was great, but the ramen was fine and kind of forgettable. I also had the poke bowl, which was okay, but a pretty small portion and probably not enough for a full meal.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
A chill spot for ramen if you don't have time to wait for Mensho. I don't believe Nojo is comparable to Mensho despite the tori paitan being the main broth here as well -- Mensho's broth, noodles, and toppings are on a different league from the rest of San Francisco's ramen shops entirely. 

Nojo is GREAT for appetizers. The corn, chicken/egg salad, and rice ball are all worth ordering. 

As for ramen, the tori paitan soy sauce is the most popular item. It comes with a slow braised chicken leg (delicious). I recommend getting a side of spice bomb for those who like spicy broth, otherwise the miso tantan is good as well--I just prefer the paitan broths here.

Noodles are similar to what you might have at Izakaya Goku or Orenchi. Thicker, but less chewy than Mensho.
author: Kathy Z.

description: Probably the best ramen I have had in a long time. Highly recommended and worth the wait! Grab a drink while you wait to be seated and come hungry :-)
author: Shirley B.

description: Still super good!! Pro-tip, parties of 2 tend to go quite quickly (faster than their recommended time). Don't recommend big groups here since the wait could be excruciating!!
author: Rahul H.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night and the wait was about an hour.  I don't like waiting for ramen and it wasn't clear how the hostess was seating everyone so that was definitely annoying!

In any case, I ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce - it was yummy and the chicken fell off the bone!  I think perhaps though it was a bit too salty as I woke up the next morning feeling super dehydrated.  My friend ordered the chicken paitan which she said was pretty good.

We also started with the teriyaki chicken bun and finished with the monaka ice cream sandwich with coffee flavored ice cream.  We also shared sake (the only unfiltered one they had on the menu).

Overall a pretty good meal but not worth an hour wait so would only come back to eat right at 5pm or at 10pm on a weeknight.
author: Siv L.

description:
At most ramen joints, the chicken-based broth is usually the least flavorful, IMHO. Not at Nojo, where all they do is chicken broth, and they do it well. 

You can't go wrong with the chicken paitan soy sauce, which comes with a fall-off-the-bone tender, slow-braised whole chicken leg, blackened garlic oil, nira, dashi egg, red onion, scallion, fish powder and fried gobo. It was my favorite by far.

The spicy miso ramen is also a home run. It's a lot of spice for one bowl so if that's not your thing, look elsewhere. We added a dashi egg and bamboo shoots.

As an appetizer, the teriyaki chicken bun with housemade tartar sauce was also delicious. Good service and a nice atmosphere.
author: Elena K.

description:
I came here on a Friday night at around 8:30 pm and there was a huge crowd outside. I put my BFF and I on the list and there was about 15 parties ahead of us! We waited around an hour to finally be called. There were a lot of people who didn't wait because towards the end the names went pretty fast. 

For appetizer we went for the Nojo Takoyaki fries. The fries were kind of bland no salt or pepper on it. They could of used more sauce on the fries. Overall will not order that again.

For the main entree, we both ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen that comes with the chicken . The broth was very savory, thick and just the right amount of spices. I almost drank all of the soup! Probably one of the best ramen I have had...but this might change when I go try Mensho ramen! I would like to come back and try the miso and other ramen broths they have next time.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Solid ramen in a cool spot. I probably wouldn't wait for more than 20min to be seated but luckily I came alone and was able to sit immediately. I've had chicken-based broth in Tokyo which was significantly more rich and creamy, but Nojo does a good enough job. I recommend ordering the chicken paitan (more rich) and adding a whole chicken leg. 

Food: 3/5
Space: 5/5
Service: 4/5
author: Derrick F.

description:
Came by on a very busy Friday with a group eight. I haven't been since they re-branded and turned this former izakaya location into a ramen parlor. I'm told by a waitress it's part of a huge Japanese restaurant group, but this kitchen is a side project.

Modern decor, very clean with an open kitchen design where you can see the chefs busy about cooking ramen noodles. Friendly staff, running around constantly.

Tried the following:
Corn on the Cob, their Japanese take on the Mexican elote, with cotija cheese. Nothing noteworthy if you're familiar with elote and cotija cheese, it's probably best to slice the kernels down with a sharp knife for serve. 

Nojo "Takoyaki" Fries ($8) - Basically shoestring fries with takoyaki dressing over it and bonito flakes. I was expecting at least a bit of octopus as tradition demands. Quite the disappointment and my fries weren't even piping hot from the fryer. Inner sadness.

Chicken Nanban ($9), for around eight bite sized pieces. Really soggy due to the tartar sauce dressing. Literally a delicious "bite." 

Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso ramen ($17) - Not a fan of the ground up chicken that almost resembled pork. The tan tan style is there, with the broth being a lot thicker than what I was expecting from a chicken base. Definitely spicy, it had a nice pleasant kick throughout and the noodles had the familiar ramen noodle firmness to them.

Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen ($18.5) - Their signature dish, with a whole chicken leg in your soup begging you to devour it, I thought the broth was just right, not too rich. A good take on chicken based ramen broth.

Overall, not too impressed. NYC ramen prices and okay dishes. Rounding in around $34 per bowl of ramen with the additional appetizers, after splitting. 

I didn't have to wait (thanks friends!) but judging by the really long line well into Friday evening, I think I'd be a lot less enthusiastic.
author: Steven C.

description: Get here before 5:25pm and you will be seated immediately! Ramen and Broth were to die for. Recommend the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen
author: Cathia L.

description: Nojo's Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce is the most delicious bowl of ramen I've had in very long time. The broth was flavorful and rich but not to the point where I would have been fatigued by the time I finished. I'm not sure how they can coax that intensity from just chicken. The noodles were perfectly thick and chewy. Fried gobo was a very nice touch. A whole chicken leg was a little unnecessary since the ramen as a whole was so freaking good.
author: Huey N.

description:
Interestingly and refreshingly hearty. Chicken Paitan was good, and the noodles, although not made on site, was perfect to the tooth, and the ingredients fresh to the t. Although I do not typically like eating meat with bones or minimal bones in them because it reminds me of the animal itself, they do have non whole leg options. 

Note to restauranteur - the lacquer on spoons need to be less textured because it interrupts with the flavor of the food, try smooth porcelain/ceramics, minor fix
author: Juls C.

description: Great traditional ramen but also some new experiences as well. Try the tomato ramen! It's unbelievably good - lots of cilantro.
author: C C.

description: Bit of a line but well worth the wait. Chicken Paitan - Hands down best chicken leg piece I've ever had. Juicy, tender, moist and all the other good adjectives.
author: Harsha K.

description:
The company who opened nojo has over 200 restaurants in Asia and I'm so impressed with this new concept they've rebranded in Hayes Valley. They serve small dishes as well as 5 main ramen noodle bowls. 

The chicken paitan soy sauce ramen was DELICIOUS. The chicken leg was soft and the broth was thick and rich. I loved the texture of it all. 

We ordered most of the menu with 8 of us and I loved everything (except for my dry spicy noodle ramen..chicken paitan tomato). 

The takoyaki fries were good. Corn on the cob was good. but the BEST was the teriyaki chicken bun which was DELICIOUS! We ordered 4 to share between 8 of us. I wish i had my own (sorry bf). 

I also loved the chicken nanban. It was so soft and tender. The tartare was tasty with it. 

I'll be back Nojo! I think this is now one of my favorite ramen/small dishes place in SF.
author: Joanna S.

description: Pretentious place. None of the ramen here were a basic miso or shio ramen, benchmark dishes for patrons to gauge the skill of the noodles and broth. All were paitan and the highlight was one with a whole chicken leg. Begs the question: do they have problems sourcing good chashu or that the chef does not have the skill to make it. Broth was tasty but the level of ummami makes one wonder if MSG was used. I'll know a little later if I have an unquenchable thirst tonight. Noodles not well cooked lacking the "mouth feeling" of well cooked noodles. Not coming back.
author: Chris F.

description:
Line can get pretty long -- we went early, so no problems there. 

Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce is the only way to go here. It's really good, the broth is great, restored my faith in chicken paitan. The Soboro (dry noodle) is not as great; the spice flavor overwhelms most of the other flavors. 

Kale beer is interesting, goes well with the hearty ramen. 

However, its pretty overpriced. The appetizers are meh and pricey. The Ramen price isn't too bad compared to other joints around (Mensho) but definitely still high.
author: Jerry L.

description:
Trendy and hip dinner spot w/ chicken centric ramen. 

We tried the takoyaki fries, Nikumaki ball rice and the Paitin ramen. The fries were tummy. Lightly crispy w/ a bold sauce and bonito flakes for flair. The Nikumaki rice ball was interesting. Rice filled but pork belly wrapped that comes w/ a layer of cheese. The Paitin Soy ramen was interesting and the chives added a bit of crunch to the oil laden broth that came off salty. The chicken thigh was delish and the star of the bowl. Heavily season but fall-off-the-bone tender and juicy. The regular Paitin ramen was more mild in flavor but definitely more well rounded and balanced. Only the 1 bowl comes w/ the chick thigh but you can add it a la cart for $7 extra.

They do get busy and no reservations are taken. So come early.
author: Julie L.

description:
This is my 4th visit to Nojo.  The third visit also was my last because the waitress was very rude and inattentive.  I was glad to give Nojo another try since I really like the noodle here plus it is my friend's birthday.  It is our tradition to have noodle on birthday.

This time a very beautiful and kind waitress (Natalia - hopefully I spelt her name right) attended us.  Made our Birthday dinner a wonderful one.  

The noodle is definitely a five star,
I gave Natalia a five star

But I leave my overall review a four star since there is one bad apple in the stuff.  Hope she can find another job she likes better and have a good attitude.  

Wish Nojo all the best!

I'd like to come back more often.
author: Angela Z.

description:
Came here with a friend from out of town and the ramen here is solid! 

I got the chicken paitan for $15 and it was super comforting - almost like a rich creamy chicken noodle soup but with ramen. My friends spicy tan tan ramen ($17) was also super yummy. We sat at the bar and they had a super nice ambience- perfect for catching up with a friend or a date. 

Tough to justify the price point when there are so many great places in SF but their chicken based broth is pretty unique! Worth it if you want to treat yourself or try something new
author: Kristie M.

description: A welcome addition to the Hayes Valley food scene, my wife and I especially like to go here on a rainy concert night at the nearby symphony hall or opera house. The menu is limited, but be assured that everything on that menu is tasty.
author: Al P.

description: Haven't found another ramen spot on SF that rivals that of Japan! Incredible and worth the wait!
author: Jamie D.

description:
I enjoyed the izakaya style menu before they changed it to the ramen tavern concept. The paitan here is very good, light broth but still hearty. I've also tried the paitan soy sauce and paitan spicy miso.  They have good noodles, too; chewy the way I like them. I wasn't impressed with the small plates menu. Nothing too special about them, even the toripan.

So I usually come here to slurp up the ramen and get on my merry way. It's a little more expensive than some ramen places (eg, in Japantown) but it's in a hip neighborhood with hip customers. The secret must have gotten out because there is a line everyday before they open.
author: Ellen S.

description: Really great ramen spot.  The ramen has depth and has layers to it.  Noodles have a bite to them and the toppings compliment the ramen.  Would recommend the basic ramen.  Tried the tomato ramen and was not a fan.
author: Matt B.

description: This is my favorite ramen place in the city.  The noodles are chewy and the broth is flavorful.  We also had the avocado with nori which is surprisingly tasty.
author: J C.

description:
3.5 Stars. 

Was here for their "Soft Opening". So excited for new ramen places in San Francisco. I'm love RAMEN! The services was great. The servers were nice. Even the head chef came over to check up on us. It hurts me to give it 3 stars because I did like my experience. 

I came here with a friend. We were seated right away on a Thursday night. We got lucky, last open table. We started out with a regular rice ball and their made to order gyoza. The gyoza was good, especially with their coconut dipping sauce. That was a good added touch but it was $10 for 4 pieces. Might be the most expensive gyozas I ever had. The rice ball was small but it was tasty.

As for Ramen, I got the spicy tan tan noodles. The broth was amazing, so much flavor. Not too spicy. But I feel like the ramen is missing some important ingredients. Doesn't feel like a complete bowl of ramen. I did add a soft boil egg which makes my ramen $17.5. My friend got the soy sauce ramen. It comes with a big chicken leg and that was really good. Very soft and tender. I normally don't like soy sauce ramen but their broth I actually like, a little heavier than other places. Very tasty. But his was 18.5 and with the add of an whole egg, his was $20. I think its pretty steep for a bowl of ramen. FYI, this ramen comes with a half egg. 

Overall I think its pretty decent but I think its pretty expensive over all. Not one of my favorite ramens in the city but will definitely come back and try the other ramens on their menu.
author: Sandy B.

description: I have not had ramen (even, food) like this before. The most  wonderful combinations of flavors exist in the tomato chicken ramen. Don't forget the spice bomb with your ramen. Vegetarians/vegans should know that the miso ramen almost always sells out by nighttime, so get in early for your fix.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Got the spicy miso ramen ($17 pricey as fuck!) for dinner. The broth is extremely savory and the noodles were bomb! However it is definitely lacking some of the typical toppings that I've been accustomed to: seaweed, egg or even a slice of pork most places tend offer as their standard topping. 

Also, I found a piece (eyebrow?) hair in my noodles and told the waiter, he smiled uncomfortably and immediately apologized for it but I didn't make a big deal or a scene out of it. It was a good thing I wasn't expecting a discount or to have my meal comped because I didn't get any or were offered any either. I got to the restaurant before 5:20 and the only seats that were left available were at the bar. The place got pretty packed after 5:30. Plan accordingly for dinner.

A four star rating means I'm a fan of this place (which I am not, but the noodles and broth were delicious) however it definitely deserves more than a three star.
author: Fanny W.

description: Nojo was a great experience, and definitely a trendy ramen place. They are popping up everywhere! Anyways, I ordered the soy sauce ramen, and was very happy with my order. The onsen eggs are prepared really well too! Definitely order one. I enjoyed my dining experience. I felt that it was slightly overpriced though. It was 17-22 bucks for a bowl of ramen. Seems a little steep. Also be aware of the wait. There is almost always going to be one, so be prepared.
author: Ross S.

description:
I don't usually write reviews but I feel like if I don't voice my opinion, then there will be nothing done. Came here to Nojo expecting to eat the only thing this place is known for, there Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce, and they completely ran out at 8:15 pm on a Friday evening. To me, this is completely unacceptable for a ramen restaurant that charges top dollar for their food. Although, I'm not here to talk down on their food. My goal is just to have the management make sure they don't run out of their signature ramen 3 hours after opening. 
As I'm sitting here disappointedly eating my tan tan ramen, I can see all the disappointed customers walking through the doors only to find out that they are out of the Chicken Paitan.
author: Vincent C.

description:
This is by AP Company, which operates the chain of Tsukada Nojo restaurants (塚田農場) in Japan. In Japan, Nojo has affiliate restaurants that dial down the 塚田 branding and emphasizes the source of ingredients (eg from Miyazaki). You would only realize it's 塚田農場 if you compared menus side by side.

Nojo Ramen Tavern is one of these affiliate restaurants. At $15 for the least expensive bowl of ramen (egg is extra charge) this format probably won't fly in Japan. But it's working really well in SF where people don't mind paying more for decent ramen in a proper restaurant. 

I got the $15 paitan ramen with tsukune (chicken meatballs). The soup was earthy, rich, velvety and has just enough yuzu peel to give some contrast. The tsukune had ginger in them and tasted moist and fluffy as advertised. So I got an extra side of tsukune for $3, which is a good deal. The thick noodles were perfectly al dente. I also ordered the egg, which was underwhelming for two reasons. It was way too cold (fridge cold), lacked flavor and is of a lower quality than is served in Nojo's jidori restaurants in Japan. This is the only reason I don't give the place five stars. Please improve the egg. 

In short, great ramen in a full service restaurant setting.
author: Mark C.

description: Amazing Ramen experience. The wait is long (30-40 min. Around dinner time), so I recommend you use Yelp to put your name on the list. The service is great and the food spectacular.
author: Ana I.

description:
The place is conveniently located near Van Ness MUNI and Civic Center BART, so it should be no issue getting here. I got to the place around 6:00PM on a weekday, and it was already a 30 minute wait. Beware of crowds.

The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce was excellent. Flavorful broth, yummy ingredients, and that chicken leg just melts in your mouth. Tastiest thing on the menu. For dinner, I suggest topping it off with the Green Tea Creme Brûlée. Never had anything like it before, and it didn't disappoint.

I think for what it's worth, this is a great ramen place, but a little too expensive for me to come back regularly. Definitely a place I would hit once in a while.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Always delicious and crowded. Had the Chicken ramen which my husband said was perfect and I had the poke bowl minus the rice with lettuce instead. Other than the 45 minute wait...we ordered, received food and comfortably ate in another 40 mins. We will always be back!
author: Gillian Dawson Y.

description:
This is one of my favorite ramen place in SF. Their soup base is chicken which make them different from others. The basic chicken paitan is really good, and found many had other ramen with chicken leg topping.

The only downside of this place is waiting time. They don't take reservation, and you normally have to wait for more than 40 minutes in line.
author: Sangwhan M.

description:
I'm so heartbroken. And with lots of positive reviews, even worse than heartbroken.

I had high expectations for this place but it was meh. The noodle tasted like pasta, it wasn't the way i imagined how ramen noodle is. It was thick, and aldente, it's not how ramen noodle should be. The soup is okay, but the noodle just turned me off. And the portion, it looks big on the pictures but when you get your bowl and dig in the noodles, it's not much. Makes me miss Japan so much and Ippodo ramen in New York. 

If you're a ramen snob, skip this place and go to ken ken or ramen underground, oh or ramen goku, it's so much better and it's worth your wallet.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: The food is fantastic so we went back a second time. We waited two and a half hours and still weren't seated. We finally left as there were five people ahead of us. We were told the wait was about 45 minutes. The hostess was wrong. She needs be more upfront with the time. The yelp check in should have a time estimate. Something.
author: James P.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Nojo! It's the epitome of Japanese comfort food and has a casual yet trendy vibe. They don't take reservations so the line can get pretty long during prime dining hours (6-8pm). But trust me, Nojo is worth the wait! 

I've been here with my husband for a date night and my boss for a 1:1 dinner and it's been a versatile enough dining location for both situations. 

I recommend ordering about 3 small plates/sides and a ramen bowl each for two people. Here are the highlights: 

1) Chicken Nanban: Deliciously fried chicken with the perfect texture of crispy skin and fatty/soft meat. It's also served with a divine house spicy tartar sauce. 
2) Nijinsky Rice Ball (spicy and with cheese): It's a pork belly wrapped rice ball topped with some yummy spicy cheese. Out of this world guilty indulgence! 
3) Their new special, Spicy Chicken Wings: The skin of the wings is simply bursting with flavor and the meat is fall off the bone delicious. 
4) Chicken Paitan Tan Tan Spicy Miso Ramen: I love the flavor of this ramen! The soup base is creamy and filled with both spices and pieces of ground chicken. The noodles are thick and slightly chewy, just the way I love it. Everything about this ramen screams comfort food. 
5) Sparkling Sake: It's a seasonal sparkling sake option on the menu that has the perfect notes to complement the richness of this cuisine. It was the perfect pairing!

We also tried the Spicy Hamachi with green onion and while it was also delicious and flavorful, my taste buds were more drawn to the more fatty appetizers, the chicken nanban, rice ball and chicken wings. 

The restaurant is tucked into the heart of Hayes Valley and is surrounded by cute bars and coffee shops that you can head to afterwards. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description: Service wasnt great. Our waitress acted like we were bothering her at work...as her customers. *shrugs*
author: J S.

description: Was my first visit, so I ordered the first one on the menu, Chicken something, and tried Spicy Ramen too. I liked the Chicken Ramen much better then the other. Tried my ramen with half boiled egg which was just a great match when it's melt into my soup. Yumm.. However felt too thirsty after the meal.
author: Yeseul S.

description:
Pleasantly surprised! It looks like paitan ramen is coming to SF and Nojo is a nice addition to Hayes Valley. I haven't been to the famous Mensho yet so it's hard for me to judge how good Nojo Ramen Tavern is but I really liked everything I had. 

"Paitan" is "white broth" and it's a lighter, yet still milky cousin of the popular tonkotsu broth. I find tonkotsu to be overwhelming at times so I really enjoyed paitan. The noodles are perfectly al dente and slightly thick as well. 

We got the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen which is richer than the chicken paitan ramen and I really liked the garlic oil and the rich broth. The chicken thigh was cooked well and the onsen egg (addition) was a nice touch. The clear highlight of the meal was spicy chicken nanban, one of the juiciest chicken nanbans I've ever had! I highly recommend this dish. The gyoza is made to order and quite delicious as well.

The interior of Nojo is similar to their previous izakaya restaurant, but with the addition of the open kitchen where you can watch the chefs make the ramen, like a Tokyo ramen shop. The service is also very friendly and personable. The price point for ramen in SF has been ever rising...and Nojo is no exception. Although I hesitate to pay 16+ for ramen, I can't fault Nojo for being the "norm" in this city, especially given their prime location.

I can't wait to try Mensho, but Nojo is a great alternative!
author: Kate M.

description:
Worth the hype. Ramen is all about broth, and Nojo doesn't disappoint - rich and full-flavored. Both the original chicken paitan and the chicken paitan soy sauce were outstanding, the latter being additionally seasoned with blackened garlic oil. Beautifully presented. 

Chicken Paitan: fluffy chicken tsukune meatballs, daikon sprouts, bamboo shoot, scallion, ginger, yuzu. The chicken tsukune indeed was "fluffy" and tasty, while the accoutrement added some lightness. 

Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce: slow braised chicken leg, blackened garlic oil, nira, dashi egg, red onion, scallion, fish powder, fried gobo. A darker, bolder flavor, both with the garlic oil and the chicken leg.

Staff takes pride in their work and menu is brief and straightforward. Group seating available. Highly recommend!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
The restaurant was horribly noisy with some loud ass group of Asian 20-somethings who were probably on their way to the Disclosure show a few blocks away, who started off as a party of 4 but then hoardes and hoardes of their friends started showing up and taking over more and more of their tables without waiting on the waitlist like all of the other customers. Despite the annoyance of that group and the one girl in a red trench coat who was obnoxiously screaming so loudly that the whole restaurant could hear her, we finally got our seats and were greeted by prompt service to order our ramen right away as we were starving... or so we thought.

The ramen took quite a while to come out.. and you could tell that they're horribly understaffed. One more server could make a huge difference, but nope, instead, there is ramen that's sitting out for a while before someone's freed up to take it to a table.

The ramen itself was HEAVY. I mean like, it was so oily and heavy that I can't drink all of the soup.. and that's something that's never happened to me in my entire life. Yes, people in the Bay Area seem to only like fatty, oily broths, but this was done to an extreme. Though the ingredients from the noodles to the duck chicken leg to the yuzu zest in the paitan broth were clearly of high quality, I just couldn't really enjoy the bowl here.
author: Kazu O.

description: The ramen here is top notch! I usually order the same thing (the spicy miso ramen) and it is delicious, I always finish the bowl. Service is friendly and while there is always a wait you can check in online and then grab a drink in Hayes valley while waiting.
author: Laura H.

description:
If I had to choose this place or Mensho, I would actually choose this place! Nojo and Mensho are pretty comparable with prices, but I feel like Nojo packed more flavor and ingredients. I had the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen and blackened garlic oil really made it. The whole braised chicken leg was tender and melted in my mouth. The dashi egg was cooked perfectly. The broth was rich but not overwhelming. 

I heard this place gets busy, but we came at 5 PM on a Wednesday, and it was pretty empty. Better than waiting in line for Mensho for 2 hours. The people are friendly; everyone greets you with a smile and welcomes you hello and goodbye. The staff here seem happy.
author: Denise L.

description: The ramen here is chicken broth based, which is pretty unique. It is pricey though - at least $15 and as much as $19 for an average/small-ish size bowl of ramen. I ordered the chicken/spicy miso ramen, which I thought was just okay - nothing really stood out to make it taste unique, even with the chicken broth base. The service was friendly but slow, felt like we waited a pretty long time for something that took us only about 10-15 minutes to finish.
author: Wayne H.

description:
A real thrill ramen. Can't get enough of it!
The chicken in this raman puts all other chicken I've had to shame. The only thing that competes is Mensho Tokyo.
author: Ofer G.

description:
My favorite tori paitan ramen spot in the city (and there's a lot of competition!) They specialize in all things chicken, so definitely try one of those dishes. 

The tsukune meatball ramen is rich and flavorful - not quite as thick as mensho but that's a good thing IMO - and the meatballs are juicy and tender. The chicken leg ramen is also good but I enjoyed the meatball ramen the best. 

Also must try is the chicken nanban, which is very juicy and crispy. Prices are a bit on the high side, but I always come here when I'm in the area.
author: Ervin T.

description:
Way overpriced for what you are getting. $18.50 for their chicken paitan ramen with soy sauce was not worth it. 

I came here on a Saturday night right when it opened. The place is in a good location in the heart of Hayes Valley. I was worried there would be a wait in line, but a few tables arrived shortly after. I was very excited because I had heard great things about the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen and seen many pictures online.

For two of us, we decided to order the chicken nanban (regular) $9 and each got our own chicken paitan soy sauce ramen. Not a big deal, but as the first customers to arrive and also order, we were slightly disappointed that our ramen came after another customer's order. We got the chicken nanban which came doused in tartar sauce and a small salad. The chicken nanban tasted a bit soggy. When the ramen arrived, it looked delicious. The chicken was super soft and the bone slipped right off. The broth was extremely rich and flavorful but way too salty! I was thirsty for the rest of the night. I thought the chicken was okay but was not impressed.

Food presentation and quality looks nice here, but too expensive for the okay taste. The ramen menu is small, and it is primarily chicken ramen.
author: Christina G.

description:
New spot, get there at 6pm, or you're in for a long wait. Cute space, well-designed. Great service, very friendly and attentive despite the rush. 

We had: 

- Cilantro, Bamboo Shoots & Rayu: was actually a small dish of cilantro, just like it said. but very well seasoned and fully devoured. 

- Nojo "Takoyaki" Fries: thin, crisp fries with a sweet glaze drizzled, and a counterbalanced savory mayo concoction. I think I ate 3/4 because I couldn't get enough. 

- Veggie Miso Ramen (with and without spice bomb): Without the spice bomb, it's (surprise) not spicy at all. It has a strong flavor to it, very thick / rich broth, so I really enjoyed it. The ramen noodle itself was a bit thicker than i was expecting, but I ate this happily and would order it again. My friend had it with the spice bomb and really enjoyed it. I might try that next time, just wanted to start pure.

- Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso: my husband loved it. He tried mine too and said he preferred his. That's about all I know about the dish :)

We'll be back. Might be my favorite ramen spot in the city...
author: Dimple B.

description: Music is bit loud. The food is good. Nice place to try out ramen. Very difficult to carry a conversation.
author: Francis I.

description: Incredible chicken ramen! This is actually the only place I have tried chicken ramen at, and I think it's awesome. Arguably the best ramen I have had. I highly recommend this place. I have only tried one type there, but I will be back to try the others. This place gets very crowded, so be prepared for a possible long wait.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Dinner date with the gf. Came here a little after opening (5:20pm) on a Wednesday evening to avoid traffic and the wait; there was no wait when we got there. Red streets on Google maps during rush hour/dinner means expect to park a couple blocks away. We finished at 6pm and there were still empty tables around & no wait list.  

Restaurant's presentation is nice and classy (wall-height windows, good sunlight, nice tables​, fancy chopsticks).
Staff was friendly and attentive. 
I went with the hype and ordered the $18.50 chicken paitan soy sauce with the braised chicken leg. It was aite. The chicken meat did slide off the bone very easily, but at the same time the flavor was a little plain, moisture a little dry, and tasted slightly overcooked. 

Serving size was typical for ramen--appears small but can be filling; but this bowl was not as satiating as similarly sized bowls from other ramen joints.  
Soup base was rich, but way too salty for my liking.
I think this is the fastest I've finished a bowl of ramen, not because it was that good, but because it was so salty I didnt have the urge to slowly sip all the soup. 

3/5 feel overall.
author: Johnny A.

description: I arrived just after 6 pm on a Sunday evening. There was a waiting list and already 20 patrons waiting for tables. The service is quick and efficient, and I decided to try the Chicken Paitan with soft boiled egg. The broth was delicious and every part of this meal was satisfying. The bowl is so large that even after eating until I eating until I was very full I still was able to leave with a container which will likely be a second meal. I'm already planning a return visit to sample some other menu selections. I will plan to arrive well before closing for optimal seating.
author: Raquelle Z.

description:
Generally one of the best ramen places you can go to in SF. Their Pai Tan Chicken ramen is awesome and they have some great apps too: the tuna tartare is solid and the rice balls with spicy garlic sauce are a MUST.

Last time, however, all three of us got a bad stomach the next day and we weren't happy when the owner/manager blamed it on us not asking our meat to be "well done". We'll be back because we're regulars but expect better service from management when they fall short. Don't blame the customer!

Still 4* for solid food.
author: Farid V.

description: This place is awesome- some of the best ramen I have had (they have slightly Americanized options as well) but why, why are you not open for lunch!?
author: Beata G.

description:
Finally a good ramen place in the city!

I was REALLY disappointed to hear that they had run out of the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen because I wanted to try that chicken leg that people keep raving about. I'll definitely be back for it, but I still ended up loving the meal!

Chicken Paitan Ramen ($15): Ended up ordering this instead, at the server's recommendation. I LOVED the chicken base broth, which was very different from the typical pork broth. It had a very comforting homemade taste to it, like a chicken soup that an Asian mother would cook for their child when sick, except a thousand times more rich, while not being too heavy. The chicken meatballs were good, though not on the same level as the tasty broth. Added a soft-boiled egg for an extra $1.50, and it was perfectly cooked :)

Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso ($17): My boyfriend ordered this, and we both enjoyed it. I don't think the broth was as memorable as the Chicken Paitan, but it was still great. The cilantro gave a really good contrast to the spiciness & richness of the broth!

For the portions, I thought that the ramen was a bit on the pricy side, but the flavors didn't disappoint. Plus the ramen noodles were nicely cooked, not mushy at all (which is a pet peeve of mine)!

Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen, I'll be back for you!
author: Sara L.

description:
Wasn't expecting this place to be super good, but was very pleasantly surprised when I came here last night. I admit, I came here after seeing the horrendous more than 70 person line outside of Mensho before Mensho even opened. I didn't want to wait 3 hrs but already had my heart set on ramen for dinner so I decided to come here. 

Around 5:30pm, no wait and was greeted quickly by a friendly waitress. Chose to sit at the counter so we could witness the chefs at work. We ordered two small plates, two ramen, and a dessert to share.

FOOD/DRINKS/$
CHICKEN paitan ramen: favorite item of the meal, very good noodles (believe me, I have high standards for noodles bc Japan ruined noodles for me), rich (almost creamy, tsukemen-like) broth, meatballs were very juicy yet delicate in flavor, slight hint of shiso/preserved(?) lemon, $15
CHICKEN paitan soy sauce ramen: wanted to try this since so many people said the whole chicken leg is perfect; very good noodles, chicken leg was cooked well but I feel like it was a bit over cooked, tasty garlic oil and lots of green onions which I like, thick broth that is pretty rich but I'm not sure if I could tell if it was a chicken or pork broth. I think it would be better if some vinegar or fish broth was added to it to cut the richness, $18.5
KOMBU/celery salad: very fresh and refreshing, lots of sesame oil flavor, $6
CILANTRObamboo shoots: fresh abs marinated, I enjoyed eating this mixed with the kombu/celery, $6
MATCHADOODLE ice cream sandwich: Humphrey Solocombe ice cream was delicious and the wafers were very cute but super small (only 2 bites) for $5
ICED Green tea: cold served with ice, not much tea flavor, $4
ICED Jasmine tea: cold served with ice, not much tea flavor, $4

AMBIENCE/DECOR
Pretty large space, modern decor, table and counter seating available, very comfortable, somewhat dimly lit, can see chefs at work if you sit at the counter. Unfortunately no hooks for jackets or purses under the counter

STAFF/SERVICE
Friendly and got our orders correct, but a waitress almost brought over a dish that we didn't order. I say almost because she asked us if we ordered it before placing it in front of us. Staff came by a couple times to check on how we were doing which was pretty attentive.

Being a person that is very critical of ramen (japan ruined it for me), this place is pretty good! The type of ramen is not the typical tonkotsu broth and yes, it's pricey, but if you've been to other shops (not going name names) in the city that charges $12-16 per bowl (excluding Mensho since I have yet to try to compare), ramen here is better than those places and you're eating at a nicer restaurant too. Definitely recommend the chicken paitan ramen, please mind that its pretty filling! The small plates I thought were good, but too overpriced for what they were/amount. Don't get the iced teas, get a beer instead!
author: Iris H.

description:
Quite good! 
Not for the ones that generally eat on the bland side. It's packed with flavor and could be considered a tad salty. 

Had the chicken soboro tossed noodles. They don't make the noodles in house but they said from the noodles are from LA. 

Their speciality is their gyozas that's are made a la minute so it takes 20m because they are fresh. For me, it was too gingery but well seasoned. The chicken bun was ok as well. 

They serve ramen that is chicken paitan based. It is on the pricier side ~ $16-18 for a bowl of noodles. But they are rich and flavorful. I tend to eat on the saltier side so this place was good for me. The noodles weren't mushy which was nice. Definitely one of the better ramen places in SF. 

It's in the soft opening stages until next week. They also serve ice cream sandwiches using Humphry Slocombe or green tea creme brulee for dessert.
author: Heejin L.

description:
I've been here several times. For some unknown reason, this is a really popular ramen place. The ramen is not bad to be honest, but I don't see any reason to wait hours to get an over priced ramen. There are many other good ramen place in the city.
The line is ALWAYS really really long. And not recommend for group. We've waited 2 hours to get a table for 6. Totally not worth it.
author: Charlie Y.

description:
Expect at least an hour wait here when coming around dinner time. Luckily, there are a lot of bars and stores to walk to in order to kill time. My friends and I walked to the nearby biergarten (but made sure to walk back around 50 minutes later, since Nojo won't call/text you when your table is ready).

Like everything on the menu, the appetizers are decent but quite pricey for what it is. We shared: (1) Nori Avocado, which we were underwhelmed by its simplicity, and (2) "Takoyaki" fries, which were more unique and filling for the same price as the tiny avocado dish.

But without going into the rabbit hole of the apps, the main star of the restaurant is obviously the ramen. The most popular is definitely the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce. It's the only ramen entree that has a slow braised chicken leg by default.  It was AMAZING.  Because chicken isn't as common of a protein for Japanese ramen, I was expecting a less savory broth.  This, however, was quite opposite.  The broth was thick, rich, and packed with flavors. It literally punched me in the face.  The chicken leg itself was perfectly seasoned. Although, it IS important to note that their ramen heavily leans on the salty side. I was chugging water nonstop after.  Just caution that this is not the kind of ramen that you should drink the broth in its entirety.

All in all, worth the wait (assuming I was feeling patient, already having a good day, and felt like splurging $ on ramen)!
author: Judy C.

description:
The Ramen was really great and flavorful the bamboo in the chicken ramen had a great smokey taste. The chicken fritters unfortunately were pretty bland and soggy. The avocado salad was pretty good and was an interesting combo. 

Come for the ramen and maybe the corn on the cob skip the rest. Probably the best ramen I've had in the city but I've not yet been to ramsho.
author: Justin S.

description: Without a doubt this was a good bowl of ramen, it's also fairly unique that they focus on chicken ramen. I got the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen which included a whole chicken leg. It's definitely the dish to get if you're coming here. The chicken was moist and tender, the flavor had seeped into the meet from the braising, and the soup and noodles were great as well. The real downside here is the $18.50 price tag, which is going to keep me from coming back, especially when there are so many other great ramen places around.
author: Richie Z.

description: Nojo Ramen Tavern is a great place to go if you want a very nice and warm dinner for a cold day. The ramen noodles are awesome, the gyoza is tasty, and people are friendly. Sometimes the wait is long but well worth it. It is the dream come true.
author: Angela L.

description:
One of the better, if not best, ramen places I've been to in sf (take that with a grain of salt).

The chicken bun with tartar sauce is awesome.

The soy sauce base with chicken leg is delicious. Chicken falls off the bone, noodles are perfectly al dante. The soup was slightly salty. 

I'd come back.
author: Scott W.

description: Another one of our neighborhood spots! I've tried each of their hot ramen items, one of my favorites is the tomato. It's definitely different but good! I don't eat red meat so this is perfect since everything is chicken based. I haven't tried too many apps or other dishes, need to save room for the ramen! Only downside is the line on busy nights, they don't take your phone number so you have to wait there. If you're not there they will skip you. Waiting there for 1-1.5 hrs rather than walking around or wait at a bar can be long. They don't have a bar inside but you can go inside and ask to order drinks. They will bring it outside for you.
author: Monika V.

description:
I'm a HUGE Ramen fan. Like HUGE. If I had an option to choose what to eat for dinner, it would be ramen lol. 

Anyways. This review is based off my first time visit, food, service, and my other ramen experiences. 

FOOD: 3.5/5
Ordered:
 -Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce $19: (3.5/5) for the price I paid, I feel like I had only 5 bites of noodle in there and the oily broth is what got me filled up and hungry later.. 

-Tako Yaki Fries $8: (1/5) don't order this. All it is: okonomiyaki sauce, Japanese mayo, and bonito flakes on fries. You can make it yourself. 

-Tofu&Advo Salad $12: (1/5) not worth $12 bucks. 

-Niku Maki (Rice balls) $4.5: (4/5) better than ramen in my opinion, but too costly. 

SERVICE: 1/5
Everything was alright up until after our meal ended. We came with a group of 8. We let Friend (A) in our group calculate the overall cost and tip into the bill, and we all paid based on what Friend (A) calculated. After 80% of our party leaves the restaurant, one server (Asian guy, black straight hair, with eye glasses) who wasn't even our main server accuses me and Friend (B) that our table didn't tip ENOUGH. Ummmm awkward? Why didn't he confront us while our whole party was there? Lol.... 

1) Tips are so often expected now a days with shitty service. It seriously boggles me. I don't think Employees realize that they are OPTIONAL. Your tip amount is based on your exceptional or unexceptional service. 

2) It is rude and uncomfortable as a customer to even experience this. It is NOT in your place (employee) to even talk down to your customer and demand for more money.

Advice: if you want a big tip from a big group. Rather than complaining about it. Why not charge automatic gratuity to parties 6+ like other restaurants normally would? 

QUALITY: 2/5
You're better off visiting HANABI RAMEN in San Mateo. They have the same delicious Paitan Chicken ramen for $15 and the option to add extra noodles for only $1.5 more. 

Overall, would not return here based on service but also for the high priced ramen and so-so appetizers.
author: Lisa M.

description: Thee best ramen spot inside the city of San Francisco. The meat from the chicken falls off the bone so gracefully. The chicken based broth will leave you begging for more. Also I recommend ordering the matcha green tea creme brûlée, to leave your tastebuds in serenity.
author: Kendrick E.

description:
Hate to give a three star to a awesome restaurant but what's gonna get me everytime is the price. 18 dollars for a small bowl of ramen..albeit it has a big chicken wang in it. But I came here for ramen not chicken, so turn down that wang size and opt for bigger portions of noodles & broth. 

On another note the broth is....a mixture between Jesus juice and elixir of the gods, dude. So creamy and thick and flavorful. My taste buds are still enveloped in it as I type. 

Service is on point. Waiter was hilarious. And the spot was popping tonight with a good crowd.
author: Katie M.

description: Almost a five, but some nit picks. Thought the spicy hamachi wasn't spicy and the meatballs were a bit salty. Everything else was great!
author: Marcos S.

description: Salty, rich, and satisfying broth. Perfectly cooked noodle (a little chew but tender). Also just the right amount of dressing and meat. Such a satisfying bowl of ramen on a chilly SF night. Definitely will be back to try out other items on the menu.
author: An N.

description: Really helpful hostess and overall service was amazing. Getting a table for 8 people on a Friday evening in Hayes Valley is a nightmare but our hostess went out of her way to accommodate our big group and even came out to get us (we were having drinks next door at the Grove) when our table was ready. Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen was delicious and had a great balance between broth, noodles and a whole leg of chicken. It's not the best bowl of ramen I've ever eaten (and there have been many different bowls all over the world), but it definitely ranks highly among the ones I've had in SF. Some other friends ordered bao appetizers and said they were very good too. Job well done and we will be back!
author: Lauren T.

description:
An assault on my taste buds!

Literally every dish we ordered was drowned in salt, rendering the high quality of the meats and veggies pointless. Service was alright, but the time waited and money spent were not at all worth the trouble.  Will not be returning.
author: Nicole C.

description: Had the Chicken Paitan Tomato Ramen and it was amazing! Expect a 30 minute wait when you arrive because it is usually packed. Atmosphere is very relaxing and is the perfect place to hang out with friends over a nice big bowl of San Francisco's best ramen!
author: Cody B.

description: It was ok, frankly. Poke bowl was pretty delicious, but the ramen was def not our fave in the city. And the cucumber appetizer was just ok.
author: Daniela O.

description:
Salt, salt, salt everywhere, in ludicrous amounts. Intensely salty crab in the "Avocado and Crab" salad. Poke bowl was so dominated by salt that we detected no other flavors. Disappointing experience :(

Food: 0/5
Place: 4/5
Staff: 5/5
author: dj s.

description: The best ramen I ever had! Highly recommend spicy miso ramen! The wait is always long but totally worthy! But I probably got food poisoning from there..
author: Alice Z.

description:
I am not much of a Ramen kind of person, but the food is definitely worth the wait.
I was surprisingly happy by the Nojo fries.
author: Marc G.

description:
Meh overall. 

The noodles were thick and had a nice texture. The chicken leg ramen that they are known for was a disappointment. The chicken leg was very dry as if they had boiled it for many hours. It had lost all of the fattiness and smoothness dark meat is known for.   Would have been better if they had put a rotisserie check leg on the ramen.
author: Ryan L.

description: Vegan, vegetarian and meaty options all equally tasty and well presented. We waited 30-40 mins on a Friday night, but put our names on the waiting list and had a drink in a nearby bar until we got a text message saying our table was ready. We had a variety of vegan and chicken options between our group and all of them tasted incredible. Some authentic options on the menu and some more westernised/fusion ramen but would highly recommend this place!
author: Georgina P.

description:
This is my ramen destination from now on. They do not have any sushi, sashimi, or tradition Japanese dishes, just the ramen and small plates.
I love the creamy ramen broth.

Staff is very attentive with nice suggestions on food. We had Gyoza (the best Gyoza ever I have ever tried), Soy sauce ramen with a chicken leg..... Yum yum yum!!!

See you again Nojo! I have to go back to try different types of your ramen.
author: Bentley K.

description:
My friend and I came in late on Thursday night, October 26th around 830-845 and there appeared to be little wait (based on the list they have and the people actually waiting).  There were three groups of 2s that were not crossed out in front of us when we arrived.  We were referred to ask the hostess (an asian girl with long hair tied back wearing glasses, no make up - natalie?) for wait time.  I approached her when she was busy stocking glasses and she had told me not too long for a wait.  Ok, she seemed busy so we went outside to wait, it was too hot inside!  Within 15 minutes the three parties ahead of us were sat but we continued to wait another 15 minutes.  Ive been here a handful of times and waiting 30 minutes is very normal if not little compared to their busy times.   However, there were no other names on the list and the shared table in the front and most of the bar were wide open.  When we approached the same girl (who we were told to be the hostess) she appeared to STILL be stocking but she interrupted me while I was asking about the wait time and telling her we were happy to sit anywhere and her response was "yeah, yeah.  I know, i know"   then she took off pushing the glass cart into the backroom without further explanation of when we would be seated.  Feeling brushed off, we went back outside to wait.  Shortly after there was a small rush of people.  Some reason we were overlooked and when the hostess came back to seat, she skipped us!!  The parties that arrived after us got sat immediately and we were there waiting half an hour!!

I used to be a waitress too.  I understand when its slow and employees want to catch up on what they need to but when a customer tries to ask to be seated when there are plenty of available seats and you are rudely interrupted so they can rushes off to finish a side task and then forget to follow up.  AND THEN skips you to seat other parties???  What happens?  you lose customers.  We left and we wont be back unfortunately.  I'd rather be somewhere that will at the very least give me some consideration for my time waiting over stocking glasses.  Not sure what the "i knows" were from her but clearly she doesnt know.  Sad to go but plenty of other ramen shops around here in SF.
author: Edith Y.

description:
First, the good - because the ramen itself was actually very good. My sister doesn't eat pork so we wanted to take her somewhere she could enjoy a delicious bowl of ramen during her visit to SF. Nojo specializes in chicken base ramen, and they do a great job at that.

This is my second time eating here and although the food is good, the service was poor both times.

We arrived at 8:00 pm on a Tuesday night and waited 1 hour for our table. The seating process is not efficient because they won't hold an adjacent table at all- not even 5 minutes- to allow smaller tables to be combined. I wouldn't recommend going here if it's not a date night for 2, or you don't mind sitting at the bar. They unapologetically seated many parties who arrived after us, and also turned over two halves of one single table that would have accommodated my party exactly. When I asked if they could put a chair on the end of a table to fit my group, they said they couldn't (which I could completely understand, except see #4 below). 

When were finally seated, they made us order by raising our hand for who wanted what ramen.  This made it complex for each person to order the toppings they wanted.

Third, they won't sell you extra noodles. 

Fourth, remember that chair they wouldn't put on the end of a table for us? When we were finally seated, I happened to notice that they put a chair on the end to accommodate someone else's party. In other words, the person I happened to ask was simply too lazy to move a chair. And I did ask very nicely, too. 

Luckily, there's plenty of amazing ramen shops with shorter lines and better service. I only hope that Nojo takes notice and tries to bring their service up to the high standards of Japanese hospitality I've come to expect... especially at one of the most expensive bowls of ramen in SF, $18.50 per bowl.
author: Ben H.

description:
Delicious ramen but definitely pricey. I like it a lot better than Mensho. I got the chicken tori ramen with chicken leg. The bowl was huge and the broth was super fatty and flavorful! I usually don't like fatty broth but this is the first time I really enjoyed it! It wasn't too salty and had very rich flavors.

The noodles were chewy and the chicken came off the bone easily. It's a pretty big piece too, so meat eaters rejoice. 

This is most likely the best chicken ramen I've ever had. Service was friendly but a bit slow. For example they forgot to give me water then kept forgetting to refill my cup even after I flagged someone. Still, I would love to come back and recommend stopping by if you're in Hayes Valley. :)
author: Sophia H.

description: Love the Taipan Soy Sauce ramen! Although it's not as good as the ramen in Japan, I would say this is the best ramen place in San Francisco among the ones I have tried so far. I personally did not like Mensho ramen that much because the broth was toooooo thick and they probably used chicken liver or something similar that made the broth really heavy and tasted a bit weird. Besides the soy sauce taipan ramen, the appetizers are also good. I tried the nanban (similar to karaage) and the pork belly rice ball (bacon-wrapped rice ball) and they were both tasty! This will be my go-to spot when I crave for ramen this winter :D
author: Kally C.

description: If all Nojo gave me was broth, I would drink it and rejoice, because the flavors pack that much punch. With that said, the toppings are also fantastic. I ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen and split it with a friend; if you're really hungry, you could probably eat an entire bowl, but they are definitely large helpings. Chicken that falls right off the bone and that fried gobo! I'd never even heard of gobo, but now it might be my favorite thing - a salty, crunchy touch to add some texture. There's definitely a long wait pretty early, so be ready for that. Still, worth it if you want some good ramen.
author: AJ P.

description: Loved it, had the miso ramen and it hit the spot. The dessert was amazing as well. Would definitely come back.
author: Nicole K.

description:
Sorry, but not sorry. This was the most disappointing and most expensive ramen I've ever had. 

I had the chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso ramen with an added onsen poached egg. I wanted their Daishi egg instead but they apparently "ran out." I swear I heard and saw the table after me order it... $17 + $1.50. 

First off, the broth was wayyyyyy too thick and oily. I thought Dojo's broth was pretty thick but this was even more. The taste was alright, but my mouth was just not loving it. The noodles were just alright. I could still taste the flour which meant they probably needed to blanch it more. I think my favorite part of the bowl was the fried gobo... sadly...  For almost $20 a bowl, I wasn't even full either! 

Perhaps I didn't order the right thing. Apparently their slow braised whole chicken leg is a must. I don't eat chicken so just my luck :P 

With the reviews and waiting, I was expecting it to make it to my top 5, if not top 10. Sadly, with the price and taste, it was far off. I don't understand their hype. Perhaps being in Hayes Valley is their safe haven. I wouldn't mind going to a mediocre ramen joint and ordering two bowls as compared to what I had.
author: Fiona L.

description:
TLDR; With a trendy and decently warm atmosphere Nojo is an inviting, nice late night spot; but sets expectations a bit too high with a bowl of ramen priced at $20*.

(*$18.50, but after tax you're at $20)

More details:
This review is specifically on the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ($18.50). The braised chicken leg floated in a bowl of ramen is the star here. Unfortunately it doesn't make up for the broth, which although hearty and not watery, still lacks a certain depth and developed flavor profile that I've experienced with other ramen. The noodles are a pleasant surprise, one the thicker side, somewhat chewy, and good noodle flavor with a hint of extra sweetness. 

The chicken is fall off the bone, braised. The skin has a great golden brown color and still a bit crispy with great flavor. The dark tender meat of the leg pairs really well with the rest of the dish. Marrow lovers rejoice, due to the long braise of the chicken the marrow is extremely soft and so are the bones, making getting the marrow out with a few soft bites an easy task.

Overall, the atmosphere is 3.5-4 stars and the this Ramen was a 4-5 star bowl of $12 ramen but 3 at best for $18.50. I expected a lot more out of the broth and flavors there. The bowl is also a pretty standard size as well, not huge, so sharing doesn't really help with the value and would only work if you were both looking for a snack. And with only one leg, you may find yourself fighting over the best parts.

Although a different neighborhood- for something objectively tastier and a better value- check out Izakaya Sozai.
author: Adam D.

description: A bit of a splurge for ramen but it's delicious!!!! I bring everyone who visits from out of town and everyone loves it.  Small place and they do run out of the best ramen the chicken taipan soy sauce - delicious.  Definitely want to show up within the first hour it opens to guarantee all menu items are available
author: Margo B.

description: This is my favorite ramen place in the city.  Add a chicken leg to your soup! Can't get enough of this ramen soup! And great hand made appetizers!  Almost didn't want to review because there's always a wait.  Worth the wait. Love it!
author: Tracy C.

description:
Easily a 5 star ramen spot, but they need to figure out a better way to turn tables!  We put our names on the wait list at 5:30 and didn't get seated until about 6:40!  What makes it even more frustrating is seeing empty tables inside while customers are waiting outside on the sidewalk...

About the food.  We had the Nojo fries, Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen and the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso ramen.  The soy sauce ramen was the consensus winner.  It's really good! The fries were also a small but good start to the meal.  The spicy miso ramen was good, but didn't knock us out the way the soy sauce ramen did. 

I would DEFINITELY come back but will try to find a time when I don't have to wait so long!
author: Charlie B.

description: I just tried Nojo Ramen Tavern for the first time today. I had the vege ramen and the nori avocado starter. They were both amazing. I arrived for an early dinner and the wait was about 15 minutes, so not bad at all. However, the place was packed and by the time I left and there seemed to be quite a wait. The wait is worth it though. The noodles are perfect and the broth has amazing flavor and consistency. I highly recommend a visit.
author: Steven K.

description:
I went most of Ramen place in SF, one of my favorite is NoJo. Good vibes tasty Ramen comfortable seat, cool decorations. 
I highly recommend it!
author: Misha O.

description:
Let's just say it's our (husband and I) favorite Sunday go to spot. Then we go to Smitten's after for ice cream:)
MUST TRY:
Ramen (duh!)
Toripan
Teriyaki chicken bun
Poke bowl
Fries

Well we have literally tried everything. And it's all FANTASTIC! 
The wait can be long, they will say 30mins, but usually you will get seated within 10. The staff is really nice and we love how the whole kitchen says bye to you when you leave. It's awesome.
author: Sania B.

description: Decent ramen shop among others in the city. Appetizers are great. Took awhile to get a seat on a casual weekday, so if you plan to go on the weekend, expect to wait a bit long. Very limit spaces to wait inside tho. Also, It's kinda dark the whole restaurant, a minus if you want to take pics of dishes. Over all, I enjoy it and would like to recommend and come back.
author: Vu P.

description:
I know what you're all thinking... chicken ramen?! For $18.50 a bowl?! But give it a try before you knock it! 

I dropped by Nojo around 7:30 PM on a Friday and to my surprise, there was no wait for this trendy Ramen joint. I glanced at the entrance once we got our ramen around 8 PM and there was a crowd of Asians gathering by the door plus they are known to run out of some of their more popular ramens before closing so do come early! 

I ordered the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen and it was everything I could have hoped for and more. The ramen isn't made with pork bones but the broth is still rich and hearty and the slow-braised chicken leg was a good substitute for the traditional pork belly/cha siu.

If you're still hungry, give the Soy Milk Cream Cheese Crostini appetizer a try as well.

Slurp up!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I am not much of a ramen connoisseur so I don't have any other nicer ramen places to compare this to, but the vegetarian miso ramen at this place is AMAZING. The produce is high quality and the broth is very filling and flavorful. I wish they had more than one vegetarian ramen dish, but honestly this one is so good I am happy to eat it every time I'm in the neighborhood for a show at the ballet or symphony. I also really like their green tea creme brulee which is pricey, but very tasty and also not something you can just pick up anywhere.

I'm knocking a star off because once they ran out of the miso veggie ramen less than an hour after opening time :'( Also, if you don't get here before the 5pm opening time, you will probably have to wait at least an hour, as the place is very small and very popular. It is usually packed as soon as the doors open.
author: Margaret S.

description:
Went here last might to kill time before a concert. 

Dark wood tables, some bar stool height and some regular. Inside is dark with dim lighting and loud from adjacent customers.

My friend and I were seated fairly fast considering it was busy. We were given the option of the bar height table by the door or wait for a regular table. We didn't want to kill too much time so we chose the bar height. There are hooks underneath for your purses and jackets; don't forget them!

The waiter came by to give us water and clipboard menus. Items are a bit pricey. I chose the $16 poke bowl. My friend picked the $16 spicy ramen.  The waiter did advise that the ramen came without broth and was very spicy. He said he could have the chef remove the chili oil, but the chicken was already pre-made with additional spices.

We waited a fair amount of time before the food arrived.  The poke bowl was served in a small wood box. Cilantro with spicy tuna, salmon, and avocado over a bed of rice. The ramen came in a fairly medium bowl. The noodles were semi-thick and the chicken was very spicy. 

Overall we had a good experience, but I don't think I'll be returning anytime soon. The food was mediocre to me. I've had better poke and ramen elsewhere for a lesser price. The service was friendly and atmosphere was comfortable. Definitely give this place a try! :)
author: Kacie Y.

description: Simply amazing.   Bit of a wait but it's well worth it.   Everything is fresh and everything we ordered was outstanding.  The avocado appetizer was out of this world.
author: Dugo J.

description:
3 stars for food (expecting that ramen will be more expensive in SF than the South Bay), 2 stars for how the waitlist is handled.

I didn't care for this place at all when it was yakitori, but we wanted to give it another try as a ramen "tavern". They're focused on paitan (I'm a big chicken fan). 

The wait was close to 90 min around 5:15pm on a Saturday.  This was my biggest complaint.  The hostess maintains the sign up list, and i think she could have handled the situation much differently. We had a big group and told her we were happy splitting up as 4 and 4 rather than waiting for a table of 8, but she kept insisting this one group was leaving.  We kept inquiring and saying we would just take tables for 4, but she kept saying they were "almost done."  I know she had good intentions, but this went on for over 30 min, and everyone else kept getting seated before us in groups of 2 or 4. Even though there were still maybe 30-40 people waiting outside, she didn't seem willing to tell the table they needed to clear it for the huge crowd outside, so I ended up doing it myself.  The party had finished their meal for a long time (at least 30 min)?and seemed to be just lingering at the table and looking at their phones - either not noticing or not caring how many people were waiting for the spot. 

Ok so the wait was pretty frustrating, but the actual food wasn't bad, per se (but also wasn't worth $17-20 a bowl in my opinion). 
- Nanban chicken: fried chicken pieces with sauce, just ok. Not very much chicken for $9
- Nikumaku rice ball: a thin piece of pork belly wrapped around a ball of rice 
- Cilantro, bamboo shoots, and ryu: mostly cilantro
- Chicken paitan soy sauce: the broth was smoky and had good flavor; it comes with a chicken leg, which is interesting 
- Chicken paitan tan tan spicy miso: I think there was much more cilantro than there was ground chicken. The broth flavor was good, but I think it was too heavy and thick (yes, I know pork broth is rich, but this wasn't just straight rich...)
- The add on dashi egg for the ramen was nicely cooked 
- Soboro dry tossed noodles: flat noodles with ground chicken, raw egg, cilantro, etc. Interesting concept, but the flavor was a lot less interesting / intense than the ramen bowls 
- Ice cream sandwich: with Humphrey slocombe ice cream. This was pretty good 

They do have a vegetarian option for ramen, which is nice.  Our actual server was also friendly and checked in to make sure we were doing ok. 

Overall, not worth the wait, price, and frustration of how the waitlist is handled (I saw other people in similar situations complaining).  Also, they only have one unisex bathroom, which constantly had a line of 3-4 people outside, and when I got inside, there was definitely a lot of urine all around the floor by the toilet, and it smelled like it had been there for a while: 

My advice is not to go with more than two people, but I think parties of two were waiting up to an hour as well.
author: Marilyn T.

description: We had to wait about 45 minutes on a Tuesday night for a table but it was certainly worth the wait. The Spicy Ramen and Tomato based Ramen were incredible and one of the best we have eaten. The service was good and food came out quickly. The restaurant was rather loud but had a good atmosphere and was close to the theaters.
author: Naomi W.

description: My japanese hair stylist recommended this restaurant to me as her favorite ramen shop in San Francisco. I came here on a Sunday around 12:30pm and there was seated immediately. I tried the chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen and the dry spicy ramen. I definitely like the broth-based ramen better since I'm not a huge fan of spicy food.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Tomato ramen. AMAZING 
Always think twice before ordering it
Always completely satisfied with the flavor 
A must try
author: Henry C.

description: I've never had chicken ramen and was pleasantly surprised to try it at Nojo Ramen Tavern. The portions were huge and the ramen was delicious! We sat at a communal table so it didn't take very long to get a seat. Would definitely recommend for a cold SF day!
author: Lauren S.

description:
This authentic Japanese Ramen place is new to the Hayes Valley neighborhood and I believe they will be here for a long time to come.
Their Chicken Leg Ramen (can't remember what it was called) was so rich and delicious! 
Also the Gyoza was really surprisingly refreshing for what is usually a heavy food.
Great for lunch, a a cozy dinner for two, or a night out with friends.
author: Harrison L.

description: Showed up at 6:40pm on a Sunday after paying $18 to park and despite a 20 minute wait there was no way they could seat my wife and infant son but I'm sure the food is great.
author: Steve N.

description: This place charges an extra fee tacked into the bill labeled as "SF mandate". Which is very decieving. Googling showed that it's not what it sounds. The owner should just increase the price on the menu. Food was decent and service was great though. Soup was a bit too salty, but still downable. The soft boiled egg didn't have the runny yolk that I really like, so that was a disappoint. I would've rather liked a whole soft boiled egg with runny yolk in the soup, rather than a sliced, sorta-hard-boiled egg on the side like the way they did it. Portions were slightly below average. Kinda pricey, probably on par for this part of SF
author: George L.

description: Came here around 5:50 on a Friday night and just missed the insane lines! Really nice that they make sure to come back to the first person on the list when your whole party isn't there, every time another table opens. We got seated around 6:20 because my friend was late (but really only waited about 5 minutes from the time she showed). We sat at the bar in front of the chef and it was really fun to see the food prep! We both ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce because of the whole chicken leg, and it was delicious! I've been to Mensho as well and while I do prefer their ramen a bit more to Nojo, the atmosphere at Nojo as well as space in general plus not waiting 45+ minutes outside made up for it! Really enjoyed my experience, waiters were all super friendly and would come back here again on a cold rainy SF day!
author: June L.

description: I'm not sure why this place doesn't have more reviews because Nojo is definitely on the top of my ramen list! It's our second time here and it was as good as our first. In comparison to other "top ramen places" in SF and NY, Nojo's broth has the perfect balance of flavor and salt cooked to the perfect consistency to bathe their al dente ramen noodles. This time around we tried their Takoyaki fries, which were a lot better than their fried rice rolls we had last time. We also had their Chicken Paitan Soy and Chicken Paitan Tan Tan, both I highly recommend! The chicken was fall off the bone tender and already have me craving more. The best part is that Nojo doesn't seem to be as well known as other ramen places (again, not sure why because this place is amazing) so our wait for a table of 2 on a Friday night at 7pm was just about 15 minutes!
author: Kimberly C.

description: My wife and I had a Friday night out without our 10-month old and came in after a ballet performance.  The staff seated us quickly even though the restaurant was full.  The staff was fast, professional and courteous.  The food came out quickly and packed a flavorful punch! The only loss of a star was for the price, $45 for two people for two basic ramen bowls and water is a bit steep, even in San Francisco.  We'll be back the next time we are out in Hayes Valley for dinner.
author: Jon K.

description: I feel compelled to update this. The chicken paitan soy sauce ramen is good and deserves more than what I said at first. Yes the chicken is not super seasoned. But with the skin on - makes it worth munching on. The excessive onions in various forms is fun and gives the broth a fresh kick.
author: Andrew G.

description:
Finally, I think I found a replacement to my ex-fave Iza Ramen.  If you're a fan of spicy broth,  the one here rocks.  The chicken pai tan soy sauce is hands down one of the top dishes I've had in my life.  I eat here a couple of times a month,  just for this dish.  The menu is very broad so I was skeptical, but it's worth it for some variety.  Plus if you're not into pork, or want vege options  (including ramen) then this place delivers.  An insane line on a weekend, but  awesome flavor.  This chicken ramen dish is the ramen standard so what more could you want.  

p.s. the "ice cream sandwich" is repulsive...don't get me wrong,  the Humphrey Slocum ice cream is always great,  but the cheesy Asian wafer to make the sandwich is a stupid idea and disgusting.
author: A A.

description:
Chicken paitan ramen is hearty, filling and delicious! I split my bowl with the bf because it's a bit pricey, but..it I soon found that it was worth the premium! The chicken was super tender, and the soup wasn't overly heavy/oily. Noodles are on point, the way o liked them; a bit more on the al dente/hard side. Definitely coming back here again the future.
