I also ordered the noripan, which was very unique. Basically like a ground chicken and sauce on a toasted baguette. Not sure if I'd order that again..it was alright. 

Definitely order the chicken ramen!
author: Jessica L.

description:
this ramen was so savory we almost felt sick afterwards, but in a good way
Negative effect on dancing abilities after eating ramen 
Nojo is no joke tho
chicken ramen has never been this rich
best damn chicken leg that i've put on my tongue
author: LoJam ..

description:
My husband and I were just walking about SF and we decided that we wanted to try a new Ramen spot.  Nojo came up in the Yelp reviews with 4 stars so we decided to give it a try.

Upon walking up to the restaurant we could tell that it was pretty trendy and a little pricey, but we were getting hungry and didn't want to look for a new place.

After sitting down and looking at the menu (and recommendations on yelp) we were excited to eat.  We first started with the Takoyaki fries and we were NOT impressed.  The service was also pretty bad.  After we ordered our appetizer, our server can back so we could order our entrees.  Mind you it was just me and my husband.  He ordered the Spicy Chicken Paitan with an egg and chicken meatballs and I ordered the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso.

The server said he forgot his pen and said "I hope I can remember this, I'm sorry if I have to come back and ask you again."  I was completely shocked.

I would have given this review a 2, but the ramen dishes turned out to be amazing.  Our two dishes were so delicious that I completely forgot about the service and the fries.  It actually made up for everything else.  Good job on the ramen!
author: Josie L.

description:
Ordered the spicy chicken soboro.  The broth was not that spicy, could've used a tad bit more spice and ground chicken. Overall the broth wasn't heavy and the noodles cooked al dente. 

Also ordered their version of chicken karage. Next time I would ask them to serve the sauce on the side. The gyoza was tasty and it was served with their house made dipping sauce.

Had the ice cream sandwich (with black sesame) for dessert and we were forewarned that it's a bite sized scoop of ice cream. Could've eaten the entire sandwich on my own but at that point I was pretty stuffed. 

The wait staff was attentive and friendly. Atmosphere and ambiance was nice.  Overall my dining experience was well worth the 4  rating.

There were 2 of us and we got there on a Friday night around 6:00. By 6:45 the place was filled and a line had formed.
author: Scott L.

description: Truly amazing ramen. I absolutely love ramen and grew accustomed to eating the likes of Totto and Ippudo once a week when I lived back in NYC. I'd struggled to find a place that matched the quality and vibe here in SF but Nojo is definitely it. Can't recommend enough!
author: Ana M.

description: Had heard some hype on this place. Unfortunately, the ramen broth (I got the Veggie Miso Ramen) was a bit too thick (almost pasty) and a bit sweet. Others with me got the regular chicken ramen, which Nojo is known for, and they had the same feedback -- way too thick and heavy. I probably won't be returning as there are two many other ramen places that are better in and outside of the city.
author: Natalise K.

description:
1)chicken patian soy sauce 
2)chicken patian tan tan spicy miso
3) nikumaki rice ball - pork belly 
4) chicken nan nan - fried chicken

Loved everything
author: Amanda L.

description:
Had been wanting to try this place for ages, and so glad I finally did! At $18 a bowl for the soy sauce chicken paitan ramen, I was suspicious. But happily, my bowl of ramen was very hearty and filling! A bit too filling if you ask me. I'm not used to having a huge piece of meat with ramen, usually only a few slices of chashu. The ramen noodles were great in texture and springiness. Overall I thoroughly enjoyed my bowl. However, for the wait (after we were seated, our food took forever to come out!) and the price, I don't think I'm dying to come back anytime soon. That said, I wouldn't object to coming here if invited. 

Also we got a "famous rice ball" that was literally a 4.50 rice ball...at least it was tasty? 

Other food items look slightly tempting however as they call themselves a "ramen house" we sort of stayed away.
author: Lydia W.

description:
Nojo is famous for their chicken-based broths (with a little pork still), which are hearty and creamy, albeit heavy (according to our waitress). I came with a friend of mine on Thursday night around 7:30PM, and there was a short wait. Even as we were leaving around 9PM, there was a short line still waiting to be seated. Definitely arrive early to put your name on the list if there is one!

Their classic Chicken Paitan (15) comes with their fluffy meatballs, and is definitely on the lighter side. The portion was also pretty small. I ordered the Veggie Miso Ramen (16.50), which had a thick miso broth and came with relatively generous helpings of corn, greens, and noodles. There was one finger (pod?) of okra. Be wary that extras, such as the soft-boiled egg (1.50), will add to the tab!

We finished up with their Monaka Ice Cream sandwich. A scoop of their creamy green tea/cinnamon ("Matchadoodle") ice cream was served between two mochi-based wafers, forming a small, cute sandwich. Even though the sandwich was good, I don't think it warranted $7.

Tl;dr -- hearty but pricey ramen joint known for their chicken-based broths.
author: Victoria C.

description: We ate at Nojo Ramen Japanese food establishment in SF and I'll tell you, if you have a high blood pressure issue, I would skip this place. I've eaten Ramen in very authentic place and I've never ate as salty soup in my Ramen soup in my whole life until I went to this place. If this is your favorite place and don't mind sipping salty soup, then maybe you should check in your doctor. Chances are you may have a high blood pressure. I'm not a food critic but I do express my honest opinion.
author: Geoff B.

description:
As you will see in my review, I am not a ramen expert.

Ramen with chicken leg.
Broth was hearty and very flavorful.
I think they had slivers of crispy yams in it. Those complimented the soup well.
Ramen was firm and chewy
Chicken quarter was tender.
I think today I would just enjoyed the bowl more with just a drumstick  and lots more noodles and soup.  

Apps:
Fries were okay.  Not amazing  
We also had this bread with chicken sausage on it or something.  It was tasty but not amazing.

I guess it's a bit pricey but am thankful to be able to eat out like this so I try to not to complain when I can check myself
author: Pin C.

description: Noodle texture and broth were great!  The broth was both creamy and flavorful as it should have been and the noodles were soft yet chewy.  My friend ordered the chicken paitan while I ordered the paitan soy sauce.  I loved both broths, but if you are looking for something lighter and less salty, I'd go for the regular paitan.  The chicken leg in the paitan soy sauce was absolutely succulent with the meat just gliding off the bone.  While I'm generally a fan of pork belly with my ramen, the chicken was a perfect pairing with my bowl of ramen and was cooked to absolute perfection.  We ordered the chicken nanban as well which was a great start to our meal.  Hope to visit again and maybe try out some of their other selections.
author: Connie Y.

description:
Great service, and the food was absolutely delicious! Highly recommend it if you like good ramen. The broth wasn't too thick or heavy. I liked it way better than Mensho; I thought the kombu flavor at Mensho was too powerful. The slow-braised chicken is to die for. 

Loved it.
author: Jennifer Hom C.

description:
Very nice service and clean atmosphere. A friend and I had lunch here during the soft opening. Chicken paitan-only ramen so no tonkotsu porky pig broth here. I had the regular chicken paitan ramen with the chicken meatballs. The meatballs were juicy and flavorful and the noodles were perfectly springy. The chicken paitan ramen had a creamy, rich, white color and rather full-bodied. Two pieces of fresh bamboo were included in the soup. Bits of citrus (yuzu?) brightened up the whole bowl.

What works:
* Clean atmosphere
* Clean bathrooms
* Love the springy, thicker, curly ramen noodles. Perfectly cooked.
* Loved the fresh bamboo.
* The chicken meatballs had some grill marks but remained super juicy.
* Nice service

What I wasn't keen on:
* Price. $15 is rather spendy for the regular chicken paitan ramen.
* Broth. While it looked unctuous, it was super bland. Super duper bland. It was off-putting to see and feel such a rich-looking broth with no flavor or salt. I couldn't tell this was made from chicken...it just wasn't chicken-y. It wasn't salty. It was disappointing. (My friend had the spicy tan-tan chicken paitan ramen and said her broth was also very bland and not spicy.)
* The bamboo and citrus were nice touches but there needed a bit of something else more acidic to play off the rich broth.
author: Manda W.

description: Absolutely delicious and totally worth the wait! The spicy ramen is amazing. The broth has a lot of flavor and I would recommend the dashi eggs on top!
author: Rayna R.

description:
Nice but little expensive

Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen was really yum. Chicken-based soup is tasty. It may feel a little too salty though. It probably go well with drinks (it's tavern). There is a chicken leg in ramen, which is also nice. It's well cooked so you can easily separate meat and bones. Noodle is good.

Gyoza is so-so. It come with coconut sauce, which is kinda unique. 

Atmosphere of restaurant is cozy and nice.

I felt price was a bit expensive though. We ordered two ramen, gyoza, and salted kombu celery. It costs $60. Definitely not so expensive if you compare to other restaurant SF, but little more than my expectation for ramen place.
author: Kazuki N.

description: This is my second favorite ramen spot in the city. I think their ramen is a little different than most ramen and I love it!!! They also have some really good appetizers! I think they have odd hours though so make sure to check them out before you go.
author: Makenzi B.

description: I love Nojo!!! Their Chicken Paitan and Vegetarian Ramen are my favorites. The veggie ramen is amazing - SO good compared to most others. Great broth for all ramens and very well done. Worth the wait.
author: Kayla T.

description: They said its open until 11pm on a saturday but its closed out 10pm. An hour early. That's a bust.
author: Stella S.

description:
I've never been a fan of chicken ramen but this place definitely has changed my mind!

Specializing in "tori paitan" style ramen, which is chicken based. The broth here is lighter, smoother, and not as thick gravy like compared to Mensho, which I personally prefer. The tori paitan soy sauce is my favorite, with a bold flavor profile. The meat of the slow-cooked chicken legs just falls of the bone! Their noodles are the thick round chewy type. The miso broth has a spicy kick it and the chicken paitan is quite light with a refreshing twinge of yuzu. Something for everyone!

Their appetizers are hit or miss. Tried the chicken nanban, which wasn't quite crispy for being fried, but the spicy sauce was BOMB. We dipped our rice balls into it. The Nojo Salad was a refreshing mix of veggies and I loved the savory dressing that came on the side in the cutest tiniest mason mug.

This place doesn't have a huge long ridiculous wait, perhaps 20 minutes tops on a Sunday evening. There is plenty of seating, both tables and bar. It has a modern hip vibe, perfect for a date I'd say.
author: Minh N.

description:
We ordered two ramens, a shared chicken plate, and two lemonades. It was all good! But not "$60" good. 4 stars for the food, but 3 stars for the value.

There's also an "SF mandate" charge added to the final bill. However small, surprise charges and fees on bills are a big minus for me.
author: Benjamin S.

description:
Basically sprinted here to make the 2:30PM cutoff. SF needs to step up it's ramen game and this was probably the best/most unique ramen I've had in the city for sure!

We saw the rave reviews for the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen but our hearts were crushed when we found out they were sold out! 

Instead the BF got the Chicken Paitan ramen (no chicken leg unfortunately) and I got the Spicy Chicken Soboro Tossed Noodle and omg we were dying watching the ramen chefs in the kitchen making bowls and bowls of ramen that weren't ours.

First off, I thought the flavors were sooooooo on point. The ramen has such a rich and addicting taste despite it being chicken (only had pork/miso based until now)! And their noodles have a fresh taste and are nice and chewy. The Spicy Chicken Soboro Noodle was some Sichuan-level numbing spiciness and thank you to the great waitresses for always refilling our water! Everything in both bowls were so yummy!!

But... we were a little disappointed as to the sizes/price point. The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen is $18.50. $18.50 for a bowl of ramen!? The Chicken Paitan came out to be $17.50 (with an egg) and it only came with 3 small chicken meatballs and the Soboro Tossed Noodle was $16.00. In Japan, bowls of ramen are less than $10.00!! Coming in I was expecting some decently-sized gourmet ramen and while gourmet it certainly was, decently-sized it was not.

If you're not on a budget and looking for some fine-dining ramen (they also serve other yummy Japanese dishes here too!), this is your spot. Definitely worth a try!
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Ramen was top notch and pretty much the star (appetizers and such were an afterthought). Creative flavors and so much depth. Expect SF prices and SF lines but worth a try. Not sure if worth another visit though, unless I'm going through ramen withdrawal.
author: Howe L.

description: I had a really good ramen! I went in when they opened and by the time I was done eating, they had a line formed outside! It was really good!
author: Joanna H.

description: Not the worst ramen spot I've been to but definitely not worth the price. If you must eat here DO NOT order the rice ball. Extremely disappointing, there wasn't even meat in the one I was served.
author: Diandra L.

description: As much as I like the vegetarian ramen here, it's been a really frustrating experience as a repeat customer. The last 5-7 times I've come here, they always run out of veggie ramen. They'll tell me they have it, I'll wait for an hour, and then it's gone. Insanely frustrating and just not worth the wait/disappointment. It's really good if you can get it though
author: Devana B.

description: Yum!  Glad to see this place doing well.  I've enjoyed it every time.  I've probably had ramen at more than 100 places in the U.S. and Japan, and this place ranks pretty high on my happy-belly scale.  True, this isn't the quick 'n' dirty cheap ramen place, but it's tastefully done and the flavors were awesome.  Put your name down on the list, and go next door for a wine or beer while you wait.  Looking forward to another bowl.
author: Aya S.

description: The way the chef prepare the chicken for the ramen is unbelievable. The meat just falls off the bone. Soup is delicious every drop. While it is a little pricey for ramen. Its worth a visit.
author: Kamron W.

description: I do not like ramen. I LOVE NoJos Ramen. I'm not exactly sure how they do it but they make the most luxurious broth out of local chicken bones. I felt like I was drinking velvety pork broth so compressed with deep complex flavors. If only it weren't obscene to pick up the bowl and sip.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Amazing spicy miso ramen. Perfect noodles. Perfect amount of spice. Make sure you add an egg on top (we tried poached!) 

Expect to wait about 30-45 minutes on a Friday night. We were lucky enough to snag one of the tables outside under the heaters and enjoyed a couple pre-dinner beers.

Great service.
author: Amanda U.

description:
I went between 3 and 4 stars, but since I loved their ramen I can look beyond issues associated with being new.

Pros
- The spicy noodle ramen was probably the best I ever had. It contained all of the flavors I never knew I craved until we devoured it.
- We shared a communal table with five people from Japan, all over the age of 60...including one very cool grandma and they finished all their food and seemed quite content with their meal.  

Cons
- The ramen is expensive, probably because of the location.
- The service is disorganized, probably because they are new. However, everyone who works there was apologetic and nice.
- They ran out of half their ramens by 6pm.
author: Rosie F.

description: Not usually a ramen gal, this place pleasantly surprised me. I ordered the first ramen on the list (chicken paitan), added a soft boiled egg, truffle oil, and a spice bomb on the side. It's all about the spice balm, adding flavor to an otherwise mild AF dish. Also tried the poke bowl and it was decent, but definitely would opt for the ramen here any day.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Quite overpriced for what it was. They're known for the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce. The chicken was very tender and fall-off-the-bone, which was pretty nice. The egg was perfectly soft-boiled though. Still not worth almost $19 for a bowl of noodle soup. I had the Chicken Paitan Tomato, which was shredded chicken, and not as good. The broth was way too salty as well. Not sure if I'd be back as there's much more affordable and tasty ramen in the city. This place has added atmosphere and some izakaya dishes, but it's a bit too expensive for my blood.
author: Audrey L.

description: Delicious ramen that comes with a thicker broth. I always order the spicy miso and it never dissapoints. It doesn't come with an egg, but I definitely feel like it is worth adding one to complete the ramen meal. The noodles are cooked al dente, just the way I like it. The broth is very flavorful and thick, but I couldn't help drinking it with my noodles. Service is slower here to say the least. Don't get me wrong, the servers are really firendly, it is just how long does it take to prepare 5 bowls of ramen? We must have waited half an hour for our noodles...We were starving and it only took us 10 minutes to devour our dinner. Nojo can definitely work on their efficiency to make the dining experience more enjoyable.
author: Crystal M.

description:
from AP company.  Miyazaki Jitou Chicken.  Chicken paitan ramen, but -1 star for price.  getting a bit ridiculous.  out of the soy, so tried the tomato: shredded chicken tenders, blackened garlic oil, cilantro, grana padano, tomato, fried garlic, scallion, lemon
also the tan tan miso: spicy ground chicken, toasted sesame, cilantro, scallion, fried gobo, spice bomb.  actually both were pretty good.  the tomato with grated cheese was interested but worked.  noodles are central chew but soft exterior.
Miyazaki-style chicken fritters dipped in a soy vinaigrette, topped with house tartar sauce for the nanban but didn't care for the heavy mayo egg tartar and moist fritter
author: Rob C.

description:
The food was decent here (a bit overpriced) and my group of 8 was happy with service up until an incident that happened as we left. (Dinged a star)

There are no reservations here, so you have to come at 5pm to stand in line to get a table. We were lucky to get a long table for our group.

We ordered a few small plates to share -- rice ball with pork belly inside, takoyaki fries, avocado tofu salad. The rice ball was so good, but it it was SO small for the price. The takoyaki fries were quite satisfying with the sauce and shaved bonito on top...pricey for what they were though, but I like fries. The salad wasn't worth it -- it was a tiny salad with avocado, tofu, okra pieces; I did like the sesame dressing, which is standard at most Japanese places.

I went with the chicken paitan tan tan spicy miso. My friends got the chicken paitan ramen that comes with the chicken leg. They were raving about their bowls. I liked mine; I should have asked them to make it less spicy because beyond a certain point, the spice covers the flavor of the broth. Still, really good -- thick broth with ground chicken bits and some greens (no egg in this one).

So, what happened? Instead of splitting the check with different cards, I collected money from my group and I put my card down. I signed the check and included a tip. Service was average, so I tipped the norm. My friends and I wanted to go to another event, so half of us left to go stand in line while a couple stayed behind to use the restroom. 

At the event, one of the girls told us that she was confronted by one of the guys who bussed our table (East Asian male with glasses) saying something to the effect of, "You know that gratuity wasn't included right?" She said yes, we had included a tip. The guy goes, "If that's what you think." EXCUSE ME(/US)? First, she wasn't even the one who signed the check; I wish I had stayed behind because I would have given him a piece of my mind about how rude and inappropriate the conversation was and asked for the check back to cross out the tip. I have NEVER been confronted by a member of the wait staff to imply that a tip wasn't left or it wasn't enough. What did you want her to do, pull out cash for you? You weren't even our main waiter; you filled our glasses with water. A Causacian male and female (slightly darker skin, had her hair in a braid) took our orders and came out with our dishes. A tip is earned and I tip based on quality. I get it, being paid hourly in SF isn't fun and you rely on tips to supplement your wage, but hey, it's not like we jipped you. I left close to 15% (I might have been shy a couple bucks due to splitting the bill multiple ways), which is the norm; I only go higher if the service is above and beyond (like making accommodations for a special celebration). What is your problem and why is the sort of behavior even occurring? Come on Nojo. I mean, Nojo can institute a gratuity for parties of 8, but they didn't, so tip is at our discretion, and we tipped what was fair. It's not like we only ordered two bowls of ramen and split everything. We each ordered our own ramen and we had several small plates to share. We spent over $30 per person. Not a good way to treat your customers and thank you for leaving us with a poor impression at the end.
author: Katherine S.

description:
In the transition from the old Nojo to the new one, we lost a forgettable izakaya for an outstanding ramen shop. I'm satisfied.

By outstanding, I mean that we don't have yet another tonkotsu place. They have a chicken based broth (along with a very tasty vegetarian option), and they basically set the bar really high for anyone else coming along that's going at the non-tonkotsu angle. Best tori paitan in town. And you don't have to wait for an hour.

It's among the priciest in SF, though, and that's definitely saying something.
author: masa s.

description: The place has good service and tasty food, but prices are too high. Ramen +add egg- 19$ ... really? And it was a good chicken broth, but nothing special...tuna tartar was amazing but again : little plate for 11$. Was great experience, but not sure that will be back.
author: Alisha M.

description:
After visiting 3 times, Nojo Ramen became one of my favorite ramen joints in SFBA!  Their ramen are unique but tasteful. Each ramen is very different from each other. So it's fun. My favorites so far are Tan-Tan Spicy Miso and Chicken Paitan.

Service is great. Though we usually have to wait about 20-30 mins, it's nice that we can drink while we wait.
author: Akiko O.

description:
It's been a long while since I've reviewed anything on Yelp, but we tried Nojo last week and it was too good not to share. 

I'd never heard of Nojo before. I feel like I've tried almost every ramen joint in the city (and South Bay for that matter) so my expectations were high. When my boyfriend suggested we eat ramen I was hesitant; there are only a select few restaurants in the city where you can get decent, let alone good, ramen and I didn't know if this place in Hayes would make the cut. 

It more than did. We were seated quickly on a Friday night and our waitress was really attentive and sweet. We had a couple of questions about the menu and she was very helpful. I ended up getting the Chicken Paitan Ramen and my boyfriend got the Chicken Paitan Tomato Ramen. Both were delicious. The traditional chicken paitan was full of chicken-y flavor. The broth was thick and creamy without being oily. The tomato paitan was really garlicky and tasty. I'm used to traditional Tonkotsu or Miso ramen broths and these were both exciting and unique and still tasted super authentic. I loved everything. 

The only drawback is that you end up paying about $17 for a bowl of noodles. Pretty steep, but understandably so considering the area this place is in. Even still, Nojo is a welcomed addition to the neighbor and my new go-to spot for ramen in the city.
author: Michelle Q.

description: Down side, wait time can be up to 20+ mns, serving time 20mns and salty broth; otherwise good noodles.
author: Mitsu A.

description: This is awesome restaurant! I've never expected about the taste, because it looks too westernized but the taste was good enough to satisfy both authentic Asian and American. Dessert was also terrific and atmosphere was cool. Lots of cool people were there!
author: John Paul Young K.

description: tried the signature Ramen, really special broth. Definitely worth to try
author: Liang H.

description:
1. Check out Nojo Ramen Tavern's website. This is the ultimate in food porn photography. Ponder the curious juxtaposition of people and critters on the About page. 

2. Run to Nojo and order the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen pictured on their menu page. It's like a duck confit and you'll never miss the duck. The fried gobo was an excellent garnish.

3. If you're a convalescent, order the chicken paitan ramen. While the chicken meatballs are delectable, the broth is best reserved for invalids. I belatedly discovered a small ball of grated ginger on a tiny raft of greens in my bowl. Briskly stirring the ginger in did season the broth a little. Perhaps ordering a 'topping' of a braised chicken leg is a requirement.  
 
4. The nikumaki rice ball, wrapped in pork belly, was interesting, but not particularly robust.
author: Mutant O.

description: We got sick for 2 days after eating here. The service was good. Veggie ramen ok. Meat ramen was delicious but this led to 2 days of diarrhea.
author: Gernaut A.

description: every single item we had was a hit. Creative, surprising flavor combos, beautiful presentation. Not far from that michelin star if you ask me!
author: Hua W.

description: Get here early!!! Lined up for dinner at 5:45 for a 6pm open and we were already 7-8th in line. Worth the wait. Lots of different alcohols on the menu, and very flavorful and precisely prepared ramen. Even the edamame had a little something special about it! And some really inventive desserts. Loved the ice cream sandwich!! We're looking for shows coming up at the war memorial opera house just to have an excuse to go back!! Can't wait :)
author: Sara S.

description:
Came here on a early Saturday afternoon, lots of empty seats and was sat at the bar area. 
After scanning through the whole menu and found out they don't have any pork in ramen at all( I thought ramen broth was supposed to be made from pork bone?), I settled for spicy tantan ($17) with slight disappointment. When they finally brought the ramen to us, I was more disappointed with the lack of topping and the signature soft-boiled egg ($1.5 extra to add one apparently , and yes I rolled my eyes in my head when I saw that on the menu). Tasty broth but nothing special, a little oily for my taste, not spicy at all, a spoon full of ground chicken meat, some green onions, and cilantro, a bit of fried gobo (a mystery root veggie of some sort), there I just described everything in my $17 bowl of ramen aside from a fist sized ball of noodles. Over priced and nothing special is my conclusion. For people who really know what true ramen should taste like, they'd find better ramen and price at Iza ramen in lower haight.
author: Julie Y.

description:
The ramen here is pretty fricking awesome.  They're known for their chicken broth, so don't expect your typical Orenchi-like tonkotsu ramen.  It's a bit pricey, even by SF standards, but you're in hipster-hood Hayes Valley... what do you expect?

Highly recommend!
author: Joyce C.

description: Yum yum yum! Authentic ramen in the bay area at it's very best. I love how this ramen joint uniquely serves a chicken based broth as oppose to the usual tonkotsu ramen. It is on the pricier side but hey, that chicken leg is sooo worth it! I highly recommend the spicy miso and chicken paitan soy sauce ramen. Their soup is creamy and very flavorful. You can defiitely tell it was cooked for 20+ hours with love and perfection. The noodles were fresh and cooked al dente. Dont forget to try their made to order gyozas! They have been open for almost two weeks and they have nailed everything. Their staff were very attentive and super nice.
author: Carmen A.

description:
Forgetting to put in an order and wasting an hour of your customer's time, focusing your customer service on getting the customer to forgive you, and then not incenting the customer to give you another chance. I desperately wanted a new go to ramen place in the city -- why did they have to fail so miserably?

Arrived around 9:30 after a nearby show. We were in a bit of a hurry, so we quickly ordered two bowls of ramen. About 30 minutes later, when another couple sat down next to us, we were puzzling why it took so long for a traditionally quick meal to be prepared, particularly on a relatively slow night. They ordered and then received their food inside of 15 minutes, and we flagged the waitress. Apparently she never put our order in, and then just wasn't paying any attention to this one of her six tables. We asked to pay for our two beers (which they comped, after 4-5 minutes to deliberate), and left.

As we walked out, someone ran out to introduce himself and apologize, which was normal. We expected the standard, "please give us another chance" or what have you, but instead he kept on trying to re-apologize in the hopes that we would tell him not to worry about it. Eventually, he misheard "well, it happened" as "it happens" then said that if we came in again *while he was there* he would "see if there was anything that [he] could do for us." How much I am not overwhelmed.
author: David V.

description: Chicken Paitan - The more direct comparison to Mensho's toripaitan, this also came with a rich, creamy broth, albeit one that's much lighter than that of Mensho's, for better or worse. I myself prefer the richer one at Mensho, while my friend found Nojo's to be more easily drinkable
author: Abby P.

description:
although there was an extremely long line, it is understandable that it was saturday night. the chicken broth and the tentenmien was phenomenal. special shout out to the chicken broth for being so rich.

however, try not to get the tomato-based ramen..unless you like spaghetti with ramen noodle.
author: Jack L.

description:
My new favorite ramen in the city. I saw a photo of the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen on a food blogger's insta, and I knew I had to have it. If you can get over the steep prices (ramen for $18.50??), I think you'll find this place worth 5 stars, too. 

Food:
All of the ramen is chicken broth based. Two things about this: 1) for an American's palate, it is comforting, a crazy gourmet chicken noodle soup on crack; and 2) while there's lots of hubbub about tonkotsu broths, in Tokyo if you're good, you're good, regardless of the broth base. And this broth is frigging outstanding. I also thought it would be awkward to eat a whole chicken leg with chopsticks, but oh baby how that meat falls right off the bone. We also got the Chicken Nanban, which I would recommend without hesitation. I will be back to try their other ramen for sure, as well as the rest of the varied menu.

Everything else:
It was a short wait for the 2 of us during dinner rush on a Saturday night, less than 15 minutes. We sat at the bar and our server was kind, bubbly, and helpful. Formidable alcohol options. Great location for extending the evening in Hayes Valley or on Polk after dinner. It was very clean and modern with a dark-ish ambiance, yet menu was easy to read. Because of the prices, don't think of this place as your neighborhood ramen joint. It's elevated, and the only ramen broth I've had in the city that can come close, but isn't consistent, is Izakaya Sozai.
author: Lisa H.

description:
I know, this is sort of a stretch to say but it is my favorite ramen spot in SF so far. I was a little hestitant on the chicken base for ramen but it was very rich like your classic pork base ramen. What really gets me though is the noodles. A+ for the thick delicious real Japanese style noodles. I could have a couple pounds of it alone!

At one point, I went here 3x in one week. I guess you can call me the noodle fanatic or just a fatty :) With that said, I've tried everything on the menu and the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen is a MUST. Definitely hefty on the price tag but so worth it. The other notable dish would be the spicy rice ball.
author: Nho C.

description: BOMBBBBB; the chicken was so delicious & I am not a big fan of chicken. Would've been a 5/5, but it was pretty pricey... We ordered two of the chicken leg ramen, Vietnamese coffee ice cream sandwich & chicken bao. Definitely enjoyed all of it!
author: Victoria T.

description:
Tl;Dr the best ramen in SF (possibly the bay area) but damn expensive

Don't be deterred by the chicken based soup! This is some of the most flavorful and thickest soup you'll get outside of Japan. If you've been to Kahoo down in San Jose, the thickness is similar, but the taste is out of this world. I had the fall-off-the-bone chicken leg ramen and wifey had the tan tan ramen. The tan tan wasn't bad... Not the best and not too unique, but pricier by a few dollars than the competition. 

My paitan soy sauce ramen was amazing. Justified $18.50 amazing. Thick, flavorful broth (without being too salty), perfect chewy noodles, and a chicken leg that I can pick apart with chopsticks. I haven't been blown away by a ramen bowl since Japan and Tsujita down in LA. 

We also had cucumbers that we hoped were Ippudo-esque but we're disappointed both by flavor and price. The rice balls were good, but again, overpriced at $5ish per ball. On a side note, there was a cook individually wrapping made from scratch pot stickers that I'd like to try in the future. 

I'll come back over and over just for the ramen and nothing else, as it could be a $20 1 bowl restaurant and still be successful.
author: Jeff N.

description: The soy sauce ramen is sooooo good! The noodles are cooked just the right amount and the chicken leg is so soft that the meat comes off from the bone. I tried mensho ramen too, and I thought it was overrated - but this place is definitely worth the wait!
author: Ella K.

description: Had the Shoyu Paitan ramen. The broth was particularly flavorful and rich, and the chicken drumstick that's included was fall-off-the-bone tender. This is now my favorite ramen place in SF.
author: Robert L.

description:
After a short wait at 6:30 on a Friday, my boyfriend and I were seated in the very attractive dining area. We ordered some wine by the glass and thought it was a surprisingly fairly priced glass of wine until said wine was presented. Tasty, but a rather light pour.

We ordered the edamame hummus to start which was a nice filler and had an interesting flavor. However, I will pass on it when I revisit Nojo simply because I want to leave as much room as possible for the ramen. 

We both ordered the Soy Sauce Ramen and were really impressed. The broth was creamy and flavorful (enhanced by the black garlic oil floating over the top), the egg was cooked to a perfect soft-boil consistency, and the mix of shallots and other toppings worked very well. The star of the show was definitely the falling-off-the-bone chicken leg and thigh. The meat was tender and flavorful and the browned skin was delicious. It added a rich fattiness and mouthfeel to the dish without being a rubbery blob of fat. 

We agreed it was the best ramen we've had in the area and we both typically prefer a pork based ramen as opposed to the chicken one that Nojo exclusively offers. We couldn't stop commenting how much we were enjoying it during and after the meal. I'll definitely be recommending Nojo to all ramen enthusiasts. 

Service was fine, nothing to write home about. Probably because a bunch of tables got up at the same time and the waitstaff had to flip a bunch of tables. 

Expensive, but worth it if you're looking for a hearty bowl of chicken ramen that will really hit the spot. I'll be back!!
author: Anna D.

description: Yes the line is long but it is worth it! I recommend the vegetable ramen, as well as the Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso, the broth is so rich!
author: Azul O.

description: It's chicken-broth based Ramen, served in an atmosphere that manages to be both a little bit Hayes St hip and super corporate, with canned speeches from waiters and an assembly line kitchen that produces food of consistently good quality. My companion would have given this place five stars. But this is my review so: 4 for decor and location, and, like much of Hayes Valley, 3.5 for food that I am rounding up because - truth be told - I finished the bowl, a first for me.
author: Morris R.

description: Good ramen, authentic flavor. No ridiculous line, even on weekends, unlike Mensho. The matcha ice cream sandwich was disappointingly small. Also, the portions aren't necessarily worth the exorbitant price ($18 for ramen? Really?).
author: Ananya M.

description: We went in rght when they opened. We ordered the rice ball wrapped with pork belly and spicy garlic chille, also their special chicken paitan and miso ramen. The soup base is thick so thats good when it comes to ramen. The rice ball is delicious too. The whole chicken leg was tender too. The only things I didnt like were bit on the chewy side, the price for a ramen cost more than other places. The service was good too. So two ramens and two rice balls with tax and 15% tips, We paid $60. Other than that, It was all good.
author: Jackson W.

description: I ordered the ramen and it was decent. It wasn't the best I've had or the worst. Luckily went on a day it  was easy to get in for lunch. Overall good experience and good service. Loved the menu in English on one side and Japanese on the other.
author: Brent T.

description:
Honestly, I would have given the ramen closer to 5 stars; the tan tan spicy ramen was awesome.

TL;DR- good food. Okay service. Shitty food timing. 

They clearly still need to figure out the service aspect. First thing I did was order wine and edamame. My date and I sat there for about another 20 minutes before our waitress took our appetizer and entree order (despite the fact that we had that "closed menu ready to order" look for over 15 minutes). 

Ramen came and was awesome! Half way through our ramen, the appetizers came (womp womp, little late). Was pretty much too full to eat them, but my taste of the chicken bun was nice. 

Here's the kicker- after we finished the appetizers, the owner came to deliver the edamame (he was clearly confused why we would order edamame so late in a meal- because who the hell would do that, amirite?!). He apologized that it came 45 minutes late, which was nice, but still charges us the 4$.... 

That being said, I'll try it again soon!
author: Jordan W.

description: I had the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce and it was delicious. The chicken was perfectly cooked and fell off the bone. The broth was flavorful and decadent. I thoroughly enjoyed my dish and will definitely be back again. It's a cool space, central location and good food. A bit pricey for ramen, but you're partly paying for the ambiance and location. For better or for worse, this isn't your hole in the wall ramen joint.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Fantastic service and food.

Appetizer: Gyoza and spicy bamboo cilantro. Highlight of my meal was definitely the cilantro bamboo. SO GOOD! 

Main: We ordered the spicy chicken ramen and ramen with the whole chicken leg? Both of them were very flavorful but I felt like mine was pretty salty. But I felt the ingredients were really unique as I've never had red onion in my ramen before. Either way, both were pretty good. 

Service: another highlight of the meal. I felt well taken care of and the waitresses constantly came back to our table to Check on us, refill our water Etc. they were genuinely really nice and sweet! 

Overall, I would def come back to try the different dishes!
author: Samantha S.

description: Amazing ramen! I had the spicy chicken tan tan miso ramen and it came out with steamy hot broth. The noodles were just a little crunchy, not soggy like most ramen places. The spiciness was perfect, only complaint is that the broth was a bit on the thicker side. Came here with my boyfriend several times and he always finishes the entire bowl and drinks all the soup.
author: Connie S.

description:
As our last day in San Francisco came to an end, we decided to look up a few places near where we were staying so that we could rush back to get our stuff and head to the greyhound station. 

Nojo Ramen came up on Yelp, and despite having few ratings and reviews, we decided to give it a shot! It's definitely a very adorable restaurant and I love the ambiance inside! We had a bit of trouble getting seated but I think it's just because we were a large party. Other people were seated quite easily. The waitresses are kind and attentive and we put our orders in quickly and they were brought out to us not too long after that! We all ordered a variety of their ramen, both dry and with broth. I had their chicken paitan tan-tan spicy miso and I quite enjoyed it! It's definitely got a great spicy kick to it, and the flavors are great! But the broth was a little too rich and salty, and it had me gulping down water through the whole meal. The noodles are also a lot harder than expected. I know most authentic ramen restaurants have tougher egg noodles than what you would get at other places, but I was a little thrown off by it! 

I'm the end i'd give them an overall 3.5 stars because while I enjoyed the meal, it was still a little disappointing given the price. You can definitely get much, much better ramen at half the price at other places! I probably won't be putting this place on my list of must haves the next time in the city, but it was okay. Just nothing impressive.
author: Krystyl C.

description:
Delicious and unique ramen in Hayes Valley!
My boyfriend and I had a great experience here and I think it had a lot to do with the customer service. Our server was funny and personable, he made us feel right at home and his recommendations were exactly what we were looking for. 
The takoyaki fries were a great starter, but I think next time we'll skip it and try the buns or get two servings of the rice balls instead (we got the spicy garlic rice ball this time and it was really good)!
All of the ramen is chicken based and our favorite one has to be the Soy Sauce one. The whole chicken leg in the broth was really tender. Everything was flavorful and not too salty. 
We'll definitely be back again to try the other ramens soon!
author: Sylvia T.

description:
2 stars for the hype.
We tried the spicy miso and tori paitan ramen dishes.
Spicy miso tastes like a miso soup gone bad with some chili sauce on top. The tori is a thick chicken soup with vermicelli. Both are way to salty.
I'll stick to traditional ramen places, that do it right and do it well.
author: Yevgeny K.

description: If you're looking for an Asian-fusion restaurant with dark ambiance, this is the right ramen place. Won't recommend it if you're looking for authentic ramen. Ordered the chicken leg ramen and the broth is super creamy and thick and personally too salty.
author: Priscilla Y.

description:
Fantastic. 
FYI this is only chicken paitan. I love my rich pork-based ramen too but this is pretty great stuff. 
I was surprised at how rich and creamy the broth was. I talked with one of the servers about this. It almost appears as though there's cream in the broth it's so rich, but that's not the case. 
The noodles are thick and chewy and perfectly cooked. Very impressive. My bowl had a hint of citrus from fresh yuzu zest. The bamboo was surprising. Not your normal long rectangles (which I think are often from a can). These are big pieces of fresh bamboo. The tomagos were brought  on the side, but cooked well. They had soft, orange yolks. The bowl also had three good sized "Fluffy Tskune balls". I love tsukune and these were a good version to be put in a broth. 


Side notes, 
This is the same Nojo location as when they did yakitori, so it is small. I expect lines to start forming soon.  Service is done with this open/ everyone takes care of everyone approach. You'll have several different people bringing you food and talking to you. I felt well taken care of but some might find this odd. The only other dish we got was gyoza and they were also cooked perfectly.
author: Mark R.

description:
came here last night, and it was good.  there is a short wait, but luckily one of my friends got here earlier, so when the rest of us showed up, we were able to sit.  they usually don't let you sit unless everyone is there, so one of my friends was running late, and we were forced to order for her.  for 5 of us, we shared 2 ramens, the poke bowl, and a couple small apps.  the avocado crab salad was super good, as were the poke and the spicy tan tan ramen.  

i liked the food, but service was kinda pushy, and our server kept rushing us to order and then rushed to take our plates away after.
author: Helen T.

description: I enjoyed this place when I came for the dinner the previous week before attending a San Francisco Ballet performance. The prices here are a few dollars higher than most ramen places, but I think it's worthwhile since this gives me a new dining option that I like prior to attending performances at either Davies Hall or the War Memorial Opera House if I lack time for dinner elsewhere first. I ordered the spicy miso option and really enjoyed both the broth and noodle. Service was friendly too.
author: H K.

description: Popular spot. The ambiance is fun and hip. The drink menu is great. The ramens are good but not exceptional. Come here for a fun outing with friends not to taste the best ramen in town.
author: Ruben K.

description: Nojo has good ramen but it is only worthy once. It is overpriced because the quality of food is not worth $18.50. You get similar or better quality for 13.00 elsewhere, but without the extra $5.50 for SF high life pretense.
author: Loan L.

description: Creamy, fragrant, yummy broth. So rich in texture and the flavor is amazing. I have no idea what spices are in there but I found orange rinds and I don't know how it all works together but it DOES. Delicious chicken meatballs. Yes it's a bit more costly than a typical bowl of ramen but I think it's worth it. Better than the ramen spots I've been to in Los Angeles. If I'm ever in town I would come back.
author: Tanya S.

description:
So, we went to the Hayes Valley Urban Street Fair. Did some shopping (yea!) and wanted to grab something to eat. We saw this ramen place and thought we'd try it out (actually my daughter picked the place for us). The first thing I saw was that the dining area is pretty small, but lively and clean. The service absolutely FANTASTIC!!! They had us seated in 10 minutes, our waitress gave us a quick run down of the menu (in great detail), and we were able to choose the dishes we liked based on her suggestions.

My daughter had the chicken teriyaki rice bowl. It was a small serving, but she said was tasty and filling. (she was all smiles). I had the Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso. I liked it; tasty, spicy, with some kick. I would've liked more noodles with the ground chicken. 

I'll have to come back here at night time. This place seems like it can be a real cool place to mingle a little bit ;-).
author: Marcus M.

description:
My brother wanted ramen, so we looked for the nearest one. It was a little busy but got seated pretty quick, the waitress was very friendly and attentive. 

I got the chicken paitan ramen, my brother got the chicken paitan soy sauce and his girlfriend got the teriyaki bowl (wasn't feeling ramen) 

Mine was alright but for the price I was hoping there would be more too it. I tried my brother and kinda wished that I got what he got and the teriyaki bowl I wouldn't recommend it at all. 

All and all... I shall be trying other ramen places as well
author: Olyvia N.

description: Absolutely fantastic food! I had never tried ramen before but after eating here... I may never eat anything other than ramen again. Can't wait until the next time I get to eat here.
author: Andrew B.

description:
My thoughts on the "new" Nojo:

* Like most restaurants in Hayes Valley, I left feeling like I had just enjoyed a really tasty meal, but also like I'd paid way more than I wanted to for said meal. My husband and I ordered two ramens, an order of gyoza, and a salad. We drank water and still ended up paying around $70 for a casual Friday night dinner when all was said and done.

* The ramens (I ordered the spicy miso ramen and my husband ordered the paitan ramen) were both richly flavored and very substantial. Neither of us actually ended up finishing our dish. Maybe it was a little too salty? Still, were they worth $15-17 each. Umm, no.

* The gyoza were delicious, but I may not be the best judge of this because I've never met a panfried dumpling I didn't like. $10 for four seemed a bit steep. Squishing another onto the plate would have felt like a better value.

* The tofu and avocado salad was also quite tasty. The bonito on top gave it a little extra something something.

* As other people have mentioned, charging an additional $1.50 for (presumably artisanal) cilantro to go with your ramen is crazy talk. Seriously, people? How much cilantro are we talking about here?

* This place was surprisingly NOT vegetarian friendly. Every single ramen is chicken-based. Vegetarian friends will be stuck ordered a bunch of small plates and salads.

* I miss the awesome meyer lemon and mushroom tempura that they served at the old Nojo :(
author: Ali S.

description: We ended up waiting about 40 minutes, but the ramen was worth it! The group I went with all ordered the spicy miso ramen and were impressed. The food took a little while, but with how packed it was it was expected. The only complaint I would have is that there was not enough noodles. Other than that I would definitely go back!
author: Nicholas T.

description:
DO NOT COME HERE unless you want to deal with horrible service, or if you have anything to do afterward (at any point in your life) and you want to get to it on time. 

I know a lot of people might come here before a show since it is close to theaters, but DO NOT DO THIS if you hope to actually eat and also make the show.

The first time I came here, service was very slow even though not that busy. The waitress also forgot our appetizer and it came out after we reminded her, after we had almost finished our meal.

On Friday night last week, I tried to come here with a group of four and had a horrible experience. Two people had to make a show nearby, so we decided to arrive two hours early at the restaurant to have plenty of time. It was pretty busy, but the man taking names told us there was only one group of four ahead and it shouldn't be too long so we decided to wait. The group ahead of us sat down and the man came back and said that since we were "such a large party" of four people (???) and that other group just sat down it could be a little while. We waited for an hour, and while we waited many parties of two came in and were seated immediately off the street. Obviously this was very frustrating. Is 4 a huge and unexpected number to sit at a restaurant? Why not push together two empty two person tables or add some chairs instead of making four people wait an hour? We were watching the group ahead of us at the four person table and after an hour they had barely ordered. We politely asked the person seating us how long he thought it would be and he replied in a mean tone "I have no idea." After ignoring and seating everyone ahead of us for an hour, maybe he could try to be nice? Since there were so many people already waiting forever for food, I guess he could afford to be rude to customers. Anyway, at that point we left and got pizza down the street. I love ramen and was hoping to be a regular at this place, but I can't really wait an hour for a $20 bowl of noodles so I will never be back. I am embarrassed that I recommended this place and tried to bring others.
author: K J.

description:
I was looking for a good place to have Ramen in SF during the weekend, so I decided to give a chance to this place "hot and new". The first impression was very positive, and it became even  better when we got our food. We had Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce, Gyoza, Chicken Paitan Tomato and an awesome wine, Gundlach Bundschu. The ramen was delicious: creamy, rich and full of body. 

Don't expect to find the traditional ramen with pork broth, because they serve only chicken ramen made with chicken broth, and it is delicious. Definitely recommended.
author: Alberto V.

description: The best ramen I've had in San Francisco, hands down. I've been to 5-6 ramen spots in the city and this is by far the best - I think it's the broth that did it.
author: Laura B.

description: Nojo is a tori paitan style ramen restaurant. This means that the broth is created from chicken bones and is pretty heavy and thick.  It's definitely different from something lighter like a soy based shoyu.  If you're not into the thicker and richer broths, I would not recommend going to this restaurant.  The tenacity of the noodles is fine, but they are missing that delicious yellow ramen flavor.  I know, that was a pretty odd way of describing ramen noodle flavor, but that is the best way I can put it into words.  I have been here twice and the first time they had gyoza and this most recent time, they were no where to be found.  I guess they took them off, which is okay with me, as they took 20 minutes to hand make and prepare.  For side dishes, the chicken nanban is basically chicken karaage.  It's what you would expect from karaage.  Please note that it's $.50 extra to make this dish spicy (say, what?).  Nojo has a solid and delicious broth with good tasting accompaniments such as a slow braised chicken leg, but it doesn't have that wow factor for me.
author: Josh S.

description: This is definitely Asian fusion. I didn't realize they only did chicken broth. It had little flavor and tasted odd, as if they added cream?! It was supposed to be spicy miso. Never tasted anything like it and that's not a compliment. were ready. We've never been here so wanted to take some time. Then two minutes later she asked again. Won't be coming here again. Service was rushed. Once we sat down she asked if we
author: Vanessa B.

description: The chicken paitan ramen is to die for. The broth is thick and amazing, the noodles are solid, and the tsukune meatballs are the icing on this sodium-infused cake.
author: Glendon M.

description: The restaurant is small, but very sleek. The service is efficient. Annnnd the ramen is yummy. I've only been once and I ordered the veggie ramen. The broth tasted very rich and I could barely tell it was a vegetable-based broth because of the depth of flavor. The raw corn and okra added nice texture and flavor to the soup. The only downside is that the menu is bit stark. I only saw chicken, fish or vegetable options on the menu, so I can imagine a lot of people would want pork and beef ramen added to the mix. I also wish they were open for lunch! I will definitely be back.
author: John L.

description: Possibly the best ramen I've had. Their broth is so flavorful and the chicken leg was so tender it just falls apart when you touch it with chopsticks. There is so much attention to detail in the dishes and restaurant.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Unfortunately, my bowl of Ramen did not measure up to other places like Orenchi or the famous Mensho.   I ordered the Paitan Ramen with the chicken leg, which is the most expensive Ramen on the menu ($18.5).  Unfortunately, the soup was way too salty even for my taste.   Just to be clear, I am famous among my friends for liking my food salty, so when I say the soup was too salty, it is saying lot.   The chicken leg was fine, and the Ramen was cooked just right.

We arrived at 6:00 pm on a Wednesday and waited 45 min to be seated.  Given my less than satisfactory experience with the Ramen, for which I paid $18.5, I don't see why I will go back.  I think Orenchi serves a much better bowl of Ramen for a lower price without the wait.
author: Will T.

description:
Great and uniquely flavored ramen. Very interesting that it is all chicken based. SF meets Tokyo. The chicken leg is fall off the bone tender and the chicken meatballs are so delicate it's amazing. The gyozas are also really nice - some of the best I've ever had.

Friendly staff and great service too. Can't wait to go back!
author: Alex H.

description: I am vegetarian and this is my favorite ramen place. Their veggie miso ramen is delicious and I highly recommend it for all vegetarians. While this is not the most authentic ramen, it tastes fabulous.  The atmosphere is very modern and meant for much smaller groups. The wait seems to be very long but to me, its worth the standard 40 minute wait
author: Suruchi S.

description: Me and Mr. B (now 4.5 yrs old) pop in here quite often.  There are 2 private schools within 2 block radius. So we see a few kids here. B loves the Ramen, so do I
author: amit s.

description: Fantastic place!!! We will come here again. This is a reopening of the place. They have new owners and a new menu. Worth the visit!!!
author: Melissa L.

description: Came with a group of friends and we had the Chicken Paitan ramen. It was almost too beautiful to eat! Delicious, not too salty. I will be back!
author: Ella V.

description: Most ramen places in America I've tried were terrible, but this place is not bad at all, quite to my surprise. Ordered chicken paitan ranmen and chicken paitan soy sauce ramen, both were pretty good. They also had authentic onsen tamago.
author: Chen P.

description: The Dashi in this Ramen this aged for two days so the chicken just falls off the bone. One of the very few chicken  mDashis in the Bay Area and this Ramen was devastating. Uuuuumami. Moms had the vegetable Ramen and it was just meh. Five stars for sure.
author: Aaron G.

description: Great ramen with fresh ingredients.  Try Chicken noodle here.  You wouldn't regret.
author: Nikki U.

description: The ramen noodles are fresh and I love that the broths are chicken based, not pork. The flavors are very good and the ingredients are quality. I would give this a 3.5 stars if I could because service isn't great. It's moderately friendly but food just comes out when it comes out so you can get a cluster of several dishes at once and also have a large gap between dishes. They also forgot one of our dishes and did the same to the people next to us. Also on the second seating next to us, they brought the ramen out nearly immediately after the small plates so by the time they had finished eating the small plates the ramen had been sitting for quite some time- not ideal. They didn't apologize for these things when brought to their attention, just said yes it comes out when it comes out and for the forgotten items just asked if we still wanted them (we cancelled ours because the ramen had already come out) and the people next to use were done with their entire meal already.
author: Piper W.

description: Admittedly, sometimes the wait can be long. Without overhyping the food, I'd still say it's worth it. Nojo has friendly service, tasty ramen, and an inviting atmosphere. I like sitting at the bar and watching the chefs, but also appreciate table seating for when I come with a larger party. Portions are filling and while it's a bit pricey, it's probably my favorite ramen place in the city. Check it out!
author: Amri I.

description: Amazing food. Amazing service. One of my favorite restaurants in the city! I'd recommend a dish but everything is incredible! It's a hidden gem that's getting really popular. It is totally worth the 10-20 minute wait.
author: Abby Z.

description: Finally a place that satisfied my ramen cravings! I came here on a Friday night with some friends and it already looked packed inside and out. Luckily we didn't wait too long for a table of three, which was surprising to me. The inside of the restaurant is not too big so the volume of sound was pretty loud. I had the Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce and it did not disappoint! The chicken was soft and tender and fell right off the bone. The broth was simple and packed with flavor. The staff was very friendly and attentive. Towards the end I felt like the meal got a little heavy, but that's my usual attitude towards ramen. I will definitely be coming back!
author: Teresa N.

description: Amazing ramen, noodles are perfect, spicy one - yum! Must get fall off the bone chicken leg!! I swear, not a ramen aficionado, but who knew chicken ramen would be dope- plus it's right in my hood!! Xoxo
author: Caroline L.

description: Very different ramen than I am used to, but absolutely delicious.  The portions are generous, but the price is a bit high to warrant a 5 star review.  If you are craving ramen, this will hit the spot, just loosen your purse string beforehand.
author: Jay P.

description: Possibly my favorite ramen place in SF (keep in mind I'm from San Mateo where there's as many ramen joints as Starbucks). I love that its ramen menu is different from the usual tonkatsu/soy/miso options. The only thing I'd skip is the rice ball, which was fine but not worth the money. Finish with the delicious and adorable ice cream sandwich!
author: Jen K.

description: I came here for the newly opened Nojo Ramen on a Sunday and I really like the location and the space, but it is def overpriced for the food. I ordered the Spicy chicken Soboro tossed noodles and while I have to say the noodles and everything that accompanied it was very good, the price on it was a little high. My girlfriend ordered the chicken paitan soy sauce ramen and it was very flavorful, the broth was a little fatty which I love, but again the price was a little steep for a bowl of ramen.
author: Brandon C.

description: Nothing to say - It's THE BEST Ramen in San Francisco.
author: Takahiro K.

description:
Who knew chicken broth ramen would be this good! 

Please open for lunch on Saturday as well
author: Chris C.

description: VERY expensive for NOT good food. It's ramen, how do you mess up that? I don't know, but they managed to do it. Broth had just an odd, off taste and after taste and noodles were not cooked enough, just slightly less than crunchy. The ambiance is terrible, very large and cavernous place, I think they are going for like an SF typer vibe? I've heard that the place can be packed, but I've never seen it.
author: Jeffery H.

description: Fell in love with this place awhile back but recent visits have let us down. Super salty!
author: Jollie C.

description: Delicious ramen, beautiful and hip ambiance. One star off for forgetting our appetizer when we were starving, but the ramen was worth the wait.
author: Ange R.

description: What pretentious people. Wouldn't even let me sit down in a restaurant that was entirely empty except for one table of 4, nobody on the waiting list.
author: Dina G.

description: The ramen here is really delicious and the portions are big. We tried the chicken paitan and the chicken paitan tomato.  Both were full of flavor. We also had the steamed chicken buns as an appetizer. Def will be back for our next ramen craving.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 5/5
Value: 2.5/5

Make no mistake, the food is good, service is good, but it's pricey.  A bowl of ramen is roughly $20+ after tax and tip - perhaps of the high rent cost.  It's fun to try the chicken broth.  But probably won't be going back because of the price.
author: Alan P.

description:
Love, love, love their ramen!
I've only been here once, a few weeks ago, and fell in love with their soy ramen dish. I have been fantasizing about their ramen ever since and am waiting for the opportunity to come back here.
author: Schisandra S.

description: I ordered the Chicken Paitan Tan Tan Spicy Miso ramen. Surprisingly delicious! The broth was very rich and creamy and extremely flavorful. The only thing was there was hella cilantro in it, but I don't like cilantro, so that may just be me.. haha Staff was also very friendly!
author: Lina C.

description: This spot has some seriously kick ass chicken paitan ramen. One of my favorite bowls of ramen in the city. Broth was extremely clean with sophisticated flavors and the chicken leg was fall of the bone tender. Cool interior, would be a great spot for date night. Only complaint is that the menu items are slightly over priced but that's what you get in Hayes valley. Would have given a 5 star all the way if the ramen was 2-3 dollars cheaper. Overall a great experience.
author: Charles W.

description: Best spicy chicken ramen I have had..... YUM! Tiny restaurant so don't expect a comfortable waiting area.
author: Tim Z.

description: Open times on yelp are in incorrect! We showed up at 240pm on Sunday and they wouldn't serve us, saying that were closed at 230.
author: Mars H.

description: The best spicy chicken ramen I've ever had!  Really high quality ingredients! Could tell the ramen noodles were so fresh by the texture and taste.
author: Lin P.

description: Simply excellent ramen. And great, friendly service. What better combination can you ask for? There are a lot of so-so ramen-ya in the city but few are authentic or, like Nojo, are authentic in Japanese taste but bringing it to a whole new level. Can't wait to go back. Thank goodness!
author: Chou K.

description: Amazing food, really nice service, the wait is completely worth it!
author: Mauricio G.

description:
Chicken Paitan and Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce were both good.  Both broths had a lot of flavor.  Chicken leg was very tender.  Noodles were al dente.  However, both were extremely rich and heavy.

Crab and avocado salad was ok - it's a mix of real crab meat and avocado in a mayonnaise based sauce.  Not blown away.
author: Allison C.

description: Fun place! Friendly staff and food is delicious! I got the chicken Paitan ramen. Priced average for SF, portion is decent. I was not able to finish my ramen.
author: Elisa H.

description: It was ok. We were going to an event nearby so we stopped in to eat. The portions were really small and expensive.  My husband had the ramen with the chicken leg in it and enjoyed it. He also ordered the rice roll or something like that and it was so small and so expensive.  We just couldn't believe it. It's ok but I would never go back.
author: Amy V.

description:
We just decided to eat whatever, so I just picked this place because it was within walking distance and close by. I love the atmosphere. I got the Spicy Chicken Soboro Tossed Noodle. It was good but it was a bit spicy and had a kick to it. But overall it was yummy. I didn't really want to sit at the bar tables but we were hungry, so that was ok, I guess. 

Because the bar tables were crowded and everyone was sitting at the table, I accidentally bumped my elbow onto this short asian waitress as I was trying to reach for my phone in my pocket. And you wouldn't believe how she reacted to me even after I said sorry like twice and I really meant it. I wouldn't do it that on purpose! Anyways that look she gave me the creep and makes me very hesitant to come back to this place. She gave me the eery murder look like she wanted to freaking kill me! I wanted to get out of the restaurant seriously! I was like ummm.... ok?? Kinda like don't know what to say except "please don't hurt me?" I looked up down the room and there she was giving me the murder death look again. After that I did not want to look at her in eye at all, but I had to when I got my check. She was fairly nice until my friend wanted separate tabs, and so I asked if we can do that. She gave me the annoyed look. She said next time please let us know." I was like ok??? hmmm do I even want to come back to this restaurant again? Idk. I;m not going to say she's a b*tch, but I did imagine her as being one only because of how murderish she looked like she wanted to b*tch at someone. 

But anyways that was really poor customer service. I never had someone tell me that I needed to tell them ahead of time about keeping the tabs separate and give attitude like that. 

This restaurant gets 2 star for the food and one star to the guy who gave me water and to the girl who brought me the correct spoon and was nice to it. The overall customer experience was meh.... I really hope the owners keep their waitress/waiters in check and to be nicer. I also understand she's probably having a really bad day and probably overworked, which means they may need to get a new job and enjoy it...
author: xaznbabyx C.

description: Their basic chicken paitan ramen is very good. Very tasty thick broth with hints of yuzu and ginger (probably other stuff too, but my tongue not that sensitive), with chicken meatballs, bamboo shoots and nice al dente thick style ramen noodles. Gyoza relatively mild flavored. They served them to us after the ramen had arrived, so they tasted rather bland in comparison to the rich broth, however, the gyoza are very juicy, and probably not bad. We'll ask for them first next time. Staff friendly and helpful. Noise level high. Pretty expensive for ramen, but you know, that's the neighborhood...
author: Bruce C.

description: This place is awesome!   I'm a big fan of chicken and given this place does 'everything' chicken based, it was something I needed to try.  We had the super spicy ramen bowl with a hard boiled egg as an extra.  We also tried the chicken fritters (spicy) and both desserts.  Besides the server coming across as 'pushy' and being seated right beside the door, the experience, service, and food was great.  Definitely will come back.
author: Vik M.

description: This place was incredible. The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce ramen was so good, the chicken was so tender. The hamachi app wasn't bad either. Def recommend!
author: Frank P.

description: The broth is really delicious. We were told that it was simmered for 2 to 3 days. I'm not used to having chicken Ramen, but it was quite good. Service was a little slow, but it was expected. There was a sign that said to expect slow service and apologized in advance because it was their soft opening.
author: Alton Y.

description: The ramen here is amazing. I highly recommend the soy sauce one or the tomato based one, both were awesome. It's a little cramped in the restaurant, but the ambiance is really nice, service is great! Certainly worth trying.
author: Aya O.

description: I was surprised to learn Nojo turned into a ramen joint after serving up successful Japanese tapas  for many years. I had the poke salad and the notorious chicken paitan soy sauce. The broth was seriously something special. I'd take that over traditional pork based ramen broth any day of the week. The chicken leg was equally incredible, flaking off the bone in perfectly sized chunks. A little salty, but hey, it's ramen. My only complaint is the service. By no means did we have a 2-3 hour meal, but we waited 30 minutes to get in, so we did want to enjoy ourselves. At multiple points throughout the evening, we were pressured to hurry the heck up. Literally 2 minutes after signing the bill, the waitress comes over and asks if we're waiting for something. I get it, but this isn't $8 ramen you pickup at a window. It's $20 a bowl and the service should reflect that.
author: Alex B.

description: Pleasantly surprised with this new ramen place! I recommend the Chicken Paitan, because the broth is rich and creamy and the meatballs are SO FLUFFY. It's like eating a beautiful, delicious cloud. It's a little pricier than most of the top ramen places in the Bay (Orenchi, Ramen Dojo), but it's definitely worth a try considering how rare it is to get chicken broth ramen here in the States.
author: Tony H.

description:
Dabomb.com

I got the spicy chicken and my friend got the chicken leg. Both were DELISH, the service was speedy and cheerful, and the ambiance is hip casual.
author: Hello P.

description: The ramen with the chicken leg (soy something) is better than all the other ramens. Don't get the gyoza, they give you like 4 pieces for 10 bucks and it doesn't taste any better than frozen dumplings from Costco. Crab salad with avocado is SOLID!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Alex M.

description: The ramen is too salty here. Not worth the price I paid. The waitress has no patient and kind of rude when we ask how we could get the ramen less salty.
author: Melissa K.

description: Best ramen in the area! Really flavorful, filling and authentic. My go-to is Chicken Paitan Tan-Tan Spicy Miso - delicious.
author: Joe S.

description: It's definitely not Asian style. I have to choose between chicken and veggie. Pork will be a transitional option for ramen. And it's pricey btw.
author: Luki H.

description: First time here, but it won't be my last. We had four items on the menu: tofu and avocado salad, fried rice ball, chicken nanban, and chicken Saipan ramen (regular). The ramen was by far the best, with the other items needing a bit of work. I incorrectly expected more traditional izakaya style items, but they were more exploratory. The salad was nothing special and had a bit too much dressing. I also thought it was slightly pricey for what it was. The fried rice ball was actually wrapped in pork belly which should have been am improvement, but it didn't add much. Flavor was good but it was lacking in texture. The chicken nanban waa definitely not my favorite. The best thing about it is it came with greens. However, I was impressed by the clean, light, and tasty flavor of the chicken ramen. The meatballs were fluffy as advertised and made a great addition to the ramen. It came with bamboo shoots and freshly grated ginger which enhanced the flavor. The noodles were fresh and perfectly al dente, making this one of my favorite ramens in the bay area. I will definitely come back and try the other ramen!
author: Katrina S.

description: Would be the duke had i checked in each time since they've opened. I'm a loyal customer. Bomb dot Com
author: Mack F.

description: Went here on a Friday and waited 20+ minutes. Normally I find that a long wait but I'm starting to understand that most places in the city take a 20+ wait unless you made reservations. With that said, I really enjoyed eating here. The service I thought was great and very helpful, always checking on us if we needed anything. Ordered the Teriyaki Chicken Bun to start with, and thought it was okay, however it might be because I prefer pork in my buns. Teriyaki Chicken Bun is worth a try though. As for ramen, I ordered the Chicken Paitan Tomato, I absolutely loved this! It's different from traditional ramen with the tomatoes adding a somewhat pasta type taste. I thought it was true to what is exactly in the ingredients, I was definitely not surprised and just how I thought it would taste and more! I also ordered a Ice Green Tea, which was not sweetened however it complimented my dinner very well. The Monaka Ice Cream Sandwhich - Matchadoodle, is tiny, the ice cream is green tea and snickerdoodle and the waffle type thing holding it is sesame type flavored. Well overall, this place is def worth it to try! I'll be returning!
author: Jen A.

description: Great ramen, authentic experience. I sat at the counter and could see a good number of complements they combined to make their delicious ramen. Highly recommend! Plus, we arrived at 7:00 pm on a Friday night without a reservation and only waited for 30 minutes. Not to mention that they served Sake outside while we waiting.
author: Montina F.

description: The ramen is very good for sure and the space is nice. But prices are way too high! Even Ippudo in NYC doesn't charge this much for better ramen. But it's good so try it!!
author: Ella M.

description: Finally, a good bowl of ramen in SF. Superior by a large margin. Innovative and truly tasty variants, homemade noodles, excellent side dishes (try the pork rice balls). If this is a 10 for the city, everything else (Orenchi - shamefully bad side dishes, Sozai - totally not worth the wait, Goku) is about a 5 or 6. Only close comp is Mensho but totally diff style.
author: Sebastian C.

description: Nojo added an amazing vegetarian ramen to their menu recently.  It is fantastic.....never have had anything like it -- delicious without being "rich," and with a grain that provides a "meaty" texture.  All four of us ordered it and loved it.  You can opt for no butter, which makes it vegan, which we did.  It was great!!
author: Teri G.

description: Creative I must say. But ramen was salty all around. Tried all my friends ramen dishes as well and we all agreed it's salty.
author: Shamoo S.

description: The Chicken Paitan Soy Sauce Ramen was delicious. The chicken leg was very tender. The noodles were cooked right. Waited about 10 minutes on a Thursday evening. By 8pm, there were plenty of seats (theatre crowd probably cleared out). But the price...$18.50...yikes!! I think I'd rather go to Orenchi Beyond and pay $13, sans chicken leg.
author: Q C.

description: I had the spicy ramen with miso broth. Absolutely amazing. The broth was perfectly seasoned. My girlfriend had the chicken ramen and it tasted a little too gingery. There was also a hair in her soup. Nevertheless, it was pretty good.
author: Tom P.

description: the ramen is incredibly salty...much more so than standard japanese ramen.  the quality of the chicken is high, but it is masked by salt, unfortunately.  almost inedible...there are much better ramen places in sf!!  NOT RECOMMENDED.
author: Max S.
